story:
Join Us in Planting Sustainable Urban Butterfly Gardens in South LA Schools, Providing Vital Environmental Education & Building a Healthier and Friendlier Community!


Local nonprofit, California Greenworks invites you to have a part in building a greener South LA, educating our kids on the environment and funding sustainable gardens at local schools…

Let's make our communities safer, healthier, more eco-friendly...


YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE RIGHT NOW >


TOGETHER WE CAN MAKE LA A BETTER PLACE!

Join us in transforming South Los Angeles into a beautiful, environmentally friendly community, while creating new opportunities for the next generation to improve the world themselves…

South L.A. may have come a long way in the last few years, but still desperately needs help in educating and equipping the next generation of leaders with the right knowledge and a healthy environment.

A registered 501 c3, California Greenworks is a nonprofit organization dedicated to beautifying neighborhoods, promoting environmental protection urban watersheds, community revitalization, education and creating leaders out of our students.

While South Los Angeles might be a safer place to live than it once was we and our children urgently need to be proactive about saving and improving our environment and making this a happier & healthier place to live.

This Campaign:

This campaign will enable California Greenworks and local volunteers and students to engage and complete 3 vital environment projects…

1. Sustainable Urban Water Conservation & Butterfly Garden

In collaboration with the Maya Angelou High School Environmental Club this campaign will cover the cost of soil materials, design work, professional labor, irrigation equipment, plants and a descriptive panel dedicating the urban garden in honor of American poet Dr. Maya Angelou at the South LA high school bearing her name.

This garden, in collaboration with Earth Day will utilize drought tolerant plants, materials and water conservation measures which will reduce the amount of water needed to supply plants nutrients over time, and create a learning space for students while offering environmental benefits by attracting butterfly and bird life to the garden. The project will also include a plaque dedicated to the school.

2. Hyde Park Blvd. Beautification

Completing tree planting and beautification projects on Hyde Park Blvd. which helps anchor environmental work and outreach in local schools. Funding from this campaign would help to defray the maintenance cost of the trees, cover watering and replacing stake pools, etc. and keep us going for the next 6 months.

3. Environmental Education & Establishing Gardens in 2 Additional South LA Schools

Funding environmental education in local schools, and assisting in setting up urban gardens at 2 new South Los Angeles, California schools.

ABOUT CALIFORNIA GREENWORKS:

California Greenworks is a registered 501 c3 nonprofit organization dedicated to community revitalization, environmental education, sustainability, creating green spaces and economic development in urban SoCal neighborhoods.

Previous projects include:

Water Links

This program is an environmental education program that Links the urban watershed to the Ocean targeted to 5th grade student and is a 4 week pilot program that raises awareness for environmental stewardship, pollution prevention, and water conservation within the urban communities.

Organizing EarthFest LA

EarthFestLA has been an annual, family oriented event focusing on environmental education and community health awareness. The event is billed as a concert for the environment and expo program.

Additional programs include: Compton Creek Pollution Prevention and environmental art contests.

Why Indiegogo?

·  Indiegogo is one of the most trusted, secure online platforms

·  We wanted to give everyone a chance to be involved in investing in the world's most valuable resources – our environment and kids. 

·  The more money we raise the better it will be and more schools and children we can reach

·  Full funding will help to get the best talent working on this to make it even better, and more impactful!

·  It's a great way for you and your kids to experience how crowdfunding works, and do something fun and meaningful together! After all, it’s not about us, it’s about your communities and future generations.

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

PLEASE SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN!

·  Contribute as much as you can

·  Use the Facebook, Twitter and G+ share buttons above

·  Email the link to everyone in your contact list

·  Tell everyone you know so that they can have the chance to be involved and make a huge difference

We’d love you to contribute, but your sharing alone is incredibly valuable and can make a HUGE difference!

Those interested in supporting the improvement of quality of life and environment in urban communities across South L.A. can show their support and make a tax deductible contribution via the big pink ‘Contribute Now’ button in the top right, or simply selecting a cool perk from the right hand column >

JOIN THE MISSION & HELP GREEN SOUTH LA NOW!

story:
Our names are Helen Walker & Harun Morrison. We work under the name They Are Here(www.theyarehere.net) as artists with a social practice. Alongside Florina Tudose, we are organising a project called SEEDS FROM ELSEWHERE over the next two years. Young refugees and migrants are invited to grow edible produce, plants and flowers from their homelands to create an urban garden in Finsbury Park. Over time the garden will become a portrait of our group and the journeys that individuals have made to get to London. The project also functions as a refuge from day-to-day concerns and offers an alternative space to share stories and ups and downs amongst a diverse group of people.

They Are Here will work closely with various groups, including Furtherfield Gallery (based in Finsbury Park) and Migrants Organise (http://www.migrantsorganise.org/), a community organization in West London and a platform where refugees and migrants organise for power, dignity and justice,  to facilitate a series of fortnightly gatherings. Art collective They Are Here draw on 10 years of experience of socially engaged projects, working with various groups across the public realm. Florina has been working with young refugees and asylum seekers for the past 2 years, and she is a passionate gardener.

Our campaign aims to raise funds to establish the gardening project and to maintain it. To do this, we need to buy tools, equipment and seeds, plus materials for building a polyethene greenhouse to support more fragile plants. We would like to provide food and drink to those who come to our meetings, encouraging people to return and spread the word about the project. We would also like to construct a pizza clay oven in the garden to create a more social gathering point. Ultimately, we want to create a space to invite the wider Finsbury Park community in to see what we have been doing.

In a time of turmoil regarding the status of the UK in the European Union, in which negative narratives around migration and refugees are present, we want to do something positive that creates a space for dialogue and a support network for those who may be struggling to find a place in London.

story:
Short Summary

Do you ever dream of adventure? Does your heart break for the disenfranchised and about environmental degradation? Do you ever wish you could support an adventure to help rectify tough challenges?

Hi, my name is Caleb Hopler, and I am passionate for environmental change and social justice. I am currently a senior at Virginia Tech, studying Environmental Resource Management, Forestry, and Environmental Economics. One strategic way I can enact my passion is through supporting Nicaraguan locals by coordinating fuel-efficient stove building, thus limiting deforestation, lowering health problems caused by inefficient combustion, and promoting a healthier and more sustainable lifestyle.

Please, help finance my trip and, through this support, take this journey with me.

What I Need & What You Get

I have received a scholarship for this trip that covers half of my costs! 

The full cost of the trip, everything included, is $2,500.

I only have $250 of personal funds to contribute. Therefore, after my scholarship and personal contribution, I need $1,000.

Be sure to check my Perks section of this page! I'm offering hand-written, personal thank you letters, a photo album of my best pictures, a personal video recorded during my stay in Nicaragua so you can see what I see, and even souvenirs!

Thank you so much for your time and support. This funding will help contribute to changing lives!

The Impact

This work will provide families with cooking stoves that are more efficient in combustion, which helps the area in a myriad of ways. By having a more complete combustion, stoves require less woody fuel, thus slowing deforestation and helping families save money. Women are able to support themselves through micro-businesses cooking tortillas. Children are able to go back to school, since they do not have to collect as much firewood.

Traditional stoves are over an open fire with little to no insulation and ventilation. Economic, social, and health issues are prominent due to poor stove construction. Last year I helped to supply five biomass cook stoves for residents, two of which were for domestic uses with the Joca-Justa stove model, and three for commercial use with the Emelda model. Both stoves utilize combustion chambers in a newer rocket elbow design. This design aids in air flow, distribution of heat, and wood size restriction. These stove models are overall designed to decrease wood fuel use by ~ 40% - 80%, reduce emissions by 98%, and increase family income by 25%.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pray for Nicaragua and for my group. Pray for safe travels and success with reaching out to the people. 

Also please help me get the word out about my campaign! Feel free to copy and paste the URL, but you can also utilize the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Greetings,

Welcome to our site. We will be having two separate events to honor Winter Solstice. One ceremony will be held on the shores of Lake Tahoe to honor Cave Rock.  Tribal family members, elders and supporters that know the calling will attend and do the important work that is called for at this 10 Million year old ancient, sacred place.

The second event will be a Women's Gathering Honoring Grandmother Moon, The Universe and  the Sacred elements.  Both events, will take place December 19, 2012 – December 24, 2012 on the shores of Lake Tahoe, California/Nevada.

Winter Solstice is a time to Welcome Winter. Many people have forgotten to honor the changing of seasons.  We will gather to pray, sing, honor, dance, listen, make offerings and bring our gifts.

The Women's Gathering allows the sacred feminine to work together and upon our Mother Earth.

"Our shawls will so the next step on this journey of life.  She is grandmother, mother, aunt, daughter, wife, friend and blessed caretaker.  She is compassion, understanding, courage, love, peace, protector, transcendent, life giver.”

Donations to fundraising campaign will assist us in providing air transportation, food, gas, lodging, wood, car rentals and additional resource needs for ceremony at the shores of Lake Tahoe and Cave Rock, especially for the five elders who are seeking to attend Winter Solstice Ceremony.

As a small grass roots organization, Preservation of Ancient Traditional Indigenous Lands (P.A.T.I.L.), and as representatives of Indigenous Nations, we were given the vision to care for our Mother Earth and Honor all the sacred life giving forces. We have worked together for 11 years. We are tribal members from several different nations and nurturing supporters. In a world where most things are rushed, we have taken time out to reflect and work towards our inner needs and ancestral calling. It is time to honor these ways that stem from the core of who we are and how we stand in this world.

We are seeking $5,000 donations due to an unforeseen cancellation of our Music Fest that was to be held on November 3rd 2012 at the War Memorial Building in San Francisco via phone call from the Trustee of the War Memorial Building and Post 448 on the 29th of October 2012. This LEFT US without a venue to hold our annual fundraising event. While we were in dismay and our hearts were on the ground, it is not by mistake that we find ourselves here on Indiegogo seeking your support. Your donation will help cover expenses for both events to bring elders to our Winter Solstice Ceremony and elders to the Women’s Gathering. The funding also assists us in the protection of Sacred Sites. Your donation will help us in providing the continued care of Cave Rock (Deek Wadap'ush) and other sacred sites. There is much to do to bring the Deek Wadap’ush site back to its original natural state.

P.A.T.I.L. supports traditional ceremonies and gatherings. Our mission is to support the necessary work for the sacred lands, waters, air and light. It is very important work to honor and celebrate the life giving sources. We look forward to expanding our wings and doing what we can to influence the future generations.  This is our first Great grand daughters campaign.  We are appealing and respectfully seek your generosity and extend our heartfelt thanks.

Board Members: Alberta Moore Gabriel Snyder (Washoe), Holly Calica (Ilocano/Pangasinan), Mary Jean Robinson (Cherokee), Ismael Versoza (Filipino), Richie Beltran (Seneca/Azteca), Edgar Santiago (Taino/Puerto Rican/Salvadoran) and Debbie Santiago (Washoe/Osage)

Board Advisors: Barbara James Snyder (Washoe/Paiute)

We have wonderful perks, ie: Virtual Hugs, Speaking your name at Lake Tahoe,Thank you cards, photo cards, prints, hair cuts, massages, talking stick and original paintings. 

The Impact:

On the shores of Lake Tahoe, California and Nevada stands Cave Rock (Deek Wadap'ush) 10 million years old. Traditionally any person passing by spoke a prayer and left an offering in their honor.  In the 1930 rock climbing became popular at Cave Rock. Washoe Tribe of Nevada and California stepped forward to protect Cave Rock.  In less then 2 decades much has been accomplished. Lake Tahoe Basin Management Service signed a rendering decision that would provide immediate protection. On January 28, 2005 the Cave Rock case was heard in Reno, Nevada. Federal Judge Howard McKibben upheld the 2003 decision by Forest Service Management to protect Cave Rock. On February 27, 2008, the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the decision to ban rock climbing.

 We are proud to express that in August 2009 372 pins and climbing apparatus were all removed.  Cave Rock now enjoys more respect and protection since its nomination to the National Register of Historic Places. 

Winter Solstice Ceremony on the shores of Lake Tahoe and and Women's Gathering is not a public event. Participation is by registration only.  Please no radios, alcohol, and drugs.

Please put out the word to everyone about this campaign. We remain strong and humble on this journey of life. 

Share this on other sites. Your attention is greatly appreciated.

Be Well.

story:
Our Story

HACER is interested in rehabilitating a community that has been negatively affected by the high number of foreclosures. This neighborhood is a victim of disrepair due to the high number of abandoned homes. It is for this reason that HACER has begun a campaign of adoption of Norma Elaine St in West Palm Beach, FL.

HACER has taken the first step in the adoption process by purchasing a four unit apartment building. These apartments have been completely remodeled with the assistance of volunteers and local contractors. Once remodeled, the units have been assigned to low-income families.

HACER has started an initiative to improve Norma Elaine Street. HACER will do this by first inviting and involving home owners on this street to join HACER in this project to enhance their community.

What We Need to get it done

To develop the project we need to obtain materials such as:

  • Sod
  • Plants & Shrubs
  • Tools
    • Wheel Barrel
    • Leased Dumpster
    • Ax
    • Rakes
    • Shovels
  • Miscellaneous Materials
    • Trash Bags
    • Gloves

The Impact

HACER’s in this project is to Plant Hope in the following ways:

  • Provide a clean street.
  • Beautify the neighborhood.
  • Create an attractive, clean and safe community.
  • Re-establish a sense of belonging.
  • Create jobs.
  • Increase property values.

Other Ways You Can Help

HACER appreciates any and all donations, whether it is monetary or the time the many volunteers give to HACER’s causes – We thank you.

We ask you to please spread the word to everyone you know in person or in your social network. It is through your help that the mission will be accomplished.

story:
My name is Camilo Galeano, and as the director of Foundation EL Color Azul, I believe that my city and the world need projects that merge art and environment.  By submerging work of arts in the ocean we can create art corridors in the bottom of the sea, that can not only be appreciated by the people, but by the underwater marine ecosystems. It is our job, as a marine conservation foundation, to counteract the negative impact on the sea.  Remember, Coral's reefs produce about US$375 billions at year in goods and services around the world and it is believed that they provide most of the earth’s oxygen.

Because of the small cultural offer from the visual and plastic arts in Cartagena, Colombia, the increment of tourists in the city, and the low level of knowledge of the environment, there is the need to create projects in the city that spark human creativity to unite both arts and nature.  MuMar, the Museum of Arts and Environment of Cartagena, is the proposal of El Color Azul Foundation to tackle the problems mentioned.  MuMar’s objective is to diversify and expand the cultural offer of the visual and plastic arts of the city.  The Museum stands between the tensions from ethics and aesthetics that are generated by all human activity.  Furthermore, it encourages interdisciplinary research that is targeted to the development of art projects that promote the health of ecosystems.

According to the 2010 Cultural Report of Cartagena, the visual arts and cultural tourism sector offers great opportunities for the development of art and natural science projects, proving that MuMar will be an important asset for the city.  Additionally, there has been more demand for national and international events, and the creation on new organizations that promote tourism, development, culture, urbanism and marine science.  The interest of the implementation of art and environment has shown a significant growth, the result is a positive experience for the local ecosystem.



MuMar began two years ago and has progressed around 40%.  This means that the resources needed account for the 60% that is left.  The funds needed are for the final details on the work of art, the transportation, submersion of the art pieces, and a short documentary on the project.  We will submerge five wooden sculptures three meters high and anchored to concrete deadweights.  Additionally, we will submerge a plate with the names of our major sponsors.  The progress of the project can be seen in the video!

This is a very complicated and ambitious project, submerging huge artifacts in the middle of the sea is very difficult.  A million things can go wrong, and there are many variables to take in account, like weather and current.  The funds will be delivered to the artist, and the transportation and submersion companies, taken in account that anything can go wrong in the middle of the ocean.  We will post all the updates, documents and information of the companies that will work on the project.




Declared part of the UNESCO World Heritage in 1984, Cartagena encapsulates all the charm of Spanish colonial architecture, the republic period and today, the attractions of intense night-life, cultural festivals, exotic scenery, superb beaches, wonderful food and a wide offer of hotels and tourist infrastructure.

Walk the streets, look at the Spanish colonial buildings – the Palace of the Inquisition, the Clock-Tower and the Castle of San Felipe de Barajas; enjoy the soft, warm breezes as you pass through the squares and plazas.

Eating out is another form of entertainment in Cartagena, with countless choices of new and exotic flavors in local and international styles.

The choice of accommodation is very wide too. There are traditional hotels and exclusive boutique hotels offering unique experiences of detail and personal service.

Cartagena offers all the enchantment of its history and the legacy of those who made it great and turned it into one of Colombia’s most important tourist destinations.

More information on www.colombia.travel






German Botero was born in Fresno, Colombia in the of 1946.  He started his wood interventions in the beaches of Venezuela during the Bienal Barro de América in 2006.  The woods were collected from the Maracaibo Lake, a very polluted water resource.  His environment projects continue but this time in Colombia since 2006, with his Terraza Tayrona in the Museum of Modern Art of Santa Marta. 




Camilo Galeano: Director of Color Blue Foundation.  Bachelor of Science on Information Techonology, Masters Degree on Foreign Affairs and PhD Candidate in Political Science.  

Manuel Zuñiga: Artist. Humanities Coordinator of the University Jorge Tadeo Lozano, and MuMar Director.

Verónica Herrera: Professional in international relations and project Coordinator of Foundation El Color Azul.

Rodolfo Segrera: Artista. Audiovisual producer. Fullbright 2012

Sandra Ontiveros: Artist. Management and Cultural Consultant



Created on September 2010, El Color Azul is a Non Governmental Organization that promotes conservation and preservation of the Colombian marine ecosystem through the use of communication campaigns, political advocacy, social and sporting events.  In addition, it offers support to the local community through education.  The Foundation strives for the protection of the marine ecosystem and its natural balance.

Objectives:

1. Promote the sustainability of the marine ecosystem

2. Technical support on marine ecosystem care       

3. Encourage a sustainable use of the marine environment.       





With a $25 contribution you will receive a digital version of the Certificate as a Founder of MuMar + the digital version of the original planning document of MuMar.  Remember, with a $50 contribution you will get this Founding Certificate as a hard copy delivered anywhere in the world.




For a $100 you will be the first with this beautiful official museum t-shirt + a hard copy of the Founding Certificate and a hard copy of the Original Planning document of MuMar.




For a contribution of $1000 your name will be etched in a metal sign under the sea for eternity!!!  The sign will be located in a concrete structure right beside the work of art.  This contribution also includes everything in the $250 perk level.

It is our job, as a marine conservation foundation, to counteract the negative impact on the sea.  Remember, Coral's reefs produce about US$375 billions at year in goods and services around the world and it is believed that they provide most of the earth’s oxygen.Because of the small cultural offer from

story:
Kitsap Forest & Bay Project

We Did It! 

In just 48 hours, our community met our $8,000 goal to help save 535 acres of forest and beach on Port Gamble Bay! Now all additional funds raised will help purchase additional land in the Port Gamble forest! 

With your help, the purchase of the Port Gamble Bay Shoreline block–the first phase of our visionary 6,700 acre Kitsap Forest & Bay Project will be completed in a few short weeks!  With that accomplished, we’ll continue right on to purchase the land and trails in the Port Gamble Forest, North Kitsap Heritage Park Expansion, Divide Forest, and Hansville Forest.  Thank You!

About the Project

We are a dedicated coalition of partners working on a visionary effort, the Kitsap Forest and Bay Project, to conserve 6,700 acres of forestland and 1.5 miles of shoreline surrounding Port Gamble Bay. It was once the hub of Puget Sound’s timber industry in Washington State. With the former lumber mill gone, the landowner has provided the community a tremendous opportunity to conserve the land for all time, preserving the property’s rich ecosystems and the recreational appeal of its existing nature tails.

We’ve raised nearly $4.6 million to purchase the first 535 acres of forest and beach on Port Gamble Bay. Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe has generously pledged a significant amount of money to this purchase. Now, the Kitsap Forest & Bay partners and the public are working to raise the final $8,000 in the next 14 days!

We need YOUR help to raise $8,000 by February 3!  Any funds raised beyond our immediate need for the shoreline will help purchase additional land in the Port Gamble forest.

Saving our SPECIAL places

Port Gamble Bay has been at the cultural heart of local tribes for eons – providing sustenance for families and enriching tribal traditions that continue to this day.  Port Gamble Bay’s forests and bay draw thousands of outdoor recreationists annually – strengthening the local economy and promoting healthy lifestyles.  Port Gamble Bay supports fish and wildlife that are critical to a healthy Puget Sound.

Our Opportunity

Due to Kitsap Forest & Bay Project’s immense size, the coalition is tackling land acquisition in five blocks/phases. With your help, we will complete the first phase of the project with the conservation of the Port Gamble Bay Shoreline block. When that’s accomplished, we’ll continue right on to purchase the land and trails in the Port Gamble Forest, North Kitsap Heritage Park Expansion, Divide Forest and Hansville Forest.

Saving the Land and Trails – Phase 1: Port Gamble Shoreline

A glimmering jewel at the mouth of Hood Canal, Port Gamble Bay abounds with waterfowl during the winter and nurtures abundant shellfish and fish year round.  Lush forests reach as far as the eye can see up the ridgeline, with the Olympics towering in the background.  At 535 acres, the Port Gamble Shoreline property contains extensive forestland, wetlands, and 1.5 miles of Port Gamble Bay’s untrammeled shoreline.  This remarkable property will be protected forever as a saltwater park – owned and maintained by Kitsap County.  Protected for all time, the park will provide a place for families to explore on foot, bike or kayak.  YOUR help is needed TODAY to raise $8,000 by February 3!

Kitsap Forest & Bay Coalition

Our dedicated coalition represents an unprecedented partnership between state, local, tribal, environmental, and recreational organizations including: Kitsap County, Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe, Suquamish Tribe, Forterra, Great Peninsula Conservancy, Kitsap Audubon Society, North Kitsap Trails Association, Kitsap Economic Development Alliance, Visit Kitsap Peninsula, local and state agencies, and community members. We have been working for years to secure a vibant future for these 6,700 acres on the Kitsap Peninsula.

Why YOU can make a difference

Just $8,000 separates us from the reality of conserving 535 acres and 1.5 miles of Port Gamble Bay shoreline forever!  By helping us raise just $8,000, you can be part of conserving not just this beautiful piece of the world, but also all the wonderful outdoor fun it supports. Please make your donation today!

If you have further questions, please contact Liz Johnston, Forterra Conservation Director - ljohnston@forterra.org.

story:
Short Summary

Help save our Elm Trees!

These Elms are over 100 years old and we are seeking your financial assistance to help keep these much loved trees alive and healthy for as long as possible.

Deaf Children Australia has been on our St Kilda Road site for nearly 150 years and generations of Deaf children have enjoyed playing and communicating in Auslan under these magnificent trees. If these trees could sign (Auslan) they could tell us about the evolution of Deaf Education from the early colonial days to the present.

In a past landscape heritage study it was reported that there were links between our gardens and Ferdinand von Mueller who also created the stunning Royal Botanic Gardens. Our property includes one of the last remaining tree lined driveways from Melbourne’s colonial history. Help us preserve this history and the history of Deaf children by extending the life of these Elms as we enter the next phase of Deaf Education on this historic site.

We need a minimum of $5,000 annually to help protect the Elms from unwanted pests like the Elm Leaf beetle. If we exceed our target, we will spend the additional funds on further protection measures such as drought proofing and removal of dead wood to give our Elms the best chance of survival.

Deaf Children Australia is a national service provider that supports Deaf children and their families. For over 100 years, we have partnered with the Victorian Government to provide school facilities and beautiful grounds for the students of the Victorian College for the Deaf (formerly VSDC).

We think we can reach our modest goal but if we don’t, your funds will still be used on protection activities for our beautiful trees.

story:
A Message from Young Scientists

We are Lise & Loïc, two 23-year old scientists and development practitioners from Belgium, currently studying in the UK.

We're part of a new generation who believes it is time to solve climate change & promote inclusive sustainable development for all.

We have developed a new approach to tackling this challenge: WATER FOR HUMANITY, a PhD research project with a twist.

The Challenge

According to the International Federation of the Red Cross, 2 billion people have been affected by natural hazards over the last 10 years. Scientific data reveals that the large majority of these hazards are hydrological (e.g. floods, storm surges) and are magnified by the effects of climate change. The most affected regions have been the Asia-Pacific region, Latin America and the Caribbean, displacing about 18 million people.


Source: IFRC World Disasters Report 2018 / EM-DAT 

These disasters greatly impact water security for the poor (e.g. through water contamination or water shortages) and threaten people's livelihoods (i.e. their culture and means of survival). The international community's response, however, has been sparse or inadequate; while humanitarian organisations can be successful at delivering emergency aid, their short-term programmes often fail at addressing the root causes of people's vulnerability.

A number of scientific studies show that this is due to a chronic lack of participation of the affected communities in the design and implementation of development programmes. Another cause for this challenge is a lack of understanding of local ecosystems, which leads organisations to implement unsustainable programmes that further enhance people's vulnerability.
 

Our Solution

WATER FOR HUMANITY is a research project led within the Oxford Department of International Development. It seeks to develop a model for providing inclusive and sustainable responses to environmental change & natural hazards, while restoring the Earth’s ecosystems.

In particular, the project aims at exploring the role of mangroves in protecting people from floods, and how indigenous knowledge can help build more inclusive development programmes that increase water security in emergencies and beyond.

 

The project has 4 main goals:

  1. Researching how international organisations and NGOs can work with people affected by environmental change in a way that is inclusive, effective and sustainable;
  2. In particular, identifying key ecosystem resources and services (e.g. mangroves) for disaster risk reduction & focusing on water security for the poor;
  3. Exploring how indigenous knowledge can be integrated into sustainable development programmes, in particular in the sustainable management of water;
  4. Communicating research findings to the wider academic and non-academic community, in order to raise awareness about how climate change impacts water resources;
  5. Partnering with international organisations, NGOs and governments to make sure the research has a positive impact on local ecosystems & benefits the most vulnerable.

This campaign is specifically aimed at funding a research trip to coastal Guyana, of a length of 4 months, where our team will conduct an ethnography of community & international response to environmental change and natural hazards.

 

 

Our Budget

Your contribution helps fund the field component of this research. Fieldwork is critical to sustainable development research, because successful development programmes depend on both particular societies and their particular environment.

In particular, your contribution will be supporting the following fieldwork expenses:

  • A first field visit. We need to visit Guyana during the first half of 2019 to meet potential partners & gather up-to-date information about the challenges faced by the country. There's not a lot of recent academic literature on Guyana.
  • A second field visit. This entails a 4-month stay in Guyana, including the cost of accommodation in Georgetown but excluding living expenses. Travel may be required outside of Georgetown in order to gather information in remote communities.
  • Transport. This includes two return plane tickets (one for the first visit, the other one for the second).
  • Healthcare. A small amount of the raised funding will be allocated to emergency healthcare, to face Guyana's tropical climate.
  • Other. This includes the purchase of research equipment and other types of research assistance, such as the services of a translator.

story:
I'm Jake, I'm a marine biologist and I’ve been working with collaborators in Dominica for nine years teaching kids about sea turtles and ocean conservation.

In Dominica, sea turtles are essential to the health of the environment and economy. Around the world single use plastic is killing hundreds of thousands of marine animals every year. In Dominica, the threat of single use plastics really strikes home.  That's because the island is home to nesting leatherback sea turtles.  Leatherbacks are the largest, farthest ranging, and deepest diving sea turtle. They also only eat jellyfish, hundreds of pounds of jellies every day. Plastic bags are often mistaken for jellies and when ingested, can seriously injure or kill leatherbacks.  

That's why we need $500 to give every kid who participates in Floating Classrooms a reusable lunch bag to use instead of plastic. It’s simple and has immediate impact.Through this initiative, we've already eliminated more than 200,000 single use bags.  

One reusable bag will replace 700+ single-use plastic bags in its lifetime. That's a lot of plastic that will never reach the sea.

Your contribution will help keep more plastic out of the ocean near these endangered turtles and help protect Dominica’s turtles, its economy and its children's future.

Floating Classroom in full swing.

story:
My Background Story

My name is Jasmine, and this year I am a senior in high school. I know I am just one person, but I am passionate about environmental conservation and I have decided to dedicate my one person to that cause by volunteering over 300 hours to marine and environmental conservation issues. I have developed the P.S. We Love You campaign to promote conservation of the Puget Sound, and I plan to pursue these interests in college where I’ll be studying marine biology and environmental sciences. My pursuit of research opportunities has helped me to discover this once in a lifetime volunteer opportunity studying Leatherback Sea Turtles in Trinidad y Tobago for twelve days.

Why I Want To Go

I didn’t make the decision to go to Trinidad and Tobago on a whim. My family’s contribution to this trip has replaced my Christmas present, my 18th birthday present, and my graduation present, and it’s completely worth it! This trip is a natural and exciting extension of the volunteer work I’ve been doing the last three years through the Seattle aquarium. This trip reflects my passions and my future ambitions perfectly.

... Leatherback Turtles? What I Am Going To Do With Them 

Yes, Leatherback Turtles. It is estimated that only one in a thousand leatherback hatchlings survive to adulthood. Eighty percent of all leatherback nesting occurs in the Caribbean, where the volunteer trip I’m pursuing takes place. On the trip I will participate in nightly beach patrols, looking for nesting adult female turtles and help researchers collect data and protect these delicate nests.

Why I Need Your Help

To support their nonprofit Leatherback Turtles Research Program, the Earthwatch Institute requires volunteers to contribute $2825 for their trips. While volunteers provide precious help to the research projects, the Institute needs money to train, house, and feed the volunteers. Included in the contribution are costs for meals and board in a bare-bones (no hot water) facility. In other words, the majority of the money will go directly to turtle research. My family has already contributed the $800 for airfare, and will be providing money for passport fees, inoculations, and spending money while I’m there. We decided together that I should earn the $2825 donation for the trip, and money to buy supplies for the local children, as part of my service. As you can see, I’m asking for less than half of the donation fees on this website, and will spend the summer working to pay off a loan for the remaining amount.

This program will provide me a type of hands-on experience that I cannot get even in the best colleges. So, even though the price is great, for me, this experience will be priceless. Any contribution you make will help greatly and will allow you to be part of my journey!

What You Get Back For Helping Me

Besides (1) a big pat on the back from good karma and mother earth, (2) feeling good about yourself for saving baby Leatherback Sea Turtles and (3) making an aspiring environmentalist’s dream come true, the, “Perks” column on the right lists additional benefits for every level of contribution. And remember, for any donation, you will also get eternal gratitude from me and from and hundreds of baby leatherbacks!

story:
Help save the longest running Olive Ridley sea turtle project in the world!

Various organizations have helped the people of Punta Banco in their efforts to protect the sea turtles that nest on their beaches. This funding is currently unavailable, but the community has rallied to continue the work of collecting, protecting, hatching, and releasing nests. Without funding, however, the project is on the ropes!

Help is on the way in the form of local government support, but not until the next fiscal year. In the meantime, our aim is to crowd fund enough money to keep the project alive.

What's the money for?

Funds will be used in two ways:

1. The community needs supplies to build new hatcheries and patrol the beaches: shovels, fencing, lights, batteries, etc. 

2. The more expensive part of the project is using funds to combat poachers by paying for nests. The community has found this to be the most effective way to ensure as many eggs as possible make it to the hatcheries. Furthermore, it provides the youth of the village with part-time employment during nesting season. Nests are bought for approximately $15 USD.

The Impact:

Ten thousand dollars is enough to float the project through this period of uncertainty and then some. If we don't reach this goal, every bit will still go a long way towards ensuring the survival of the program. In the absence of a governing non-profit, all money will go directly to the Comite de las Tortugas del la Asociacion de Vecinos de Punta Banco (The Sea Turtle Committee of the Punta Banco  Neighborhood Association).

Who am I?

I've been living primarily in Punta Banco for the last eight years. I manage The Yoga Farm, a local sustainable living project and rustic yoga center. Before my departure for the states last month, local friends involved in the project asked me to do what I could to raise awareness and money for the project while away. 

Risks & Challenges

While it can be tricky to show where money flows when crossing borders and changing hands, I can say this: the forming coalition of local businesses and concerned residents is both heartening and trustworthy by my measure. Once deposited, the Neighborhood Association will keep records of how money is spent and who is paid for their work. This will become public record in Costa Rica - which can then be posted to our forthcoming website - Friends of Punta Banco. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, please pass this campaign along to anyone who knows and loves Punta Banco, cares for sea turtles (who doesn't like sea turtles?), and anyone who can help get the word out. Thanks so much!!!

story:
Did you know there will be 3.5 million people experiencing homelessness again in America in 2012?

You can help us help the homeless - One Bag At A Time!

     My name is Krista, I live in the Austin, Texas area.  On a daily basis, one red light after another I have found myself curious of the stories behind those holding the signs on the street corners.  Even more though, I struggle with what I can do to assist.  I am not always comfortable handing over the loose change in my car.  Not because I am afraid, but more out of concern that I will be feeding a habit instead of a hungry belly.

     I then learned about this idea of filling ziplock bags with hygiene necessaties, water and a snack.  We then distribute them to the homeless on corners, in parks, under bridges and so on.  

     The bags we distribute contain:  Water, high protein bars, toothpase, toothbrush, soap, shampoo, washcloth, hand sanitizer or moist wraps, tissue packet, comb and socks.

     As we enter into the cooler months, we will adjust the bags to contain thermal underwear, gloves and hats and small blankets also.

 

What We Need:

While we ask for donations of these products, we are still left with many supplies to purchase.  As the cooler months approach, there will be a much higher demand for additional supplies such as blankets and thermal wear.

With your monatary gift today, we will be able to purchase even more supplies to continue this project much quicker.

How Will Your Donation Impact The Community?

At this point in time, we are strictly reliant on donation of products and helping with our money.  This limits the amount of bags we are able to put together and distribute.

The quicker we are able to generate donations, the faster we can assist the homeless - One Bag At A Time!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

You can still help - tell everyone about us, encourage others to donate - Spread The Word!

Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
We all know how it goes; you wake up one day and decide that there has to be more to life than the daily grind. Everyone has their own bucket list - with one crowing thing that they’d love to do before they die. 

 

That’s exactly how this project came about; realising one day that I wanted to do something really big, really different and really special. 

 

With a good friend in tow, I hatched a plan to take the biggest adventure we possibly could, and resolved to climb Mount Kilimanjaro, the highest peak in Africa. Standing at an impressive 19,341 ft, Kili towers over the harsh landscape of Tanzania, and is one of the highest mountains in the world. 

 

But the more we talked about it, as we looked at the different routes to the summit, the more we realised there was a better reason to climb the mountain than simply taking a bit of a different holiday. Together, we decided that we wanted to use the opportunity to raise money for charity - because if the two of us can make it right to the top, then surely that’s worth a few pound to improve someone else’s life? 

 

We’ll be undertaking the climb in late 2012/early 2013 to raise money for three charities;

 

Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research in memory of Edwin, Will’s dad, who died as a result of Leukaemia in 1996. This charity is the only one in the UK solely dedicated to research into blood cancers, including leukaemia, lymphoma and myeloma.

 

The Sharon Golledge Memorial Fund, set up in 2007 following the unexpected death of Ben’s sister Sharon from an epileptic seizure at the age of 25. Raising money on behalf of Epilepsy Research UK, which strives to ensure that the signs of epilepsy can be detected in time to help save lives. 

 

For the third charity, we wanted the money to stay in Africa. Hope to Ghana have a few simple aims with their fundraising; including helping to relieve poverty, hardship & distress among needy people in the country and to provide education to those children who would not normally get the opportunity. Through friends, Will has seen the hard work the charity puts in to help improve lives.  


-----


The money we’re asking for here on Indegogo isn’t money to go direct to these charities; it’s the money we need to get ourselves to (and up!) the mountain. Between us, we can only raise so much cash, and without your help, we’ll never make it. 

 

We’re asking for $7,500 (or as close to it as we can get!) to cover the cost of flights and all the various charges incurred in climbing the mountain. Any money that we raise *over* this amount will be sent direct to the charities, alongside money raised once we actually start looking for sponsors. 

 

Any amount is greatly received - every penny brings us closer to reaching our goal, and making our way up Kilimanjaro. 

 

Thank you,

 

Will Brooks and Ben Norman

May 2012

 

 

**CAMPAIGN VIDEO ON ITS WAY**

story:
It´s time for a breakthrough in housing technology to become accessible to the most vulnerable communities in the world

Due to climate change, floods are happening more frequently and with more devastating effects on communities worldwide. The current strategy to help vulnerable communities is to relocate them.

However, relocating these families breaks their connection to their income source (mostly agriculture and fishing), to their identity, and to each other. Moreover, this strategy is expensive and has largely failed, as families often return to their land seeking for a better quality of life.

How can we help vulnerable communities living in flood prone areas without breaking their ties to income, identity, and support networks?

By providing them with houses that can float when the water rises and return to the ground when it recedes. CO2 Bambu, a Nicaraguan social enterprise specialized in building ecological bamboo houses, has designed a low-cost amphibious house that can increase the life quality of millions of vulnerable people worldwide.

What is an amphibious house?

An amphibious house is one that sits on the ground the majority of the time, but which has the ability to rise up with rising waters during flooding events, and return to the ground when the waters recede.  This is done by securing the house to a buoyant platform, and connecting the house to vertical guideposts so that the house doesn’t float away. This technology already exists in the Netherlands and has been successfully deployed for over two decades.

These houses, however, can cost up to €300,000, making them an unrealistic option for hundreds of millions of the world´s most vulnerable people living in coastal areas.

Our challenge is to deliver amphibious houses at a price lower than $15,000.

How does bamboo fit in to all of this?

There is a relationship between the weight of the house and the cost of the below water buoyant system.  The lighter the house, the simpler the buoyant portion of the house.  Since bamboo is inherently light, it is the most promising building material to arrive at a low cost, flood resilient, bamboo amphibious house solution.

How to contribute

CO2 Bambu has engaged in dialogue with the community of Malacatoya, along with the world´s leaders in amphibious construction technology, and designed a solution.  Now we need to field our first prototype.  WE NEED TO DO THIS QUICKLY, BEFORE OCTOBER, WHEN THE WATERS OF THE MALACATOYA RIVER WILL RISE AGAIN.

We have received a donation for some of the materials by a US shelter manufacturer and CO2 Bambu can contribute the bamboo material required to build the above water home, but WE NEED YOUR HELP TO FUND:

 -       The purchase of barrels

-       Construction and testing of the steel frame that will allow the amphibious house to sit on top of barrels in the dry season

-       Conduct testing with the national university of engineering to establish a testing protocol that will allow for the approval of this innovative construction

-       Deployment of the proof of concept amphibious house

We have come face to face with a broken paradigm in the global toolkit for post disaster response.  The current paradigm is to relocate populations to higher ground and yet there is ample empirical evidence that this solution does not work.  Populations return to their homelands.  We need to collectively come up with a flood-resilient solution that will allow vulnerable populations to adapt to Climate Change, but to do so in their homelands.  This is the promise of amphibious housing.

In the words of Martha Fernandez “Si nos quieren ayudar, que nos ayuden aqui.” (¨If you want to help us, then help us here”)

Join us in deploying the first amphibious house in Malacatoya.  It will be a technological breakthrough, one that will allow populations to adapt to their harsh and changing environment, and will do so without destroying the very fabric of the community.

 

For more information about our previous experience with bamboo construction and our engagement towards climate adaptation, please visit:

CO2 Bambu's inclusive bamboo value chain: http://www.inclusivebamboovaluechain.com/

CO2 Bambu's transition towards Climate Adaptation: http://www.climateadaptationnow.org/
 
CO2 Bambu's amphibious house to tackle climate change in flood prone areas: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2tS_brKx9K4&feature=player_embedded

CO2 Bambu-amphibious house-flotation system: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x7oJruA_PNQ&feature=player_embedded

Dr. Elizabeth English, foremost authority in affordable amphibious houses in South Louisiana: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HgT9Gxjztl0&feature=youtu.be

story:
Short Summary

Hi:

My name is James Borgman and I am a co-founder at the Green Water Garden. I have been supporting people with disabilities and helping them live in the community for the last 20 years. Our goal is to have people with disabilities live and work in the community in a sustainable way. 

The Green Water Garden is a solution to a number of challenges we face on this planet. Using 90% less water than growing vegetables in the ground, producing and selling locally and not using harmful pesticides are just some of the environmental solutions. Paying a living wage, decreasing dependence upon social security, offering people an identity and creating an inclusive society are some of the social solutions.  

This demonstration project was built using personal funding. We now want to build a production model that will keep us sustainable and allow us to compete in the open market. To do this we will need $30,000. Your tax deductible (through Cultural Media Services our fiscal sponsor) donation will go directly to building the infrastructure of the new farm. We currently have eight people working at the farm. This expansion project will allow 30 more jobs for people with disabilities.

Our goal is to expand this program across the state of California. We want every adult with a disability to have the opportunity to find, keep and enjoy productive employment in their community. If you can't contribute, please help us by sending the video link to at least ten of your friends. Every little bit helps.

Thank you for being a part of creating a sustainable community!

Sincerely,

James E. Borgman, MA

story:
Join me in bringing a monsoon of support to some of the most ecologically and financially parched corners of the globe!

This is Sadhana Forest, the eco-humanitarian non-profit in southern India where I spent the last six months and will return in January to work as a long-term volunteer. I arrived intending the experience to be a stint between jobs but departed with a commitment to service and community, ready to give my skills and time to this organization without the security of knowing if and how I would be supported in return.

That's why I need your help! While you may not be in a position to travel to India or Kenya (where we will soon launch a sister project) to give the trees and people the personal touch they so badly need, you can make a donation that will allow me to continue this critical work and enable our organization to expand its highly successful model of ecological revival, sustainable living and environmental education to other countries and communities in need. This is your chance to have your charitable giving go toward an organization with which you will have a direct and personal connection: me!

 Sadhana Forest is operated solely through the generosity of volunteers and donors. The organization's commitment to fostering an economy of service and investment in community is partially what attracted me to the project. Therefore, I decided to reach out through my community and network, both locally and abroad, in order to fund my next year as a volunteer. Not only will this enable each of you to be involved in supporting a dynamic and growing international organization, but it will also allow the organization's monetary resources to go directly to fund projects instead of subsidizing a volunteer position.

Your donation will assist with:

  • Travel to and from project sites
  • In-country transportation
  • Essentials such as food, biodegradable toiletries and petrol
  • Insurance payments
  • Communication services

Funds raised in excess of what is needed to cover cost-of-living expenses will be donated to Sadhana Forest.

Sometimes, we don’t know where the money will come from to feed and support our volunteers for the next month, let alone fund our key projects. However, in every case, we have been supplied with exactly what we need at just the right moment. As our founder and director told me, “I awake each morning and ask myself what wonderful thing will happen today?” Today, that “wonderful thing” can be you!


For more information about Sadhana Forest and the projects we are involved with, please visit our website:

Sadhana Forest Website


Examples of the perk you will receive with a gift of $100 or more

story:
Short Summary

Salina Cares is a group of concerned citizens who care about respecting the environment and are dedicated to halting the water fluoridation policy of the City of Salina, Kansas.

What We Need

We are preparing a public campaign to educate the people of Salina to join us in our efforts to prevent the city from continuing to add a toxic chemical, sodium fluorosilicate, to our public water supply. Your donations will help cover our expenses to purchase advertising and distribute printed literature, yard, signs, banners, and bumper stickers.

The Impact

Our research indicates fluoride to be ineffective against preventing cavities and an unsafe contaminant to water that has serious negative health effects.

Other Ways You Can Help

People who just can’t contribute, can help out in other ways.

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Use the Indiegogo share tools.

Thanks for your support. We appreciate it very much.

story:
Support the precedent-setting ballot measure to make Hood River County, Oregon, the first in the country to prohibit commercial water bottling. 

Help give our community the resources to stand up to Nestlé and other water bottling corporations in this David and Goliath fight.

Warm Springs tribal member Klairice Westley with Wanapum Fishing People Against Nestle in front of Oxbow Springs in Cascade Locks, Oregon, which Nestlé's project is targeting.

Our Campaign: Standing up to Nestlé’s water grab

      Faced with Nestlé’s plans to export over 200 million gallons of bottled water a year from our drought-stricken county in the Columbia River Gorge, a diverse coalition of residents and tribal members from Hood River County, Oregon, have filed a precedent-setting ballot measure to prohibit bottled water production in our county. Our goal at the Local Water Alliance is simple: We want to protect our  limited water resources that we need to support our families, farms and salmon fishery.  Every community has the right to protect its most important resource: our water. No community should set a precedent of exporting water at the expense of its water security.

       Nestlé’s misguided project would send over 1.7 billion plastic water bottles out of the County each year. Every drop of water Nestlé wants to use is currently publicly owned by the State of Oregon or the City of Cascade Locks, making Nestlé’s project the largest potential privatization of public water for a bottled water project in Oregon history.

       We know Nestlé and the water bottling industry is prepared to spend whatever it takes to stop our measure and to prevent other communities from following suit. Our ballot initiative will set a precedent that communities all over the country could use to take control of their local water security.

More information and the text of the measure is available at LocalWaterAlliance.org.

Volunteers at a ballot measure signature gathering kickoff event have a very
clear message.

Why do we need your financial support?

       Our David and Goliath campaign would stop plans for a water bottling mega plant by one of the largest corporations in the world. While we have strong public backing, we need your financial support today so we can do two big things:

  1) Educate voters about the importance of this measure; and

  2) Rebut Nestlé’s misleading political spin about their plans to export over 1.7 billion plastic bottles of water a year out of our community that cannot even meet our existing water needs. 

       With your help, we can mobilize our grassroots campaign to stand up to Nestlé, which is already working to mislead voters with empty promises and fear tactics. Your funding will help us:

  • Recruit and train volunteers to connect with and educate voters
  • Produce and pay for buttons, lawn signs, and flyers
  • Register people to vote and turn out thousands of voters leading up to Election Day 2016
  • Run door-to-door neighborhood canvasses and phonebanks where our volunteer base will talk to voters one by one
  • Produce and pay for voter outreach that educates voters and rebuts Nestlé’s political spin
  • Pay for our campaign office space and supplies

Oregon residents may be eligible for a $50 state tax credit or $100 for couples filing jointly.  Please consult your tax adviser for details. 

NOTE: Because of Oregon elections law all donors must provide their address when making a contribution.  If you want to make a donation but do not want any perk  or gift please donate directly through our website.

Tribal members and residents join together to protest Nestlé's water grab at the Capitol in Salem, Oregon, in September, 2015.

Help Us Set a Precedent for Community Water Protection

       Communities around the country and world are facing the threat of bottled water exports despite shrinking local water supplies and widespread projections of  drought as the new normal. Our grassroots campaign has the potential to set a precedent for water security not only in Hood River County, but for communities across Oregon and the country. 

Cascade Locks residents have been fighting Nestlé's reckless water bottling plans for years and are laying the foundation for winning this precedent-setting measure.

Our drought is fresh in voters’ minds

       Hood River County was formally declared in a state of drought emergency this summer and voters are well aware of the County's serious water troubles. If you drove down most Hood River County streets this summer, you would have seen  dried up lawns, trees and shrubs. Orchardists and farmers spent thousands of dollars on high efficiency irrigation systems and irrigation flows were cut off early. Toilets went unflushed.  Over 200,000 sockeye salmon died due to high river temperatures driven largely by record low river flows from Columbia River tributaries. 

A critical source of Hood River County's water supply, Mount Hood's receding glaciers and record low snow pack presents a serious threat to water security.

        Despite this severe drought, Nestlé argues that the more than 200 million gallons a year it wants to ship out of the county is not much. But this is a lot of water if you do not have water to spare. It also does not include the untold millions of gallons Nestlé could truck to its proposed plant from the Hood River Valley and elsewhere, like it does for its other bottling plants.  Nestlé, for example, trucks over 65 million gallons per year to its Denver, Colorado, plant from sources as far as 120 miles away.[1] 

        Voters will not soon forget this summer’s drought, especially since all predictions are that this type drought is quickly becoming our new normal.


Our campaign strategy for winning

       Our campaign is a grassroots effort defined by neighbors talking to neighbors and volunteers working one-on-one with voters to highlight the risks water bottling poses to our water security.  We have already raised more than $10,000, won a legal fight against Hood River County to qualify our measure for the ballot, opened a downtown campaign office, and have more than 50 active volunteers working on the campaign. This is great progress, but we need more support to win this.

       Our strategy is to thoughtfully educate voters while being able to quickly respond to misleading political spin from Nestlé and other bottled water companies. We have supporters from across the political spectrum that represent every part of the county and our goal is to use these supporters’ passion and experiences to educate and inspire those around them. This type of intimate voter contact is possible in a county with just over 11,400 voters, but we will also use all the traditional campaign outreach measures and tools. Our goal is not merely to win the election, but to win with a super-majority of support.   

       While our campaign is homegrown, we also benefit from the expertise and experience of organizations such as Food & Water Watch, which is helping communities around the country stand up to corporate water bottlers, and the CRAG Law Center, which is representing the Local Water Alliance and recently won our lawsuit against the County to help qualify our measure for the ballot. These and many other allies, businesses and elected leaders have already endorsed our ballot measure and taken a stand for the future of our water security.

[1] Sources: http://www.coloradoindependent.com/55554/nestle-to-begin-draining-millions-of-gallons-of-arkansas-river-water; https://www.hcn.org/blogs/goat/nestle-water-plan-approved; http://www.truth-out.org/news/item/25977-nestle...


About Us

The Local Water Alliance is made of up of Hood River County residents working to protect our local water supply from bottled water operations. We are non-partisan and believe people from all political parties can agree that Hood River County's water resources should be used for residential and agricultural uses. 

While the Local Water Alliance is made up of Hood River County residents, we know that communities around the United States are fighting similar battles for their water and appreciate all the advice and support we have received from people and organizations around the county. 

We hope you will join us in supporting this precedent-setting effort to ensure local control of our water supply and our future. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Besides financial support, there are other ways you can help us out:

  • Get the word out to your friends, family, co-workers, and community. Like and share us on Facebook and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Volunteer for and publicly endorse our campaign at LocalWaterAlliance.org.
