story:
Overview

I set out on a path just over a year and a half ago to document local fishing communities in Indonesia. As an Ocean lover, SCUBA Diver and marine conservationist I wanted to see for myself what the impact, if any, a country with one of the World's densest populations, a large part of whom depend on the Ocean for their daily sustenance, was having on the regional marine life. What I found shocked me to the core.

I'm an Emmy winning underwater and wildlife cameraman. I have spent the most part of my working life, since leaving military service in 1994, in the pursuit of imagery to compliment International broadcast and production projects. During that time I have, and continue to, self produce short films predominantly with a conservation message linked to them. Three of these films to date have either won high profile International Film Festival awards or been selected as official entrants for other prestigious screenings.

This particular project will help reinforce the message that we simply cannot keep taking for granted that which the Ocean provides. Local resources can only support local populations IF they are managed correctly. It is sad to state that throughout my filming all I could see was the drive by certain elements to take as much as they could from the local resources in order to supply International demand. In effect taking the food out of the mouths of the families of the men catching the commodity.

Below; Fishing vessels await departure - Tanjung Luar, Lombok

What is Needed?

All of the filming for the Indonesian side of things is now complete. I have run two Crowdfunding drives for this project to date, with a total budget requirement of US$75,000 I managed to raise a total of US$28,005 leaving a shortfall of US$46,995. With a current supporting of some 236 backers to date the underlying feeling is to push through with this final drive for the remainder of the shortfall.

Where will the Money be spent?

Whilst there is some sterling work being done by wonderful people in certain areas of Indonesia, and who feature in this film, it is sad to say that these entities are very much the minority. Very much in evidence throughout the archipelago is the feeling that every person is out for themselves with little, if any, regard for others or for the impact their actions may have on the local marine environment. Needless to say whilst there is some marine based tourism throughout Indonesia it is a tourism aspect which doesn't seem to figure in the daily lives of the majority of coastal living communities. For this reason I want to compare Indonesia with the Republic of Palau.

Very much seen as a leading light in the modern day Ocean conservation drives Palau was the first nation to declare its territorial waters a shark sanctuary back in September of 2009, it is also a place in which I lived for almost four years. A large part of the Palauan population is involved directly or indirectly with the burgeoning Ocean related tourism on which the local economy thrives. One of the major 'pulls' of Palau with the International SCUBA Diving fraternity is that it remains as one of the few remaining locations on Earth where one can interact with a wide diversity of Shark and other enigmatic marine species, such as manta Rays and Turtles, on an almost daily basis.

In order to conclude this project I need to cover the costs for the following key eventualities;

  • Costs for 2 weeks filming in Palau including Helicopter aerial sequences
  • Final Documentary Soundtrack
  • Final 'look' or grading of the documentary
  • Initial DVD product run of 1000 educational and marketing units.
  • Marketing artwork and packaging
  • *Perk Shipping Costs
  • International Film Festival Entry Fees
  • Associated travel costs for festival attendance
  • Licensing Associated Fees

*There remain some perks, T-Shirts, to be shipped from the previous round of crowdfunding which will be collectively administered once this round is complete.

What do you get out of this?

Other than the feelgood factor of being involved with this project simply as an Ocean or marine life lover here is the list of perks I have set up for this final push.

  1.  A US$25 donation gets you listed in the film credits with a Special Thanks.
  2.  A US$75 donation gets you a 'Postcard from Palau' sent during the film trip to complete the project imagery requirement.
  3.  A US$275 gets you a fine art print of 60 x 40cm (24" x 16") print from a gallery of imagery that will be posted for your selection once the Palau segment has been finalized. You will also be included in the 'Special Thanks' credits.
  4.  A US$500 donation gets the previous perks of a postcard and print as well as an 'Ocean Ambassador' title in the film credits and a signed DVD of the final film.
  5.  A US$2,500 donation receives the previous postcard, print and DVD perks plus one of two available credits as Associate Producer.
  6.  **A US$5,000 donation receives previous postcard, print and DVD perks as well as the sole credit as 'Executive Producer' and an invitation, for one person, to the nearest National film festival screening to their home base. 
  7.  A US$10,000 donation receives all perks plus an invitation, for one person, to be my guest of honor at one of the planned International Film Festivals.

**The final film will be submitted to key wildlife and conservation film festivals throughout North America, Europe and the Pacific region.

Note:

All backers are invited by email to join an established private facebook group where some of the more fragile elements of the project are discussed.

Tiger sharks are a SCUBA Diving tourism magnet, not so in Indonesia.


What happens if I don't hit my funding Goal?

Always the main aspect of crowdfunding. I have selected the option to receive the funds raised irrespective if I reach my goal or not. This is down simply to the fact that there is one more filming segment to complete and all the imagery required will be 'in the bag' so to speak. As a working cameraman I will then simply have to look at providing the shortfall in the budget from the income of other projects I work on.

Living and working from a camera is not easy but telling this story to show the world what is happening is a necessity, if not for me then for those who can see the damage that is being done and take steps to correct them, before it's too late. I may go over my deadlines for perk delivery or it may take longer than planned to piece this intricate web of stories together. All I can say is that this is a story and a message that needs to be seen, that will be seen.

What happens if I go beyond the funding Goal?

In a perfect World this project will resonate with enough people to push the raised funds beyond the amount I'm seeking. In that eventuality any excess funds will go towards my next planned project which will focus on the wildlife poaching crisis in Africa.


The Impact

With your help this film will generate enough media attention for the Indonesian authorities to take notice and enforce the national laws of the land, and waters. Many of the fish markets around the country have very clearly placed posters and signs which illustrate species, such as the Great Hammerheads in the above image and the Manta Ray below, to be off limits to fishermen. These signs tend not to last very long, whilst the killing continues.

  • SHARKS - A much needed element in every healthy marine environment. Regulators of a healthy gene pool they guarantee, to an extent, the health of the local fish populations of the reefs they patrol. Indonesia is constantly seen as a global leader in Shark Fin exports to supply the Asian demand for shark fins for the supposed delicacy of sharks fin soup. Many supposedly protected species are documented in this film being landed openly at regional fish markets.
  • Manta Rays - Nothing can describe the feeling of diving with these sentient beings. With the largest brain size to body mass ratio in the Oceans they truly are spectacular. It is therefore somewhat disturbing to see them increasingly targeted by fishermen for their gills which again figure in certain Asian Medicine recipes as supposed cures for a range of ills from curing Cancer to boosting Male virility. Manta Rays are supposed to be protected throughout Indonesia as of February of 2014. The still frame below was taken from filmed footage realized in August 2014.

Below; A GoPro frame taken from the film shows a Giant Manta Ray having been landed with porters taking the main body for processing - Tanjung Luar, Lombok.

The Kicker

As global human populations explode the demands on our Oceans increase exponentially. Trawlers with nets that can fit 13 Jumbo jets in them hoover up target and non target species from huge swathes of our Oceans on a daily basis. Sharks and other predator populations are in free fall, some species are estimated at being 90% decimated since the 1950's. Given this scarcity something has to give, and sadly again that signals the demise of yet another enigmatic marine inhabitant, Dolphins.

It has long been known that certain fishing communities around the World actively target cetaceans to use as bait for regional shark fisheries, Indonesia is no different. Often denied by the authorities this documentary has categorical imagery based evidence proving that this activity still takes place in a number of locations.

To Summarize

We are all connected to the Ocean, to the amazing calm it instills when we sit by it's shores, the invigorating rush of interacting with it for sports and leisure as well as offering us the chance to marvel at it's beauty below the waves. As a nation the Republic of Indonesia is home to some 280 million people, many of them impoverished and dependent on the Ocean for their daily sustenance. Imagine day in day out the requirement to feed even a conservative 40% of the population, that is still in excess of 100 million people per day eating one fish and a handful of rice. One hundred million fish per day at the minimum, is a huge debit to be expected from an already depleted resource.

This film is not about victimization. It is not intended to paint anyone in a bad light, it is mainly pointing out some facts, some cold hard facts. Unregulated fishing of key species such as sharks and Manta Rays from a local resource will end in that local resource collapsing. With no regulators, disease in fish populations will go unchecked, second tier predators move in and turn the food chain on it's head with disastrous results.

This film aims to highlight this and in turn offer an option for a country as diverse and naturally blessed as Indonesia a view into what could transpire of their laws were steadfastly enforced for the better of all citizens. And more so for the generations to come...


Ways You Can Help

I'm very much appreciative from the backers to date and also those to come who feel so moved to select one of the Perks as listed on the right hand column of this project. However, and I completely understand, some people just can't contribute financially but that doesn't mean they can't help. Other ways of supporting this project are as follows:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
  • Please use the allocated social media sharing options for this project!
  • If you follow me on any social media channel I ask that you share or RT any updates I make with regards to the project. This increases the potential audience many fold.

Many thanks for the support. With your help we will tell this story to the World and instill a change for the better.
story_txt:
Overview I set out on a path just over a year and a half ago to document local fishing communities in Indonesia. As an Ocean lover, SCUBA Diver and marine conservationist I wanted to see for myself what the impact, if any, a country with one of the World's densest populations, a large part of whom depend on the Ocean for their daily sustenance, was having on the regional marine life. What I found shocked me to the core.
I'm an Emmy winning underwater and wildlife cameraman. I have spent the most part of my working life, since leaving military service in 1994, in the pursuit of imagery to compliment International broadcast and production projects. During that time I have, and continue to, self produce short films predominantly with a conservation message linked to them. Three of these films to date have either won high profile International Film Festival awards or been selected as official entrants for other prestigious screenings. 
This particular project will help reinforce the message that we simply cannot keep taking for granted that which the Ocean provides. Local resources can only support local populations IF they are managed correctly. It is sad to state that throughout my filming all I could see was the drive by certain elements to take as much as they could from the local resources in order to supply International demand. In effect taking the food out of the mouths of the families of the men catching the commodity. 
Below; Fishing vessels await departure - Tanjung Luar, Lombok


  What is Needed?
 All of the filming for the Indonesian side of things is now complete. I have run two Crowdfunding drives for this project to date, with a total budget requirement of US$75,000 I managed to raise a total of US$28,005 leaving a shortfall of US$46,995. With a current supporting of some 236 backers to date the underlying feeling is to push through with this final drive for the remainder of the shortfall. 
Where will the Money be spent?

Whilst there is some sterling work being done by wonderful people in certain areas of Indonesia, and who feature in this film, it is sad to say that these entities are very much the minority. Very much in evidence throughout the archipelago is the feeling that every person is out for themselves with little, if any, regard for others or for the impact their actions may have on the local marine environment. Needless to say whilst there is some marine based tourism throughout Indonesia it is a tourism aspect which doesn't seem to figure in the daily lives of the majority of coastal living communities. For this reason I want to compare Indonesia with the Republic of Palau.Very much seen as a leading light in the modern day Ocean conservation drives Palau was the first nation to declare its territorial waters a shark sanctuary back in September of 2009, it is also a place in which I lived for almost four years. A large part of the Palauan population is involved directly or indirectly with the burgeoning Ocean related tourism on which the local economy thrives. One of the major 'pulls' of Palau with the International SCUBA Diving fraternity is that it remains as one of the few remaining locations on Earth where one can interact with a wide diversity of Shark and other enigmatic marine species, such as manta Rays and Turtles, on an almost daily basis. 
In order to conclude this project I need to cover the costs for the following key eventualities;

Costs for 2 weeks filming in Palau including Helicopter aerial sequences

Final Documentary Soundtrack
Final 'look' or grading of the documentary
Initial DVD product run of 1000 educational and marketing units.

Marketing artwork and packaging
*Perk Shipping Costs
International Film Festival Entry Fees
Associated travel costs for festival attendance

Licensing Associated Fees

*There remain some perks, T-Shirts, to be shipped from the previous round of crowdfunding which will be collectively administered once this round is complete.




What do you get out of this?Other than the feelgood factor of being involved with this project simply as an Ocean or marine life lover here is the list of perks I have set up for this final push.
 A US$25 donation gets you listed in the film credits with a Special Thanks.
 A US$75 donation gets you a 'Postcard from Palau' sent during the film trip to complete the project imagery requirement.
 A US$275 gets you a fine art print of 60 x 40cm (24" x 16") print from a gallery of imagery that will be posted for your selection once the Palau segment has been finalized. You will also be included in the 'Special Thanks' credits.

 A US$500 donation gets the previous perks of a postcard and print as well as an 'Ocean Ambassador' title in the film credits and a signed DVD of the final film.

 A US$2,500 donation receives the previous postcard, print and DVD perks plus one of two available credits as Associate Producer.
 **A US$5,000 donation receives previous postcard, print and DVD perks as well as the sole credit as 'Executive Producer' and an invitation, for one person, to the nearest National film festival screening to their home base. 
 A US$10,000 donation receives all perks plus an invitation, for one person, to be my guest of honor at one of the planned International Film Festivals.

**The final film will be submitted to key wildlife and conservation film 
festivals throughout North America, Europe and the Pacific region.


Note:
All backers are invited by email to join an established private facebook group where some of the more fragile elements of the project are discussed.




Tiger sharks are a SCUBA Diving tourism magnet, not so in Indonesia.


What happens if I don't hit my funding Goal?Always the main aspect of crowdfunding. I have selected the option to receive the funds raised irrespective if I reach my goal or not. This is down simply to the fact that there is one more filming segment to complete and all the imagery required will be 'in the bag' so to speak. As a working cameraman I will then simply have to look at providing the shortfall in the budget from the income of other projects I work on. Living and working from a camera is not easy but telling this story to show the world what is happening is a necessity, if not for me then for those who can see the damage that is being done and take steps to correct them, before it's too late. I may go over my deadlines for perk delivery or it may take longer than planned to piece this intricate web of stories together. All I can say is that this is a story and a message that needs to be seen, that will be seen.What happens if I go beyond the funding Goal?In a perfect World this project will resonate with enough people to push the raised funds beyond the amount I'm seeking. In that eventuality any excess funds will go towards my next planned project which will focus on the wildlife poaching crisis in Africa. 



 
The Impact With your help this film will generate enough media attention for the Indonesian authorities to take notice and enforce the national laws of the land, and waters. Many of the fish markets around the country have very clearly placed posters and signs which illustrate species, such as the Great Hammerheads in the above image and the Manta Ray below, to be off limits to fishermen. These signs tend not to last very long, whilst the killing continues. 


SHARKS - A much needed element in every healthy marine environment. Regulators of a healthy gene pool they guarantee, to an extent, the health of the local fish populations of the reefs they patrol. Indonesia is constantly seen as a global leader in Shark Fin exports to supply the Asian demand for shark fins for the supposed delicacy of sharks fin soup. Many supposedly protected species are documented in this film being landed openly at regional fish markets.

Manta Rays - Nothing can describe the feeling of diving with these sentient beings. With the largest brain size to body mass ratio in the Oceans they truly are spectacular. It is therefore somewhat disturbing to see them increasingly targeted by fishermen for their gills which again figure in certain Asian Medicine recipes as supposed cures for a range of ills from curing Cancer to boosting Male virility. Manta Rays are supposed to be protected throughout Indonesia as of February of 2014. The still frame below was taken from filmed footage realized in August 2014.

Below; A GoPro frame taken from the film shows a Giant Manta Ray having been landed with porters taking the main body for processing - Tanjung Luar, Lombok.





The Kicker
As global human populations explode the demands on our Oceans increase exponentially. Trawlers with nets that can fit 13 Jumbo jets in them hoover up target and non target species from huge swathes of our Oceans on a daily basis. Sharks and other predator populations are in free fall, some species are estimated at being 90% decimated since the 1950's. Given this scarcity something has to give, and sadly again that signals the demise of yet another enigmatic marine inhabitant, Dolphins. It has long been known that certain fishing communities around the World actively target cetaceans to use as bait for regional shark fisheries, Indonesia is no different. Often denied by the authorities this documentary has categorical imagery based evidence proving that this activity still takes place in a number of locations.



To Summarize

We are all connected to the Ocean, to the amazing calm it instills when we sit by it's shores, the invigorating rush of interacting with it for sports and leisure as well as offering us the chance to marvel at it's beauty below the waves. As a nation the Republic of Indonesia is home to some 280 million people, many of them impoverished and dependent on the Ocean for their daily sustenance. Imagine day in day out the requirement to feed even a conservative 40% of the population, that is still in excess of 100 million people per day eating one fish and a handful of rice. One hundred million fish per day at the minimum, is a huge debit to be expected from an already depleted resource. This film is not about victimization. It is not intended to paint anyone in a bad light, it is mainly pointing out some facts, some cold hard facts. Unregulated fishing of key species such as sharks and Manta Rays from a local resource will end in that local resource collapsing. With no regulators, disease in fish populations will go unchecked, second tier predators move in and turn the food chain on it's head with disastrous results. This film aims to highlight this and in turn offer an option for a country as diverse and naturally blessed as Indonesia a view into what could transpire of their laws were steadfastly enforced for the better of all citizens. And more so for the generations to come...

  Ways You Can Help I'm very much appreciative from the backers to date and also those to come who feel so moved to select one of the Perks as listed on the right hand column of this project. However, and I completely understand, some people just can't contribute financially but that doesn't mean they can't help. Other ways of supporting this project are as follows:  Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign. Please use the allocated social media sharing options for this project!
If you follow me on any social media channel I ask that you share or RT any updates I make with regards to the project. This increases the potential audience many fold.
   Many thanks for the support. With your help we will tell this story to the World and instill a change for the better.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Brendan Goldberg and I am currently a High School Student. Over the past few years I have become really interested in film making. It has recently come to my knowledge the major problem Los Angeles and many other major cities face in terms of global warming.

My Campaign is to make a Short Film documenting the increasing polution in Los Angeles, in hopes to spread awareness about the growing issue we face. I hope to show how it is directly affecting all of our lives every single day. It's time to make a difference.

Right now the biggest issue in creating this film is the financial aspect. As I am a high school student i am not sufficiently funded to create a film of this magnitude! This is where you can help! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

As of now we need $1750 to create our film. This will go directly to the film. The money will go directly to the production of this film. Your contribution will make a direct impact! When I say production, I mean, Gear rentals, Assistants, Mic Holders, Camera operators and much more!

If you choose our Clean Air Donation, we will include your name in the closing credits and a special thanks on our facebook page

If you choose our Wind Power donation, we will Include your name in the closing credits and a special thanks on our facebook page and we will send you a copy of the finished DVD

If you choose our Solar Power donation, we will send you a framed picture of the entire production team signed by all of us. And we will include your name in the closing credits and a special thanks on our facebook page + a copy of the finished DVD

If you choose our Natural Resources donation, your name will be at the start of the film under the "Major Contributors", you will recieve a framed picture of the entire production team signed by all of us. And we will put you in a special thanks on our facebook page and a copy of the DVD,

If you choose our Off The Grid donation we will Send you 5 copys of the DVD, A framed picture of us signed by all of the production team, your name in the start of the film, a special thanks on the facebook page, and a T-Shirt!

You can help spread awareness about Polution all over the world and ways to change it with just a contribution! And if you can't contribute, that's ok! Just please help us spread the word!

Thank you everyone!

Brendan Goldberg

story:
¡Salvemos al Río Jondachi!

The Jondachi, one of the last remaining free-flowing tributaries to the Amazon and Ecuador’s premier kayaking destination, is threatened by imminent hydroelectric development.

The Jondachi was slated to be dammed in January 2015. The Ecuadorian Rivers Institute's 501(c)(3) legal defense of the Jondachi and the exposure generated by the first Jondachi Fest have effectively stalled out dam development...for the time being. 


A strategic 3-part plan to save the river

The ERI's defense of the Jondachi River represents a pioneering strategy for international river conservation, engaging local stakeholders and promoting a clear alternative for resource management by preserving the Jondachi as a wild and scenic, free-flowing ecological corridor between the Andes and the Amazon. 

The ERI is calling on the international community to support the three complementary initiatives of our defense of the Jondachi River: 


1. LEGAL DEFENSE: Protecting the legal rights of the river 

The Ecuadorian Rivers Institute has opposed hydroelectric development on the Jondachi River for over a decade. In 2012, the ERI presented a legal defense of the Jondachi in a renewed effort to stop the La Merced de Jondachi hydro project and keep the Jondachi flowing freely. The ERI's successful 2013 Indiegogo campaign brought in $5000 to fund the original Jondachi Legal Defense. (THANK YOU to everyone who supported us then!) 

Now, after more than two years of deliberation, the Ecuadorian government water authority has REJECTED the ERI's demand to cancel the water concession granted for the La Merced de Jondachi hydro project without taking into consideration tourism and recreational use of the Jondachi River, the errors, omissions, and irregularities in the water concession process, or the recommendations of their own government-appointed expert who advised that the project should be completely re-conceived.  The ERI is now APPEALING this ruling in Ecuadorian court. We are pursuing grant monies to cover the bulk of the legal fees but are calling on our international supporters to help us jumpstart the process. 

(As a side note: In 2008, in an inspiring political statement, Ecuador built into its national constitution an acknowledgement of the rights of nature - personified as pachamama in the indigenous Kichwa. In theory, the new law granted legal standing to natural entities such as rivers. The ERI is acting on behalf of the Jondachi River to be sure those "rights" are not disregarded.)

  • LEARN MORE HERE: Amazon Headwaters under siege: 19 dams slated for Napo watershed 


2. EDUCATION & OUTREACH: An innovative model for watershed conservation  

Last year, the international paddling community rallied together with our Ecuadorian counterparts in an unprecedented expression of impassioned solidarity to create the first-ever Jondachi Fest. 

Jondachi Fest is a grass-roots, volunteer-driven community river festival and whitewater kayak competition that aims to promote the free-flowing Jondachi River as an economically viable alternative to hydro. The Jondachi Fest celebration integrates local facilitation and international participation with whitewater recreation and competition. With Jondachi Fest, the emphasis is on local involvement. 

In 2015, the first Jondachi Fest enjoyed an international media reach of over 100,000 people, while local Ecuadorian media coverage of the event and the issue focused the eyes of the country on this tremendous resource. 

  • LEARN MORE HERE: Canoe & Kayak “Endangered Rivers” digital feature: the Jondcahi

3. CONSERVATION: Groundbreaking pursuit of international wild and scenic river designation  

The ERI is actively pursuing the designation of the Jondachi-Hollin-Misahualli-Napo Ecological Corridor, the international equivalent of “wild and scenic river” protection — the first-ever endeavor of its kind in Ecuador. 

The ERI intends for the proposed Ecological Corridor to be included in the Ecuadorian government’s new strategic plan to make the country a major low-impact adventure tourism destination. The Ecological Corridor initiative is championed by the country's Ministerio del Deporte (Ministry of Sports) and the Ministerio del Turismo (Ministry of Tourism). 

If the precedent can be set for protection of the Jondachi under a new wild and scenic statute, the door will be open for future protection of other imperiled rivers in the Amazon Basin.

  • LEARN MORE HERE: Dams could be catastrophic to Amazon ecological connectivity 




A call to the international community

We need global support to continue fighting for this legendary and iconic river. If we can secure protected river designation for the Jondachi, a door will be opened for future conservation of threatened rivers within the Amazon Basin. 


Where your money will go:

  • 50% of the money we raise in this campaign will go toward the legal defense of the Jondachi. The ERI needs financial support to continue fighting this dam. With this campaign, the ERI is raising crucial funds to APPEAL the landmark river case on the Jondachi and build grassroots vision and action towards appropriate watershed management and development in the Jondachi watershed. 
  • The other 50% will go toward education and outreach (Jondachi Fest) and further socialization of the proposed Ecological Corridor. The ERI needs funds to cover the costs of Jondachi Fest's event infrastructure, kayak safety and logistical support for the Upper Jondachi Race, and the foundation for the community river festival in Tena.

About our fundraising goal:
According to the ancient "science" (and we use that term loosely) of numerology, repetition of the number 11 represents an awakening to opportunities, to idealism, to synchronicity; a chance to notice latent potential and recognize what is truly possible. (All that sounds great to us!) We are embracing this idea with a nod toward the unseen forces in the world. Our fundraising goal acknowledges the playful nature of the universe, and we are aiming for $11,111 by 11:11 pm on November 11. Bring it, universe! Let's do this!

To donate DIRECTLY to the ERI (bypassing Indiegogo's platform fees), please visit the ERI's donation page. 


Who's watching the Jondachi?

International reach:  The first Jondachi Fest enjoyed international media exposure of over 100,000 people. Jondachi Fest was featured in 2015 the following publications, among others:

  • Jondachi Fest’s 2015 bilingual video (by Quito-based Afuera Producciones)
  • Canoe & Kayak “Endangered Rivers” digital feature (March 3, 2015)
  • Canoe & Kayak festival dispatch (January 27, 2015)
  •  Rapid Media festival dispatch (March 11, 2015)
  • American Whitewater Journal dispatch (May/June 2015)

Jondachi Fest also appeared in print in Kayak Session and Paddling Magazine in 2015. Images and news from Jondachi Fest were shared at the National Paddling Film Festival, on sponsored athlete blogs and on the International Rafting Federation’s Threatened Rivers list. Jondachi Fest has an active Facebook presence, Instagram profile, and website (on the Ecuadorian Rivers Institute homepage).



Learn more about Ecuador's rivers

Check out this New York Times article on the development of Ecuador's resources.

To learn about dams in the Andean region, read these articles from Mongabay:

  • Proposed Andean Headwater dams an ecological calamity for Amazon Basin 
  • It can be done: Building better dams in the Andean Amazon 
  • Amazon Headwaters under siege: 19 dams slated for Napo watershed 
  • Dams could be catastrophic to Amazon ecological connectivity 


More ways to support the Jondachi River

  • Share this campaign and our mission with people who may be able to help.
  • Come to Ecuador and participate in Jondachi Fest, January 15-17, 2016! 
  • Stay informed as to how the world's water resources are being developed. 

We encourage you to support free-flowing rivers around the world. 

Thank you for joining us in our fight to save one river that just might pave the way to more effective watershed conservation in the headwaters of the Amazon.     


Gracias to our incredible campaign sponsors:


 

www.smallworldadventures.com


    

www.teamscum.com

www.endlessriveradventures.com

 

 www.teamtarkio.com

GLOBAL RIVER EXPLORATIONS 

 www.globalriverexplorations.com


and thank you to Modality for the beautiful video edit: https://www.vimeo.com/modality

story:
Questa campagna è terminata, clicca sul link sotto per accedere alla nuova campagna di crowdfunding ORTHO CULTURA - construction -


www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/ortho-cultura-construction


Ciao a tutti, siamo Edoardo e Carlo, due ingegneri laureati in ingegneria edile-architettura, innamorati dell'architettura e di tutto quello che attorno vi gravita.

Hi everyone, we are Edoardo and Carlo, two Civil engineer and architect  with a strong passion for architecture in a broad sense and for everything that gravitates around it.

Siamo risultati vincitori di un bando di concorso per la realizzazione di un'installazione di architettura da esporre in occasione della fiera  dell'agricoltura “Festival degli Orti” 2015, che si terrà a Monza dal 14 al 24 maggio, e vorremmo poter realizzare davvero il nostro progetto.

We won a competition for the construction of an architecture installation to be exhibited at the agriculture fair "Festival degli Orti 2015" that will be held in Monza from May 14th to May 24th, and we would love to truly realize our project.

TERRALAB 3.0 - www.terralabtrepuntozero.org
FESTIVAL DEGLI ORTI - www.festivaldegliorti.it

Il bando che ci ha visto vincitori non prevede lo stanziamento di fondi per la realizzazione e obbliga i progettisti a farsi carico degli oneri di esecuzione. Essendo due giovani professionisti e non avendo alle spalle aziende o privati che ci sostengano, siamo alla ricerca di fondi, partnership e sponsor che ci aiutino nella realizzazione dell’installazione.

The competition we won unfortunately does not include funds allocation for the project realization. For this reason we are forced to fund the execution with our own forces. As young professionals with no support from companies, we are looking for funds, partnerships or sponsors willing to help us in the realization of the installation

                                             

è un progetto "sociale" nato con l'ambiziosa volontà di suggerire e sensibilizzare di fronte la necessità di rileggere l’agricoltura. Pensarla ed immaginarla in modi nuovi rispetto al passato, perdendo pregiudizi e preconcetti storici e storicizzati, tendendo ad un’idea di agricoltura nuova, accompagnata per questo da nuove forme e stimoli. Saper vedere l’agricoltura con occhi nuovi rivalutandone il carattere strategico a livello economico e sociale.

is a social project born with the ambitious desire to suggest and raise awareness of the need to re-read the concept of agriculture. Think and imagine it in an innovative way by losing historical prejudices and preconceptions, tending to a brand new idea of agriculture, accompanied by new forms and stimuli. Being able to see agriculture with new eyes revalues its strategic role from an economic and social point of view.

ORTHO CULTURA interpreta la necessità di guardare all’agricoltura non solo come un mezzo per “vivere in economia” ma anche come opportunità di “fare economia”, ricominciare a credere che con un’agricoltura nuova, smart, intelligente e all’avanguardia per metodi e gestione, si possano creare allo stesso tempo business e integrazione.

ORTHO CULTURA interprets the need to look at agriculture not only as a means to "live with no great expenses" but also as an opportunity to "economize", by starting to believe that agriculture can be a way to create both business and integration through new, smart and innovative methods and a renowned management style.

Un’agricoltura 3.0 per approccio ed atteggiamento, per questo giovane e alla portata di chiunque.

Our purpose is to boost agriculture 3.0 characterized by a new approach and attitude, attractive for young people and affordable for everyone.


La soddisfazione di essere stati selezionati è stata chiaramente immensa, vista da noi sia come incredibile opportunità di farci conoscere quali giovani professionisti e come progettisti attenti al profondo valore e significato sociale che l'architettura, nella sua accezione più ampia, deve avere e deve riscoprire; sia come vanto ed orgoglio di essere gli unici abruzzesi a poter esporre "un’opera” all’interno di una manifestazione internazionale strettamente connessa con EXPO 2015.

The satisfaction of being selected as winners was clearly immense. To us this it as an incredible opportunity to emerge as young professionals and designers with a particular focus to the deep value and social role that architecture, in its broadest sense, must have and must rediscover nowadays; yet, we are extremely proud of being the only ones from our beautiful land Abruzzo to be able to expose at an international event of this relevance, closely connected with EXPO 2015.


Il progetto è stato pensato come un'installazione di facile e veloce realizzazione in linea con lo spirito e le linee guida del concorso. Materiali sostenibili, ma soprattutto semilavorati, utilizzati secondo principi di UP-CYCLING e RE-CYCLING, di facile reperimento e comoda installazione. Il budget minimo di cui avremo bisogno per poter realizzare ed esporre la nostra opera è stato calcolato considerando il costo e/o il valore di questi materiali.

The project was conceived as an installation of quick and easy implementation in line with the spirit and guidelines of the contest. Sustainable materials, but mostly semi-used ones in accordance with the principles of UP-CYCLING and RE-CYCLING, easy to find and to install. The minimum budget that we need to realize and expose our work has been calculated considering the cost and / or the value of these materials.

Una rilettura in chiave moderna dell'orto urbano, e della possibilità di fare dell'agricoltura un momento sociale, aggregante, nuovo luogo di relazione, incontro, scambio ed apprendimento.
A modern reinterpretation of the urban farm, and of the possibility of making agriculture a social activity, being at the same time aggregating and a place of relationship, meeting, exchange and mutual learning.

Un elemento flessibile caratterizzato da una progettazione aperta che sottende la possibilità di utilizzo a varia scala e su scenari profondamente diversi. Suggerisce un approccio di condivisione e collaborazione proponendo una lettura mai univoca dello spazio. 

A flexible element characterized by an open design that underlies the possibility of using different scales and deeply different scenarios. It suggests sharing and collaboration by offering a multilateral space reading that is never unique.

Tavolati in legno montati ad incastro realizzano una griglia ortogonale statica che regola l’inserimento degli elementi necessari alla coltivazione, vera parte dinamica. Pozzetti in calcestruzzo trovano nuovo utilizzo tra le maglie del basamento dando vita a passerelle distributive.
Wooden planks interlocking constitute an orthogonal static grid that rules the inclusion of the necessary elements for cultivation, that represent the truly dynamic part. Concrete manholes find new use in the base meshes creating walkways distribution.
L’installazione perimetrata da elementi verticali, leggeri e permeabili, idealizza pareti e narra uno spazio architettonico in cui elementi classici del costruire vengono prestati all’orto che diviene, in tal modo, urbano.
The installation bounded by light and permeable vertical elements, idealizes walls and narrates an architectural space where classic elements of the building are “lent” to the garden that becomes, in this way, urban.

La volontà di veicolare il progetto partendo dalle nostre realtà, con la possibilità di estenderlo verso il bacino di utenza di molte associazioni no-profit che già operano con successo permettendo a famiglie intere di fare economia attraverso piccoli ma preziosissimi sforzi.
Our goal is to convey the project starting from our reality, with the possibility of extending it to the user base of many non-profit organizations that already operate successfully in this sector, allowing entire families to make savings through small but valuable efforts.
Una vocazione totalmente sociale che speriamo possa prendere il largo grazie a tutti voi!
Thus, Ortho Cultura is 100% inspired by a social vocation and we truly hope that it will take off thanks to your contribution and support!!


Come contribuire con una donazione:

- inserisci il contributo (in dollari USD)
- clicca su 


- procedi al pagamento tramite carta di credito o paypal

How to make a donation:

- insert your contribute (dollar USD)
- click on 


- proceed to pay by credit card or paypal

Questa campagna è terminata, clicca sul link sotto per accedere alla nuova campagna di crowdfunding ORTHO CULTURA - construction -
www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/ortho-cultura-construction

Ciao a tutti, siamo
Edoardo e Carlo, due ingegneri laureati in ingegneria edile-architettura, innamorati dell'architettura e di tutto quello che attorno vi gravita.

Hi everyone, we are Edoardo and Carlo, two Civil engineer and architect  with a strong passion for architecture in a broad sense and for everything that gravitates around it.

story:
Green Jobs Rule!

Who doesn't want a job that means more than just a paycheck? Until every job is a green job, we're connecting users with the best green jobs on the world's coolest green job posting website.

Our campaign goal is to raise enough funds to design, build, launch, and promote a user-friendly, hyper-connected green jobs portal that will help millions of people around the world shift into greener careers. 


What We Need & What You Get

Our needs are simple: we're seeking the startup capital to design, build, launch and promote our new site. The estimated cost for this rockin' project is about $4,000. After this initial funding, the site will become self-sustaining.

If you represent a company working in sustainability, you will get: 

  • Great Connections: Our green jobs site will help you reach our millions of intelligent, motivated, and sophisticated readers. Through this campaign, you can pre-buy job post ad credits, and use them when you are ready to find someone awesome. 
  • Excellent Exposure: We are connected to one of the world's biggest green media companies, and this means only good things for your company. Some of the Perks we're offering with this campaign include targeted, high-value exposure for your company or organization on our network of over 20 sites and/or sharing across our broad social media networks.
If you're an individual who wants to see a super-green website devoted entirely to jobs in renewables, green building, sustainable food and the like, you can get: 
  • Sweet prizes: We're offering up sustainability board games, green living books, and much more...
And no matter who you are, your support earns you mega good green karma and our undying love, gratitude, and appreciation! Thank you in advance for your support of our project.

Risks & Challenges

Why should we believe that this site will turn into a powerful force for good? 

People want green jobs. That is crystal clear. We've been working in sustainable media for 12 years, and believe we are the people to create and SUSTAIN the world's best green jobs website. This site will be part of Important Media, one of the world's biggest sustainability media companies, with over 3 million monthly readers. 

Sheesh, our name is a little self-important, isn't it? Well, the reason we call it Important Media is because we cover things that are VERY important: your health, the quality of your air, the quality of your water, the movements and people that are making our planet better everyday, along with all the other things we need to do to sustain life on this planet. We have never, not once, ever covered anything about  the Kardashians or deflated footballs. And we never will. :) 

We own the world's largest clean tech news site, one of the top alternative transportation sites, and over 20 other niche sites dedicated to one aspect of sustainability or another. 

Each week, we will broadcast all the great jobs posted on our green jobs site to our network, increasing exposure to the jobs and helping people connect their passion with work that matters. With the Important Media network we can build our green jobs site into an effective tool to help millions of people find a career they love to sustain the planet we all need. 

And check out our growth plan!

Not only do we want to create the most comprehensive and most searched green jobs database, like, EVER, we want to continue to grow and increase our green jobs reach. Here our our Stretch Goals for the next two years:

story:
Hi,

my name is Zoltan, my fiancée is Alexandra. We are a couple of "back to the land"-ers in Hungary. We will move this year from the capital city Budapest, to one of the most beautifull area of the hill-country of Zala.

We've just acquired a small piece of land near Nagykanizsa, Homokkomarom. The valley is slashed with small properties, on most they grow vine. In the vicinity there is a huge woodland with all its miracles and places to explore. Some photos via google.
Our property is oriented to the south-west, and gets a good sun in the whole year around (the avarage temperature is 11°C). It has a slope of cca. 10 meters. The annual rainfall is over 600mm, so rainwater harvesting is quite possibel.
The farm has an old vine plantation, that must be replaced, a wild-grown locust forest, and some plughland unused for 5 years.

Our goal is to start a new life there, and if possible to create commun of dedicated people to sustainable living, to permaculture.
We'll be creating an off-grid farm, with low imputs of money and high imputs of human efforts, talent and heart.
After carefull assesment of the soil, the climate, and the externalities we will be planting native trees and plants from local sources, and we will be raising some small lifestock, and bees.

In the first step, we have to stop speading locust further, and we have to cut a lot of long dead vine-stocks.  These cuttings then has to be shredded for mulch and for compost.
We are triing to be the most low-impact, so we will be growing plants in no till gardenbeds. For that we will need a lot of mulch. The easiest way getting this much mulch is to use the resources in the vicinity of our farm. That meens we have to shred biomass for our self.

So we need a shredder, and because we don't have electricity, we need a petrol powered one (like MTD 465). These units costs about 800€, my wage for three months. We can't afford that in this year for there is the project of off-grid living: - 200W solar panels and batteries costs around the same; - house repairment also costs a lot; - bulid a shower, and composting loo, with greywater threatment and bins; - summer kitchen, and guest qouters, etc.

We are a starting farm, but we have high hopes for the future.
We will be hosting woofers and couchsurfers in a year! We are an open farm, so we can learn from everyone - and everyone can learn from us to.
We'd like to host permaculture curses, to spread the ideas of Bill and David, and lot of others in order to grow more with less energy, and better quality.
We will explore the wilderness around our site, and create hicking tracks to show the beauty and wonders of our native forest.
 
For your generous contribution we can offer you a our services as host, as tour guides, or as facilitators. We will be glad meeting you in Hungary at our little corner of this world, and spending some time together!

For those of you who can't offer money, you are also welcome to visit us, and help us bulid a better world!
 
Also please share my project so more people can learn about it, and help us get trough!
 
We are wishing you and your familie the best of the best!
Zoltan & Alexandra

story:
Begawan Foundation has been breeding, raising and releasing the endangered Bali Starling, the mascot of Bali, since 1999. For the most part, funds come from our founders, whose mission it is to ensure that Bali Starlings once again safely live and breed in the wild. In 1999 there were probably only about 6 birds left in the wild, not a healthy situation.

The first aviaries were built in a small village north of Ubud, Bali in 1999 to house our first two pairs of Bali Starlings, imported from UK. In 2005, all aviaries went to the small island of Nusa Penida, where 65 Bali Starlings were released and a small flock of birds is still in place there. Extinction is being avoided!

In 2010 all aviaries were moved back to mainland Bali, to our new breeding and release site in Sibang, once again near Ubud, and more aviaries were built. We have now released 8 birds here, with Dr Jane Goodall participating in the most recent release in June this year.

It’s time for us to ensure that all the aviaries, old and new are maintained at an international standard. The breeding Bali Starlings deserve to have their homes in tip-top condition. We frequently have guests visit us, we provide a tour of the site, guests can assist with the daily feeding of the birds, and lunch can be served right beside the socialisation aviary where juvenile Bali Starlings play, find a mate and generally enjoy themselves before they move to the breeding enclosures.

Check us out on our website www.begawanfoundation.org and our Facebook page www.facebook.com/begawanfoundation

All funds received will be used to replace wire mesh, metal panels, and give all a new coat of paint.

Jane Goodall participating in the most recent release in June this year.
It’s time for us to ensure that all the
aviaries, old and new are maintained at an international standard. The breeding
Bali Starlings deserve to have their homes in tip-top condition. We frequently
have guests visit us, we provide a tour of the site, guests can assist with the
daily feeding of the birds, and lunch can be served right beside the
socialisation aviary where juvenile Bali Starlings play, find a mate and
generally enjoy themselves before they move to the breeding enclosures.
Check us out on our website www.begawanfoundation.org and our
Facebook page www.facebook.com/begawanfoundation
All funds received will be used to replace
wire mesh, metal panels, and give all a new coat of paint.

story:
ABOUT ME

My name is Jerry Wilson. I was born in McComb, Mississippi, and moved to California when I was 7 years old. During my childhood, I watched and sometimes helped my father make anything we needed out of wood. He had the simplest of tools but was able to make beautiful, useful things for his 3 sons and our mother. I still have a table in my hallway he made when he was 18 years old. 

 My career focus took me away from woodworking but I've always worked in manufacturing. At one time, I made winches for 12 meter racing yachts and had the privilege of working on equipment for the Intrepid, two-time Defender of the America's Cup in 1967 and 1970.

 For 10 years, I owned a machine shop making all kinds of metal parts and equipment. I sold the machine shop to my partner and found a job in the medical industry where I designed and made equipment to manufacture small plastic lenses (intraocular lenses) that were implanted inside the human eye of cataract patients. I worked in this field for the next 30 years. During this time I built 8 medical facilities for this product in 6 different countries.

 Now I have a wood shop that my father couldn't have dreamed of. Modern technology has changed the world including what is now possible in a wood shop. As a craftsmen working alone I have access to some amazing technology: computer numerical control (CNC) equipment, computer-aided drafting (CAD) and Computer-aided manufacturing (CAM). The equipment I like to use most is my ShopBot 3D Router and my Epilog CO2 laser.

 CNC and CAD CAM is very efficient when it comes to making more than 1 part. I've found that the more you can make the more efficiency you can realize. I enjoy both the production of multiple pieces and making one of a kind items as well.

 Thank you!

 Jerry

About the shop

My shop space was built by the former owner as a place to park his work truck, so it's open to the environment on three sides. I have to cover the equipment to protect them. The other night I walked out to the shop and suprised a raccoon looking for something to eat. I'm hoping I reach my project goal so I can enclose my shop. The support of the Indiegogo community would be helpful and most appreciated.

Below you will find useful information supplied by my bamboo supplier, I hope you enjoy reading it as much as I did.

Why Bamboo?

In considering the benefits of an expanding bamboo industry globally there is much good to be said of it. From a forestry standpoint, bamboo can be grown with no added fertilizers, pesticides or irrigation and can sequester up to 70% more carbon per year than a hardwood forest.

Moso bamboo has an optimal five-year growth cycle and is selectively harvested by hand, eliminating heavy equipment that can impact habitat. Bamboo can be harvested without the need to replant, as it naturally regenerates annually. Due to a rhizome root structure, bamboo has the ability to hold loose soil in place, preventing erosion.

Bamboo is a rapidly renewable and readily available alternative source of material for a wide range of applications. Uses and applications for bamboo are plentiful with new ones being discovered all the time.

From its humble origins as an inexpensive raw material for building or fabrication of simple structures, furniture, tools, baskets, artistic craft and food source, bamboo now finds itself used for flooring, plywood, veneers, bicycles, fabrics and additives for both food and cosmetics. This has created new jobs in forestry, manufacturing, innovation and design, science and technology.

Because Smith & Fong has worked hand-in-hand with local farmers, processors and manufacturers for many years, we are able to understand the challenges and the opportunities of the bamboo industry in ways few people can.

Environment and Sustainability 

From the beginning, Smith & Fong has been dedicated to sustainability. We make our decisions based on quality and design as well as social and environmental considerations. We believe that profit is the byproduct --not the product-- of a job well done.

We have worked hard to earn a reputation for integrity and consider the trust our customers place in us one of our greatest assets. We believe in the natural sustainability of bamboo forestry and the harvesting practices developed over centuries of experience. To validate the legitimacy of our forestry practices, we sought out the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) for their help in certifying our Moso bamboo forest in China. After a two-year process, we succeeded in becoming the first bamboo company to offer FSC-Pure certified bamboo flooring, plywood and veneer in the North American market.

As adhesive sciences improved and concern for indoor air quality grew, we became the first adapters of formaldehyde-free manufacturing in both the bamboo and palm industries. We confirmed our success with California Section 01350 testing, still the most stringent off-gas testing protocol available anywhere. In an effort to streamline our formaldehyde-free program, an interesting alternative appeared--soy-based, formaldehyde-free resins. To our knowledge there was only one other company worldwide that was using anything similar. We liked it.

Over a three-year process we were successful in adapting the soy-based resin to our unique bamboo manufacturing process. This allowed us to become the first bamboo company to offer a soy-based, formaldehyde-free adhesive system, surpassing emission requirements and setting a new level for clean in the industry. In order to improve our processes and our products, we undergo independent auditing and hold certification with FSC, well-managed forestry, FloorScore, requiring 01350 off-gas testing as well as management and factory controls and ISO 14001, a world standard in environmental control protocols.

We also make every effort to recycle, reuse or use recycled materials in our packaging. Smith & Fong is directly engaged in setting environmental company policy and goals.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Let your friends about about the bamboo party trays project.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
I'm  Minni Jain and I run a Charity (not for profit), Earthlinks UK, which works with water issues globally (theflowpartnership.org). We are organising the visit  of Rajendra Singh, the Water Gandhi, to the UK from 4th - 9th Nov 2014, to look at easing floods and droughts by holding water upstream in the landscape. 



A few years ago I met Rajendra Singh (see his work in the video above)


On his invitation, I went to India to see the work they were doing in relieving droughts. Amazingly, the villages in that area were all engaged in building johads ( small dam interventions)  in strategic places in the landscape and holding back the water that fell in the rainy season, bringing life and livelihoods back to that  dry  and arid region.


And last year, with the massive flooding the UK experienced - I met some scientists who had been working with communities and landowners in the UK, BUILDING SIMILAR INTERVENTIONS as Johads TO STOP FLOODS!

A johad like intervention to retain flood water in the UK

These two problems of drought and flooding can be solved using the same techniques of  “Holding Water”in the landscape– one solution to two extreme problems facing humanity. This is why we are bringing Rajendra Singh over to the UK  to share his experiences with a view to helping the UK solve its flooding challenges in a way that benefits both the communities and the environment.

Brief description of our campaign 

 In this week in November, Rajendra Singh has been invited to the UK to convene various meetings around these two issues and their solutions. Through these meetings at strategic places, we are seeking the active collaboration of farmers, scientists, engineers, NGO’s, politicians, landowners, property developers and other interested people from local communities.

Confirmed Program ( so far):

4th November: A Global Resource Partnership – evening dinner with future strategic partners at the House of Lords

5th November: Natural Flood management in the UK – Holding Water – Savills, Margaret Street, London with partners the James Hutton Institute/Scotland & Newcastle University

6th November: The Economist WORLD WATER SUMMIT/Time for Action at ‘The Crystal’, London– closing keynote by Rajendra Singh/welcome by Minni Jain

7th November: Meetings with farmers and landowners on site . Managing Floods – sharing  Indian and UK experiences and solutions- partners -the James Hutton Institute/Scotland & Newcastle University

8TH November – in Devon – public event – TBC.


What your contributions will help us achieve

Thanks to all the kind and generous donations that we have received so far , we now have £8000 of the £15000 we need to make Rajendra Singh’s visit happen. Our target now is to raise the remaining £7000 by 15th October 2014 which will ensure that:

a) We will be able to organise an interactive symposium for young activists to meet with Rajendra Singh and hear his remarkable story which started at the age of 25  inspired by the ideals of Gandhi and a passion to bring life back to a  arid region in a remote part of Rajasthan, India.

b) We will be able to visit some of the sites of last winters flooding  in the UK with Rajendra and  meet with affected communities and landowners with a view to helping them ease their water related problems in the long term.

c) We will be able to come together with potential policy makers and funders with the aim of simplifying policy by introducing them to these cost-effective solutions that empower land owners and communities. This meeting will happen in Westminster.

d) We will also be able to invite Maulik Sisodia, the implementation co-ordinator from India - who is responsible for the on-the ground actions and initiating future projects.  Coming here will enable him to interact with UK co-ordinators, sharing his practical experience of project implementation and help create opportunities for future collaborations with them.

HEALTHY LANDSCAPES

Rajendra’s visit  will help to raise awareness about the simple shifts in land management towards the retention of water within the landscape which are fundamental to the future health of our catchments. Both dry and flood-prone regions, need to retain runoff within the landscape, to ‘slow, store and filter’ water at as many locations as possible. This requires all land owners and policy makers to recognise in the first instance, that the enhanced loss of water from their landscape is the major problem. Holding back water in landscapes is fundamental to resilient and healthy systems better able to supply food, clean water and ease flooding. A simple approach of holding back water back on land could help simplify policy, be cost-effective, remove red tape and empower land owners and communities to create the healthy landscapes they desire. 


River BEFORE restoration 


River AFTER restoration by building these small dams 'Johads', 12 years later

What we need 

 This visit is the first part of a co-ordinated approach which will link flood and drought prone areas around the world in order to share experience, skills, best-practice and methods with a view to effective water management that will benefit local communities, ecology and ensure global food security.


These community led water solutions are both empowering and necessary. They help the landscape, ecology and communities. We welcome your involvement and you will be welcome to visit any of our projects in the UK and in India.  This is a growing movement and we would really like to meet you if you have an interest in this area of drought and flood solutions.

Our  fundraising milestones on the way to the £7000 are

£1000 - will enable us to organise a visit to a UK success story where small dam interventions have successfully held back the water, prevented floods even during last winters torrential  rain. This is to raise awareness as well as spark excitement in the surrounding villages facing similar problems that low-cost local solutions are not only effective but also within their reach.
£3000 - This will also allow us to also organise an interactive symposium for young activists to meet with Rajendra Singh and hear his remarkable story which started at the age of 25  inspired by the ideals of Gandhi and a passion to bring life back to a  arid region in a remote part of Rajasthan, India.
    £5000 - Will allow us to organise a presentation by Rajendra Singh in Westminster, London for prospective funders to pledge their support with funds and enable these catchment solution methods to be implemented globally through building more Johads and starting water schools.
    £7000 - This will allow us to invite Maulik Sisodia, the implementation co-ordinator from India - who is responsible for the on-the ground actions and initiating future projects.  Coming here will enable him to interact with UK co-ordinators, sharing his practical experience of project implementation and help create opportunities for future collaborations with them.

    The Impact

    • The project facilitates community-driven decentralised water management & conservation. It encourages the disciplined use of natural resources, ensuring sustainable water availability for humans and livestock, resulting in an increase in agricultural and milk production. In turn this ensures food security and restores an area’s ecology and afforestation, sequestering carbon, increasing bio-diversity and strengthening its capacity to adapt to climate change.

    • Over the last 28 years, we have revived 7 rivers in Rajasthan, India from being completely dry to flowing perennially! In the UK, a village that flooded 5 times in 2 years, has been dry this last winter when every other village was flooded in that area. Please see our website for more information: www.theflowpartnership.org


    Other Ways You Can Help

    We will be grateful if you can share and recommend this project through your networks. Please use all possible media to talk about it, blog about it, forward it – send it to everyone you know! The world will be grateful! And we will be too!

story:
Summary

The Nature Iraq Foundation, Inc. (NIF) is a U.S.-based 501(c)3 public charity whose mission is to provide financial and administrative support to Nature Iraq and nonprofit organizations dedicated to the protection, restoration, and conservation of the environment in Iraq and the Middle East region. 

Our goal is to orchestrate a journey down the Tigris River, starting in southeastern Turkey and travelling through Iraq, using traditional boats and vessels in order to document and bring awareness to the myriad threats facing not only the timeless waters of the Tigris but also the unique cultural heritage of Mesopotamia. In so doing, the project seeks to connect conservation issues with daily life and enable people to take action. 

By building greater awareness of both the local and gobal community and collecting data critical to understanding the current state and threats to the Tigris, YOU can help us empower local communities in protecting this vital resource.

What We Need 

The Flotilla Project requires a lot more funding than what we're asking for on Indiegogo.  We anticipate the project costing closer to $200,000 than $20,000.  We will utilize several sources, including foundations, private donors, and in-kind support from partners, to make this adventure happen.  

The money raised here will be used for the initial project costs, including the most important part: building the traditional boats that will be used for the journey!  We will build a tarada, a guffa, and a kelek, using natural materials with traditional methods. Nature Iraq's ecocamp in Sulaimani Iraq was built using natural materials with traditional methods so we're already knowledgeable about these techniques.  We just need the funds to get going! 

Because building the boats and planning the security and logistics of such a trip take time, we expect to launch the flotilla in the fall of 2013.  

The Impact

We hope to: 

1) Achieve greater awareness in local communities in Turkey and Iraq about the threats to the Tigris River, and help call global attention to this one-of-a-kind ecology. We will do this through riverside community outreach and presentations, local media interviews, and through a blog that will catelogue and explain the journey.

2) Collect data critical to understanding the ecology of the Tigris and document the state of the river through water quality tests and threat assessments. We will partner with at least one university in Iraq and one in Turkey for the analysis of the data to help encourage regional partnership on water protection.

3) Create a stronger voice and network for communities to influence decision-making regarding water resource management by identifying Community Waterkeeper Liasons, building a website for future networking, collecting declaration letters from communities on what they want for their local water source, and organizing at least 3 direct actions throughout the trip.

Our History

Nature Iraq has a long history of water protection in Iraq.  If you would like more information, please see some of the media coverage of past activities:

Miracle in the Marshes of Iraq: A one-hour wildlife documentary by BBC

http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00xxf9f

Restoring the Paradise that Saddam Destroyed: Article by Der Spiegel

http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/iraq-s-garden-of-eden-restoring-the-paradise-that-saddam-destroyed-a-709866.html

Braving Iraq: 60 Minutes on Nature Iraq on PBS

http://www.pbs.org/wnet/nature/episodes/braving-iraq/introduction/5957/

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to support the Tigris River Flotilla project but want to give more than money, please consider these non-monetary ways to help:

  • Help spread the word! Use Indiegogo share tools, post on your Facebook wall, write an article for the newspaper you work for, tell your friends over coffee, whatever you've got!  
  • Donate items we need for the trip! See our Wish List at REI or contact us for more information on how you can help.

Thanks for your support!

We will do this through riverside community outreach and presentations, local media interviews, and through a blog that will catelogue and explain the journey.
2) Collect data critical to understanding the ecology of the Tigris and document the state of the river through water quality tests and threat assessments. We will partner with at least one university in Iraq and one in Turkey for the analysis of the data to help encourage regional partnership on water protection.
3) Create a stronger voice and network for communities to influence decision-making regarding water resource management by identifying Community Waterkeeper Liasons, building a website for future networking, collecting declaration letters from communities on what they want for their local water source, and organizing at least 3 direct actions throughout the trip.
Our History
Nature Iraq has a long history of water protection in Iraq.  If you would like more information, please see some of the media coverage of past activities:
Miracle in the Marshes of Iraq: A one-hour wildlife documentary by BBC
http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00xxf9f
Restoring the Paradise that Saddam Destroyed: Article by Der Spiegel
http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/iraq-s-garden-of-eden-restoring-the-paradise-that-saddam-destroyed-a-709866.html
Braving Iraq: 60 Minutes on Nature Iraq on PBS
http://www.pbs.org/wnet/nature/episodes/braving-iraq/introduction/5957/
Other Ways You Can Help


If you would like to support the Tigris River Flotilla project but want to give more than money, please consider these non-monetary ways to help:

Help spread the word! Use Indiegogo share tools, post on your Facebook wall, write an article for the newspaper you work for, tell your friends over coffee, whatever you've got!  
Donate items we need for the trip! See our Wish List at REI or contact us for more information on how you can help.

Thanks for your support!

story:
What if the cheapest new car in America was electric and 100% zombie apocalypse ready?


We are two brothers, Michael and Kenny, who want to build street-legal electric vehicles that are affordable and apocalypse ready. While traditional car companies don't care that your current vehicle is nothing more than an out-of-gas zombie trap in a post-apocalypse wasteland, we have come up with a solution. Whether caused by the rapture, nuclear war, or (most likely) zombies, ApocalypsEV-1 is the affordable solar/battery powered transportation that allows savvy survivors to traverse the sun-baked badlands the fun way. Whether searching for pockets of civilization, water, or family, the ApocalypsEV limits the search for one valuable commodity, fuel. 

At ApocalypsEV, we are humans first and promise to take firm stand against selling any of our vehicles to the undead, unlike some major car companies. While waiting for judgement day, our ApocalypsEV-1 retains practical, civilized applications. First and foremost it functions as an electric, All Terrain Vehicle (ATV) while doubling as a street-legal Electric Vehicle (EV) for short commutes and errands.

ApocalypsEV-1 Specs:


-Side by side ATV with seating for two (similar in design to a Yamaha Rhino) 

-Platform that can be 2 or 4 wheel drive

-Solar boost charging
-Accept many battery configurations based on price and range

 By lessening dependence on oil, it is hoped the ApocalypsEV-1 can help avert several apocalyptic scenarios, but if it happens despite our best efforts, we have you covered. ApocalypsEV-1 tests the feasibility of affordable EVs that are capable off-roaders and qualify as federal Neighborhood Electric Vehicle for trips to the gun or grocery store.


The Impact

ApocalypsEV-1 is an EV that is both street legal and off-road capable. The question is whether it will prove to be usable, which is why we need to build ApocalypsEV-1 as a test mule. If it proves usable, our ultimate goal is to create a company which offers a $5-8k (base price) EV, that can be plugged in or use built in solar to charge its battery pack.  At this price, people can afford an ApocalypsEV-1 as a second car for short commutes, errands, and off-road fun.  

Now that you know about the ApocalypsEV-1 concept, surviving the apocalypse, will be bittersweet if you don't help us build this handy, self-fueling vehicle. Sure, as a survivor you will have your choice of super cars or military vehicles, but they won't do you much good because there will be no gas. By helping make ApocalypsEV-1, you are ensuring your time as a survivor is that much easier. Imagine the fun you will have wearing your custom chainsaw-ninja suit while tearing through the badlands in your solar powered ApocalypsEV-1!  


What We Need & What You Get

All funds raised will go toward building the ApocalypsEV-1 and related costs (fees, taxes). Money spent will be documented on our website. If we do not meet our funding goals on IndieGoGo, we will try and raise funds from other sources by seeking donations of parts or money from others.  We are two brothers who previously raised $1200 to build a solar powered EV called TWEAK (http://kinaestheticwind.com/projects/tweak0.php). ApocalypsEV-1 takes the lessons learned from TWEAK, and applies them to a small, two-seat electric ATV that will be street legal under the federal Neighborhood Electric Vehicle provision. 

Costs:
Motors and controllers:       $1400-3000

Chassis, suspension, tires: $2000-5000  (We would like to build the chassis from scratch, but we may end up repurposing an existing ATV chassis. It will need headlights, turn signals, seats, seat belts and will cost more to make the prototype than it will in production.

Batteries:                             $400-1000

Solar Panels and charger:   $150-300

Miscellaneous:                     $100-700


What you get:

Check out our unique perks. All donors are kept up to date on the project, and we have various levels of goodies to say thanks for your support.


Other Ways You Can Help

Join us on Twitter @ApocalypsEV1
Check out the website http://ApocalypsEV.com


Please share the project with people who might be interested


Cheers,

Michael and Kenny
