their organic methods, passed down for generations, and work with them to
address challenges which can make their processes less sustainable.According to the Global Shea Alliance, the industry sources
raw material for export from around four million rural women collectors, with a
total of approximately 16 million collectors active across the entire Shea
zone.



Help Build a Sustainability Revolution in Africa!
Through our modest pilot, in 2013 and 2014, we created
direct employment opportunities for six community members and indirect employment
for four. These projects were personally funded. At this point, external
financing will significantly expand our reach.                                                     Some  Shea processors from  the community which helped us with our first pilot
My team currently
needs $5500 in seed
funding to keep the ball rolling for this new organization and to fund our first
project under the Sustainable Business Leader Program. To get this going, I
don’t just want to ask for donations. Rather, I’d like to offer you something
tangible, and awesome in the form of perks.How Indiegogo Works: 
You choose how much you want to pledge and pick a perk (or
more...)  At the end of our campaign we pay indiegogo a 4% fee from the money
we’ve raised.  If we don't reach our goal, we have to pay 9%.  You
can see how important it is that we reach our goal! 
Perks:Below are some perks up for grabs                               Sustainable Business Leader Certified Logo                                                                                   Digital Photo Pack & Thank You Note 
             
                                        Organic Hand Made
Shea Souvenir                                                                       Photo Credits:Amanda of Swan Maiden            Your Name in the
Credits for the 2015 Global Water Dance-Ghana                Limited Edition DVD of the 2015 Global Water Dance-Ghana                                                    Six Years in
Mozambique                                                                                                              

Mind Wanderer
                                                                           Africa's
Entrepreneurs in the 21st Century
                                                                      
                                                      A School for My Village
                                                                                                          The Toaster Project                                                                                           Named Climate  Smart Orchard                        There is a great need for environmental education and preservation of open areas for future generations. Therefore, the SBLP  process will support development work on a planned 15 acre sustainable agroforestry research and industrial center.The center will double as a "tinkering" field campus/learning center for science, arts, global studies, and engineering. Your "Named Orchard will be part our innovative pioneering projects. Make history with us! as we empower communities and create awareness for both school children and adults;local and international
Where your Money Will
Go:                              
Once the campaign is over, I'll secure all gift items and
copies of the books, and have them delivered to you. In the interim, I’ll use
the remainder of the money to help launch the organization. The money ( and any extra) will act
as seed funding, allowing all the pieces to fall into place for the
organization and proper design of the first project. At this point I can attract
funding from larger organizations that can help scale it up and eventually
become self-sufficient.
The cost breaks down are as follows:        Stipend for local workers: $500Start up operational costs and legal obligations : $3000Travel and Logistics: $1, 500 ( I'm happy to share that a  consulting firm dedicated to serving the food industry through science will be reducing our cost by collaborating with our local agriculture officers. Thank you Dr. Norei!!)Overhead: $500Total: $5,500                                                   The Impact- Our
work has two different kinds of impact. First, our process will prioritize
effective resource management methods, livelihood improvement strategies, and a
customized and culturally friendly sustainability certification process. 
                    Second, at SBLP Ghana, we believe that knowing each other on
a cultural level creates a sense of unity and understanding. Therefore, we use
a culturally friendly approach to learn about local business operational
processes, and also teach ways to customize and adapt them to globally accepted
ones. We believe that when we know more about and respect each others resources; the world is a safer, peaceful and beautiful place.
The Next Steps-This indiegogo project is only the beginning of what we plan to create. Our goal is
to initiate a series of innovative poverty alleviation and sustainable economic
alternatives which will harness the conscientiousness of individuals and
businesses concerned with ensuring responsible supply chain operations and
sourcing from Africa. 
Other Ways You Can Help- If you are not able to contribute financially, we appreciate every tweet, every post, and every action that increases awareness. You can use the brilliant indiegogo widgets or just mention it in passing to friends, family, and colleagues.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Francesca and I am a junior at The Academy at Charlemont. I want to build an outdoor cob oven to bring the community together over delicious food, while learning about sustainability in the process! Your donation will go to acquiring the materials for construction.

Once the oven is up and running, we can have all-school pizza nights where the whole community can come together to help prepare and consume delicious wood-fire pizzas (picture an autumn evening filled with good food and music).

 

What is a cob oven?

A cob oven is an outdoor, dome-shaped oven. They are constructed predominantly out of clay, sand, straw, and water. These earthen ovens can be used to make bread, pizza, and really anything else that can be baked. Not only do cob ovens produce delicious and healthy food, but they also are beneficial towards environmental sustainability, are inexpensive and fairly easy to construct, and can become strong community building hubs.

 

What makes a cob oven sustainable?

Most of the building supplies can be locally sourced, so as to limit the amount of fuel/emissions used in transport. In addition, cob ovens are wood-fired. This means no electricity or gas is needed. Because of the locally sourced, unprocessed materials, cob ovens have little impact on their surrounding environments. For example, when it rains, no chemicals will leach into the surrounding soil because all materials are natural and local. In addition, the unique shapes of the cob oven make it so it uses heat efficiently. This means it takes a small amount of wood to fire the oven. Therefore the environmental benefits outweigh the drawbacks of burning wood. Cob ovens are able to cook large amounts of food with minimal fuel.

 

The Construction Process

The construction process will take approximately four weeks before the oven will be operational. There will be only four full days of hands on work. These will be long, fun, and muddy summer days! During construction, the layers of cob will need to dry completely in order to proceed to the next step, so that's why the whole process will take around four weeks.  Additional students are invited to join in and help. After construction, the oven will last for approximately four years before needing any minor repairs.

 

How else can you help?

-If you would like to help with the construction, please contact me! I would love to have lots of helping hands/feet (you mix cob with with your feet!). The more the merrier. I will be building the oven over the summer. Please email me at: fruggiero@charlemont.org 

-If you have any extra: broken bricks, large stones, cow manure, or any other materials listed below that you would be willing to donate, please contact me! Donations of materials would be greatly appreciated. Please email me at: fruggiero@charlemont.org 

-Let other people know! Please tell your friends and family about the cob oven!

 

Detailed list of materials needed

Steel roof panel (for sheltering roof)

Wooden beams

Clay

Rough sand

Fine sand

Water

Stones

Broken bricks/busted concrete

Gravel

Broken bottles

Dry perlite

Firebricks

Plywood

Cardboard

1" shim sticks

Galvanized stove pipe

Newspaper

Fresh screened cow manure

Wheat waste

Cattail fluff

 

Detailed construction procedure

Building the sheltering roof

Digging a drainage trench- Measure a 58” diameter circle. Dig out the circle below the frost line (four feet deep). *Dig a drainage trench to reach daylight. Line this trench with gravel.*

Building the foundation- Build 36” foundation by dry stacking stones around the hole.  Fill the center with broken bricks and other scrap materials.

Insulating the  hearth- Mix up some cob by combining 2 parts sand, 1 part clay, and some straw on a tarp with feet. Add water to get the correct texture. Layer cob onto the filled hole and level to create an even and flat surface. Build a 4” cob wall surrounding the surface.

Building a firebrick hearth- lay out a thin bed of sifted sand for the firebricks. Line up and center four bricks for the door support on the edge of the hearth.  Place the rest of the fire bricks to cover the surface for the hearth with no space in between each brick.

Building a doorway template- The door opening will be 10” high and 13.5” wide. Cut out a plywood doorway template based on these dimensions. Trace the shape onto another piece of plywood and cut this piece out. Set the two cut out plywood pieces 8” apart and connect with two layers of cardboard to create a tunnel.  Set it up on the firebrick hearth on top of the 1” shim sticks on either side of the opening.

Making a cob arch- Mix up a sticky batch of cob to make the arch. To mix cob, use 2 parts sand, 1 part clay, some straw,  and water. Lay out a tarp and combine with feet until the mixture is cohesive. Layer it onto the arch evenly and in multiple layers.

Installing the chimney- Position the stove pipe in the center of the arch at least 1-2” from the dome side of the doorway opening. Use a level to make sure the pipe is level.

Making a sand form- Wet the sand down enough that it will stick together and is easily sculpted. Draw a 27” diameter circle on the firebrick hearth. Load sand onto the bricks. Shape the sand into a dome. The shape should be similar to that of an egg cut in half.  The peak of the dome should be about ⅓ in from the back of the dome. Mark 16” on a stick and insert into the place that will become the peak of the dome. Once the sand has reached that height, stop adding sand. Tear up pieces of newspaper, wet them, and lay them across the sand dome.

Building a cob dome- Make more cob. Gently layer the cob around the perimeter of the dome.  Build up the dome evenly. The cob should be equally thick across the dome. Let the cob dry for 1-2 days. Once the cob is firm, remove the doorway template and scoop the sand out.

Insulating with straw-clay mixture- Once the cob has fully dried mix straw and a chocolate milk consistency clay slip. Mix a large amount of this insulation. Pack the insulation onto the dome in thick layers.

Preparing the oven for “plaster”- Immediately after insulating the oven, apply a yogurt consistency clay slip to cover the entire straw insulation.

Applying the base coat of plaster- Immediately following the previous step,  apply the base coat of plaster. The plaster is a watery cob mix. Apply the mixture ½” thickness over the entire dome.

Applying finishing plaster- Mix sifted sand with screened clay on a clean tarp. Add in fresh screened cow manure, wheat waste and the fluff of 3-4 cattails.  Spread ¼” of plaster across the surface of the dome. Smooth with a plaster trowel, or insert colored glass to make a mosaic design on the oven.

 

Thank you so much!

story:
We are seeking funds to complete purchase of a 4.37-acre public floater's camp and riverfront park along the Jefferson River, near Three Forks, Montana.

Our organization, the Jefferson River Canoe Trail, is a chapter of the 501(c)3 nonprofit Lewis and Clark Trail Heritage Foundation. We are working towards establishing a network of eight public campsites along the Jefferson River segment of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. Three campsites already exist on BLM lands. This property will be number four.

Being close to the city of Three Forks, the property will be available as a walk-in riverfront park.

The total property purchase is $65,000. We have raised $20,000 so far and we have an agreement and financing to close on the property purchase on May 30th, 2014. We are seeking to raise an additional $20,000 through this campaign and the balance through grant applications and local fundraisers. Any surplus funds will be applied towards site management or the next campsite purchase.

The Jefferson is a great river with great scenery, abundant wildlife, great floating opportunities, and an essential stake in our nation's history.

Almost all land along the river is in private hands and development is encroaching everywhere. Yet amazingly, when you get into a canoe and experience the river from the viewpoint of Lewis and Clark, you discover how much the viewshed remains intact from the river. Most of the existing development is far enough back from the river that you only experience the cottonwood ecology along the river, against a backdrop of undeveloped mountains in the distance. Floaters can experience the Jefferson River much as Lewis and Clark found it 200 years ago.

We are working to make the Jefferson River corridor an experience that people can more fully appreciate. All that is needed is a few more good sites to allow floaters a quality place to get out and stretch their legs, have lunch, or stop and camp.

Help secure this property, and come experience your own Lewis and Clark adventure on the Jefferson River!

The property is located along Old Town Road  not far upstream from the confluence of the Jefferson, Madison, and Gallatin Rivers that together make up the headwaters of the Missouri River. The Jefferson River swings by the property just before passing under the bridge. Paddling up the nice backwater slough brings floaters to a perfect landing site and campsites hidden among the cottonwood trees.

Take a virtual tour of the Jefferson River Canoe Trail:


Check out the perks, and make a difference today!

story:
Building Leadership and Success within the Michigan LCV Education Fund 

Hello, my name is Erica Bloom, and I am the Program Manager for the Michigan League of Conservation Voters Education Fund. In my role as Program Manager I work with a diverse array of environmental and conservation organizations across the state to advance our priority issues in the state legislature and administration. 

I've started this fundraising campaign to raise $2,500 for the Education Fund's programs, specifically the ones I manage. As part of my own professional development  I am participating in the Environmental Leadership Program to become  a National Fellow. This program will allow me to become a more skillful, thoughtful and strategic Program Manager and environmental leader in my career. The money raised will go toward this Fellowship program and is considered an investment in me and therefore the Education Fund's programming. 

Here's a bit more about the MLCV Education Fund--

The Michigan League of Conservation Voters Education Fund is a 501(c3) organization that works in tandem with the Michigan League of Conservation Voters.  The Education Fund's mission is to provide voters and policy makers with the information and tools to protect Michigan's threatened natural resources. The Education Fund partners with members of Michigan's environmental and conservation community to determine legislative priorities in order to increase the salience of environmental issues in the legislative and administrative debate. 

Below is our Cycle of Accountability which illustrates how the organizations work together. 

The main program I run within the MLCV Education Fund is called "Great Michigan" and has a number of goals. The first is to convene the environmental and conservation community to determine a common agenda or, simply put, a short list of environmental issues and policy recommendations that state lawmakers consider the community's top priorities. These priorities become the main issues that MLCV Education Fund concentrates on for the legislative session (this year the issues relate to clean energy, public lands and water protection). 

Convening over 30 other groups to identify and collectively support priorities requires skillful relationship building and strategic decision making. The National Environmental Fellowship is a series of two retreats which train environmental leaders to negotiate and lead diverse coalitions. Participating in this Fellowship will only enhance my ability to facilitate this sort of coalition or any others like it.

Environmental and Conservation Organizations convene in Lansing for the "Great Michigan" Priority Setting Meeting

A second component of the "Great Michigan" program is to build the capacity of our environmental partners to advocate for the priority issues.  Through relationships made during the priority setting process, I am able to partner with the organizations and engage them in the state legislative process. For example, I organized a "Great Michigan" Legislative Education Day at the State Capital where many groups attended and discussed our priorities with their Representatives and Senators. 

In addition, I continually mobilize groups to meet with their legislators in their own communities through in-district coffee hours, I organize in-district Town Hall meetings, foster collaboration between our partner organizations, send out regular e-newsletters on priority issue progress, and, alongside my co-workers, hold webinar workshops on volunteer engagement, messaging strategies, and working with non-traditional allies. All these activities start to add up to a more informed, better organized and stronger environmental movement in Michigan.

 

 Our programs mobalize partner groups to meet with their State Representatives. Above, Anglers of AuSable board members meet with Rep. Rendon for in-district coffee hours to discuss fracking.

 

We educate Michigan citizens and voters on our why we need to fix our nation's toxic chemicals laws. Here my co-worker Melissa and I prepare for our first "toxics podcast."

In addition to coalition building, the Fellowship Program in which I am participating offers strategies for professionals on how to work with diverse constituencies, mobilize others to take action and gives space for personal reflection and evaluation of one's own leadership style. These training retreats as well as access to a personal coach point exactly back to the work I do on a daily basis, and will help me achieve greater success at activating a wide range of MLCV Education Fund's partners. 

Your Support Goes a Long Way.  

As I mentioned earlier, I am raising $2,500 to participate in the Fellowship Program. I have graciously been offered a nice scholarship from the Program itself, and funds from MLCV and I am looking to fill in the remaining gap. The money raised will go toward participating in the retreats, travel expenses to the retreats, access to a personal coach to develop my professional goals and a network of other emerging leaders. 

The beauty of this campaign is that you can support MLCV Education Fund's programs with a small donation knowing that  even a gift of $10 will go a long way of meeting our goals. Another perk is that your gift will be tax-deductible since you are giving to our 501(c3) organization. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute right now, that doesn't mean you still can't help. You can help get the word out about the campaign through your social media tools, and ask friends, family, or colleagues to contribute. However you choose to support MLCV Education Fund I, and the whole staff, thank you for your belief in our work and your belief in me as an environmental leader.

story:
Hello, 

My name is Jarred Johnson, and I'm currently fundraising for "Power Shift" as campus lead recruiter at University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB). My goal is to raise money to cover student's registration fees, and well as cover part of costs for travel expenses. I'm also currently interim president of environmental club "Green Initiative," so this is an excellent way to get students plugged into a huge movement, and have them ready and excited about coming back to their community in Birmingham, AL to make change in environmental issues and social justice issues.

The city of Birmingham is a heavily polluted area, and it also happens to be a "food desert." The pollution problems arise from heavy traffic, dust from industrial and construction sites, and smog from steel production. The food desert problem means that Birmingham is an area where fresh and organic food isn't readily and abundantly available for Birmingham citizens, and affects the food that students receive throughout the school system, from elementary school to colleges. The Magic City Agriculture Project (MCAP) is working to provide organic food for Birmingham, and already has an expanding program with members like myself. In this program, organic food workshops and farm-grown food are available, allowing people to purchase clean and GMO (Genetically Modified Organism) free food (http://www.southernfoodways.org/sustainable-south-magic-city-agriculture-project/). This replaces food that causes birth defects, cancer, and other GMO food related illnesses (http://responsibletechnology.org/health-risks). 

Where does Green Initiative come into the big picture? We are a organization on UAB's campus, seeking to educate young individuals on environmental justice, social justice, and help create leaders that will not only spread their knowledge, but advocate the drive to clean up Birmingham's pollution and related issues ( a brief look at Green Initiative is available here http://www.uab.edu/news/uab-magazine/item/2929-green-lantern-a-student-voice-for-sustainability). I've been involved with environmental justice since 2012 at Mississippi State University with SSC (Students for Sustainable Campus), and have met some of the most inspirational people I could ever hope to meet. Among these people, there are people that are striving to be psychologists, engineers, biologists, and other fields. My point? The major doesn't make the person, nor their beliefs. Environmental justice is extremely important, as the earth continues to deteriorate and be exploited for it's natural resources. Greed, corruption, and pollution are just the tip of the ice-burg (no pun intended). I've attended several workshops since then, and realized that I can make a difference, especially as an environmental issues. However, I find it very important to not be the engineer that only looks at pay, and is perfectly complacent with a decent paycheck and no community involvement. I'm now at UAB, and realize that I need to step up to the place, and help organize students interested in the environment, for not only our sake, but generations to come after us.  

So, what is Power Shift exactly? Here's my summary:

  • It's a 10,000+ youth gathering that will take place this year in *Pittsburgh, PA on October 18th-21st
  • At *Power Shift* you'll learn the skills and knowledge that you need to work together to organize and fight climate change on YOUR campus or YOUR community
  • There will be by seasoned, professional organizers. There will also be awesome keynote tons or organizing skills trainings and environmental issue workshops as well as speakers like *Bill McKibben* (350.org) and *Josh Fox* *(Gasland, Gasland II)
  • Website to Power Shift is available here: http://www.wearepowershift.org/about
 In all of this being said, it's one thing to talk about environmental change, and have meetings about having "meetings about environmental justice." I want to help others like-minded get registered for Power Shift (Which is currently $80 per person), and help them experience a strong youth driven environmental justice conference, network with people from all over the nation, and help them find opportunities for organizing and "green" jobs, which I'm very excited about! Please help me get college students to Pittsburgh, PA on  October 18th, and let them see that they can be a huge part of CHANGE!

Please help me get college students to Pittsburgh, PA on  October 18th, and let them see that they can be a huge part of CHANGE!

story:
Short Summary

On August 3rd, 2016 Libertad Urban Farm was burglarized and vandalized by one Rico Valdez. After being caught red handed by bat wielding Founder and Executive Director, Tanys Fields he was arrested and charged with Petty Larceny. 

Rico took all of our shovels, our rakes and hoes, two fully functioning wheelbarrows, knocked over our shed and effectively decimated it. He took eggplants and the Asian pears off the tree, he trampled and destroyed dozens of not yet ready to harvest onions. He got away with three tents, our large garbage pail, a set of 100 drill bits, 4 large folding tables, a large barrel charcoal grill, a 4 foot long cooler and a large gas pail. Amazingly, he was allowed to leave after his arraignment and a week late community members observed him burglarizing the space AGAIN! This time he took the few materials we had replaced. 

The dilapidated gate and destroyed shed have made Libertad Urban Farm an easy mark and in order to continue to do our work and provide the community with a much needed green community space we must get these things remedied. The literal future of our projects depend on it. This burglary has already set back our Buying Club a month. Libertad Urban Farm since it's inception two years ago after a six year community led campaign has hosted events that encourage civic engagement and discourse, grown hundreds of pounds of food and hosted  food education curbside popups on the South Bronx Mobile Market Bus. It has proven itself to be a much needed resource in the community and one Bad Apple (no pun intended) and poor secutity conditions shouldn't keep us from ending the season with a bang and planning an even more successful season next year and beyond. 

Your contribution will help us bypass much of the city bureaucracy  that has kept us from having a gate in functional condition including the inclusion of a retaining wall and getting a more appropriate heavy duty shed!

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least 7500 bucks and here's for what:

  1. Min. 3k to work with NYC Parks Dept's Greenthumb to get a retaining wall and have them install an 8 foot gate. They have been amazingly responsive and understand the need an urgency but budgeting constraints and overwhelming need from other community gardens limits their response time and how quickly this can happen. We needed a gate 2 years ago. 3K can get us a retaining wall and a gate in a few weeks!
  2. $2.5k for materials for a new shed. Eva Lucien a Union Member master builder has volunteered to come in with a team of kick butt student builders and build us a heavy duty, outdoor metal shed if we provide her with the materials. If we raise past our goal they'll even throw in a greenhouse! Whoop whoop!
  3. 1.2K will go towards wireless remote security cameras and motion sensor lights to deter wiuld be thieves who seek to steal from the community to keep their tookus' out of LUF and give us the ability to see what is happening in the garden in real time and institute some community policing protocols. 
  4. The leftovers will go to support programming like our cooking demos, workdays, intern stipends and movie nights. 

Th perks:

  1. Our undying gratitude!
  2. T-shirts
  3. Mugs
  4. Hot Sauce
  5. Tickets to Not Just Talk: #BLACKMAMAMAGIC

The Impact

  • We have turned a 20 year old lot into an open green space that welcomes community involvement and is led by the needs of the residents
  • We have hosted intergenerational work days, affirmed the humanity and worth of mothers, in particular Black low-income mothers, our model and methodology has emphasized self-sufficiency and economic inclusion over altruism and charity.
  • With that said we believe in a sliding scale buying model and sweat equity. No one is ever denied food from LUF (barring they don't scale our fence and take it under cover of night)
  • Our space is quickly becoming a space of radical resistance and ideology.
  • Last year we grew close to two hundred pounds of food and gave much of it away.

Risks & Challenges

  • The reality is no matter how many security measures we may NEVER be able to keep people from trespassing, We hope through these measures to decrease the likelihood. 
  • Even if we don't make our goal we will still use funds to replace tools and shed. That is a priority. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute a few coins there are other things you can do:

  1. Send the link around. Be sure to include your personal narrative as why your friends and family donating to us is important to you, it will increase the chances they will actually donate.
  2. Send us an email and come volunteer with us!
  3. Send us in-kind donations to:
    The BLK Projek
    C/O Mothers on the Move
    928 Intervale Ave
    Bronx, NY 10455 
  4. or send an actual check to our fiscal sponsor The Mary Mitchell Center (with The BLK Projek in the memo...that's important) to:
    The BLK Projek
    c/o The Mary Mitchell Center
    2007 Mapes Avenue
    Bronx, NY 10460

story:
Protecting an Iconic Species

Common Loons, an iconic species richly characterizing the waters and landscapes of the North Woods, have long been synonymous with true wilderness. As with other wildlife, their natural cycles and critical habitat often hang in the balance, susceptible to the footprint of consumption, a shrinking world, and climate change. 

News just broke confirming that the tropical disease avian malaria caused the death of a Common Loon in the Northeast.(See news reports here: https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/2016/04/06/... and http://bangordailynews.com/2016/04/08/outdoors/...).

Responding to the Challenge

Biodiversity Research Institute (BRI), a wildlife research nonprofit headquartered in Portland, Maine, in partnership with the Loon Preservation Committee (LPC) in Moultonborough, New Hampshire, is launching a Crowd Funding campaign to investigate the scope of this finding.

We are poised to undertake this investigation. In 2013, BRI’s Wildlife Health Program initiated an ongoing study that is examining some of the effects of climate change on loons. In addition, LPC recently launched an initiative to measure impacts of climate change on loons and the viability of New Hampshire’s loon population given predictions of increasing temperatures and precipitation, and has an established network of volunteers and staff monitoring lakes to be able to detect and transport loons for necropsy.

A changing environment brings increased risk of infectious disease for both humans and wildlife. Pathogens that are spread by mosquitoes such Zika virus, malaria, Eastern Equine Encephalitis (EEE), and West Nile Virus are just a few of the diseases that are becoming a greater concern for both people and animals. At a time of unprecedented environmental change, this work is more urgent than ever.

Emerging diseases require rapid deployment to obtain time-sensitive samples, and traditional funding sources are slow in response. Our ability to make a difference depends on immediate action and private funding. 

Mobilizing a Team

Our Institute aims to mobilize wildlife veterinarians, loon biologists, and concerned citizens in an effort to understand the scope of this finding, which not only affects loons, but other wildlife and human populations as well. 

How You Can Help

  • Donate here to help defray the costs of our urgent field and lab research
  • Volunteer time to help monitor loons in the field (these birds are now arriving at their breeding grounds on Northeast lakes)
  • Spread the word about this campaign to fund critical research that affects all of us 

A successful $30,000 campaign will cover the costs of loon monitoring, comprehensive health assessment and disease surveillance of live loons, supplies and travel costs for field biologists, and examination of deceased loons in BRI’s Wildlife Health and Pathology Lab and the New Hampshire Veterinary Diagnostic Lab.

Grassroots efforts, such as this initiative, are critical as governmental agencies have fewer and more limited resources in proportion to the number of ecological stressors and challenges we face in today’s world. Every contribution, large or small, matters!

BRI’s Immediate Action Plan to Help the Loons

1) Responding to Sick/Deceased Loons
BRI is joining forces with the Loon Preservation Committee in New Hampshire to perform a rapid assessment of known loon territories and identify sick or dying loons, dovetailing with existing monitoring efforts. 

To maximize coverage throughout the Northeast, BRI and LPC are working with the Northeast Loon Study Working Group (NELSWG), whose participating organizations can survey large areas of the loon's breeding range in northeastern North America.

We will launch a public awareness campaign from May through August 2016 to encourage reports of loons exhibiting some or all of the following behaviors and symptoms: (1) excessive preening; (2) listing to one side while on water; and (3) beaching activity.  

BRI’s Wildlife Health and Pathology Lab will perform most of the necropsy examinations on deceased loons, partnering with the University of New Hampshire’s Veterinary Diagnostic Lab to perform advanced testing. Vital information gained through necropsy examination can help guide conservation efforts, disease surveillance, and future research. 

2) Increased Disease Surveillance in Live Loons
BRI and LPC will work together to study loon health in the Northeast, increasing surveillance of mosquito-borne diseases among wild loons. We will analyze loon blood samples for malaria and other blood parasites; we will also send samples to the Maine Vector-borne Disease Laboratory for viral surveillance. In addition, we will analyze samples to assess the overall health status of the region's loons and determine how loon health is influenced by a changing environment. 

To Report Sick or Deceased Loons - Contact:

  • In Maine: Maine Audubon- 
    • 207-781-2330
  • In Massachusetts: Biodiversity Research Institute – 207-839-7600
  • In New York: BRI’s Adirondack Center for Loon Conservation – 
    888-749-5666 x145
  • In New Hampshire: Loon Preservation Committee – 603-476-5666
  • In Vermont: Vermont Center for Ecostudies – 802-649-1431
For More Information, Visit:
www.briloon.org/crowdfunding/avianmalaria

story:
About Us

Lake Ontario Waterkeeper is a registered charity working to ensure your water is clean and wild enough to swim, drink, and fish. Water should be free from pollution - and if it’s not, the people dunking, dipping, and diving have a right to know.

The Plan

So here’s our plan. The Waterkeeper team will bring our boat, Angus Bruce, to Toronto this summer.  We will sample the 25 most popular recreation zones on the waterfront. And you will finally know if water quality in our beautiful harbour meets government standards.

The Problem

But we need your help. Our boat, Angus needs a few repairs - the main one is a new roof to keep out the rain, so we can sample when pollution is at its worst. Then we need money for gas and lab testing. If you can help us raise $5000, we can get Angus to Toronto to test the waters. 

There are 9 combined sewage outfalls in the Toronto Harbour. And there are two wastewater treatment plants that also bypass sewage into the lake. However, 97% of Toronto's waterfront is not monitored -  100% of the Toronto Harbour is not monitored. No government monitoring means that there is no water quality information. Compare this with the fact that Toronto has one of the busiest recreational harbours in North America. People are swimming, paddling, sailing and boating in the water without knowing the quality of the water. This is a huge problem - and because of this lack of information, this summer 36,000 Ontarian's will develop a rash or become ill after swimming in polluted water.

Impact

With our sampling we will finally know if the water in Toronto's harbour meets government standards. 

Water sampling won’t solve Toronto’s sewage and stormwater pollution problem for good, but it will ensure people can safely enjoy Toronto's waters in the meantime.

Risks & Challenges

Some water quality information is better than no water quality information. While we hope to achieve our full goal of $5000 to accomplish our full set of testing - if we don't reach our full goal we still commit to conducting water quality testing in the Toronto Harbour's most threatened sites. But, the more we raise, the more testing we can do and the clearer picture we'll have of Toronto's water quality.

Other Ways to Help

If you can't contribute to the campaign financially, sharing our message with your network of friends and family is still huge help!

Suggested Social Media Shares:

Help make Lake Ontario #swimdrinkfish-able. @LOWaterkeeper just launched a crowd-funding campaign on Indiegogo  https://igg.me/at/swimmablelakeontario

This summer @LOWaterkeeper wants to sample the TO harbour's water. How to help: https://igg.me/at/swimmablelakeontario #swimdrinkfish

97% of Toronto's waterfront is not monitored & 100% of the Toronto Harbour is not monitored. People are swimming, paddling, sailing and boating in the water without knowing the quality of the water. To change that, this summer Lake Ontario Waterkeeper wants to sample the harbour. But they need your help. Check out their just launched a crowd-funding campaign on Indiegogo. Go to https://igg.me/at/swimmablelakeontario to help make Lake Ontario swimmable, drinkable, fishable.

How to help: https://igg.me/at/swimmablelakeontario #swimdrinkfish97% of Toronto's waterfront is not monitored & 100% of the Toronto Harbour is not monitored. People are swimming, paddling, sailing and boating in the water without knowing the quality of the water. To change that, this summer Lake Ontario Waterkeeper wants to sample the harbour. But they need your help. Check out their just launched a crowd-funding campaign on Indiegogo. Go to https://igg.me/at/swimmablelakeontario to help make Lake Ontario swimmable, drinkable, fishable.

story:
HI EVERYONE! CIAO A TUTTI!

 

la spiegazione italiana su streetitalia.it ---> chiediamo un piccolo contributo, di qualsiasi taglia, per dimostrarci il tuo appoggio in questa impresa!

RICORDA CHE PUò ESSERE TUTTO ANONIMO, SE NON VUOI APPARIRE!

 

Our project is called sTreet, and we believe that it could modify the concept of urban renewal in Italy and around the world. The project aim is to increase tree patrimony in any city, introducing one or more trees using the software we are creating.

We can see hundreds of empty spaces in our cities that could be simply filled with trees instead of concrete or buildings! We want to create this instrument, with whom, introducing trees can get really easy. 

We believe in our project and in the benefits it could bring to our lives. We will make it because we’re sure it's practical and innovative.

  • who are we?

We are Martina and Maddalena and we are italian. We have two different kinds of bachelor, Agronomy and Architecture and we met at the University of Florence during our master in landscape Architecture. We are guerilla gardeners!

 We'd love to see people having more care of their cities, living them as it was their own home.

  • our campaign.

The our idea is simple: plant as more trees as possible in our cities.

We will give the tools to make it real through the use of a software that will simplify tree planting. We believe that trees are the solution for many illnesses of our times: environmental, social, economical and aesthetical.

Please help us because if you take care of your community trees, trees will take care of your community!

  • We need of your support to reach the goal for our project!

We need 6000$ to do many things!

  • We must pay the guy who's helping us making the software,
  • we need to buy new computers because ours are quite old and had tough life during university exams!
  • we need to improve our web site (www.streetitalia.it),
  • we must pay all the trips we need to meet and work together (Skype is cool but not enough)
  • we need to go to updating conferences about urban planning and arboriculture
  • and obviously we need a little bit of advertising for sTreet project.

Did you know you can gauge the country’s wealth, by its tree cover?! Think about it, won't you prefer greener cities, trees to watch, to lie under, instead of grey concrete or ANOTHER building??

If (unfortunately) we won't reach the goal we will use the money we managed to get to cover smaller costs (web site, some job trips) in order to continue searching for partners interested in our project. People who believed in us will obviously receive their marvelous perks! 

  • PERKS

Every single person can contribute to help us making sTreet real, because even a few dollars can make the difference.

THANK YOU so much for your support!

  • The Impact

We really think this project is worth trying! With our software everyone will tell which kind of trees goes in that specific area. It's something technical but even social. People need trees, but someone don't even know yet! It could be a method to learn more about trees too! Not everybody knows how useful urban trees are: they improve health, save energy, clean the air, reduce temperatures, and counteract our polluting lifestyles!

We are already working on sTreet software, to make planting easier, but we need funds to make it usable and concrete!

  • HOW WILL IT WORK? The planner simply inputs the necessary information, and sTREEt suggests the tree unit that best fits the available space. It will speed up and simplify the technical aspects of urban upgrade. This tree unit includes species, number of trees, distances and everything you'll need to plant your tree without worries.

STREET will help improve the quality of air and life. The benefits it will bring to the environment, the people and the buyers will be tangible and verifiable.Just think of all the small (but even big) empty spaces in our towns, or in our gardens:

 

 

Thanks to sTreet, planting we'll get really simple! STreet will give you all the information for a urban project containing as many trees as possible. Urban renowal can be fast and simple if you know how to do it!

Everyone can simulate (and then realize!) a recovery in the empty space he identified.

Street means to shorten the time for urban design.

 

 

 

  • Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you really can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help us! Talk about sTreet, make noise, let other people know about our idea! Use any share tool you can!

 

Thanks a lot to everyone. Martina & Maddalena

story:
The Morse Wildlife Preserve is a Unique Place for People and Animals

The 98-acre Morse Wildlife Preserve is a mosaic of conifer forest, wetlands, oak savanna and prairie. It is an ideal home for many bird species such as owls, raptors, aquatic fowl and the uncommon western bluebird. Mammals such as deer, coyote, bobcat, rabbits and a variety of rodents live here or make foraging visits. The Preserve was created in 1995 to permanently protect critical wildlife habitat and serve as an educational center for students and the broader community.

Built circa 1910, the barn at Morse Wildlife Preserve is listed on the Washington State Historic Barn Register and the Pierce County Historic Landmarks Register. It is the centerpiece to the education program at the Preserve. It not only provides shelter from the weather for visiting school children, but also a location for storytelling and educational displays as well as storage for tools and materials used by the Morse Force volunteers for restoration projects. 

The Barn Needs Our Help!

Unfortunately, the entire barn had to be closed to visitors in 2011 due to safety concerns with the shed roof, which covers the entrance to the barn. We are working to fund construction of Phase I of a three phase project to fully restore the historic barn to the standards of the Historic Barn Register, which includes mandatory use of costly cedar shake roof tiles. Phase I restoration to replace the west shed roof will cost $8,500. Forterra received a $5,000 grant from Pierce County to help fund the project. The grant funding expires at the end of September, which means we need to complete Phase I THIS summer.

Without YOUR support this historic building will be lost as a critical centerpiece shelter for our ongoing community and youth education at this beautiful nature preserve.

Thank you!

story:
Our Story

~Coastal youth coming together to celebrate their land and say NO to tankers~

After two incredible experiences in the Great Bear Rainforest, and learning about the threats of an oil spill on the BC coast, Magdalena and a team or university students are organizing a paddle to protest the proposed Enbridge pipeline. The group, along with youth from the Gitga'at community of Hartley Bay, will come together on a four day canoe journey in BC's Great Bear Rainforest, to celebrate the region and to say NO to oil supertankers. Through fundrasing events, concerts, documentary screenings and presentations, the GBR Youth Paddle aims to raise awareness about the potential threat of an oil spill and to engage youth to take action and to promote a sustainable future.

 

My Background:

My name is Magdalena Angel, and currently I am a student at Quest University Canada, located in Squamish BC. In 2009, I went to the Great Bear Rainforest for the first time with the Ecology class from Quest University. During this experience, our group stayed in Hartley Bay with the Gitgaâ€™at First Nations, where the community shared with us their culture and traditions. The leaders of the community also taught us about the issues that the community has faced, such as the sinking of the ferry Queen of the North in March of 2006, and its effects on the surrounding water. We also learned about the biggest threat to the Gitgaâ€™atâ€™s way of life, Enbridgeâ€™s Northern Gateway Project.

During my time in Hartley Bay, I learned about the Gitga'at's culture and traditions. I also, saw the incredible beauty and wildlife of the surrounding natural environment. This was a very powerful experience for me. As a result, in 2010 I took the opportunity to volunteer at Cetacealab, located on Gil Island in Gitgaâ€™at territory. I worked with Hermann Meuter and Janey Wray, two whale researchers, who established themselves here nine years ago. I helped collect data for their ongoing research of whale populations. Working here exposed me to the pressing issue and risks of having oil tankers traveling through the Great Bear Rainforest. By spending more time up here I had the chance, again, to reconnect with the unique and amazing environment as well as the great people who live and work there.

During the past year, Norm Hannâ€™s StandUp4GreatBear paddle and Frank Wolf and Todd McGowanâ€™s On the Line project have inspired me to take action and find a way to help keep this Northern Gateway Project from happening.

 

The Project

From these experiences, I have grown fond of the Hartley Bay community and I am concerned for the future of what lies ahead and along this coastline. I want to support the First Nations communities, the environmental groups and people of the coast who are working hard to preserve the culture and the integrity of this beautiful area. For this reason, I am organizing the Great Bear Rainforest Youth Paddle (GBR Youth Paddle). This four day canoe journey will take place in the Gitgaâ€™at territory and will involve youth from this community and from the Quest community. These two groups will set off from the community of Hartley Bay and end at Kiel, the communityâ€™s Spring Camp, a culturally and historically significant site.

This paddle will raise awareness and encourage youth in both the Gitgaâ€™at and the Quest communities to work together and take action. The paddle will give youth the opportunity to visit culturally significant areas and spend time with elders in their community who can share the importance of such places, and why it is crucial to protect them. The paddle will also focus on giving youth a voice in this battle to protect their lands and water and would promote the stewardship in individuals. Quest students have built a relationship with Hartley Bay over the past two years and many are interested and exited to work to preserve the Great Bear Rainforest and to supporting the First Nations groups.

I am passionate and excited to organize this journey and contribute to the growing campaign against the Enbridge project. I am asking for your support of this project to help make this canoe journey successful in June 2012.


learn more at www.gbryouthpaddle.org

The Impact

The issue of building an oil pipeline across two provinces that would pose the risk of an oil spill through First Nations territories, the beautiful Great Bear Rainforest, and the BC coast, is not only an issue about building an oil pipeline. The issue with the Enbridge pipeline is that by allowing projects like this to go through, Canada commits to continue the expansion of the Tar Sands, and continue its ever-growing fossil fuel emissions. By allowing the Enbridge Pipeline to go through, Canada will not take a stand for social justice and environmental justice, nor will our government prove its commitment to long term goals that will benefit future generations. Instead, the project will put the BC province at risk of disaster, seeing that the potential of an oil spill will be larger than the well-documented Exxon Valdez spill.


By participating in this paddle, we aim to raise awareness about the Northern Gateway Pipeline Project proposed. We want to educate others about the environmental and cultural impact the proposed pipeline will have on the ecology of this region, as well as First Nations groups, coastal citizens, and future generations. Through presentations at high schools, our university, and public venues we hope to educate the public on these type of environmental and social impacts, and we want to promote long term thinking to keep the future in mind.

What We Need & What You Get

The total amount of money our campaign is aiming to raise is $25,088. This money will go towards the cost of transportation and food for all participants travelling to Hartley Bay where the trip will begin. In addition, these funds will pay for a documentary film maker to capture our journey, and show the importance of this region to others. For your donation, there are many perks you can receive, ranging from pins and T-shirts to posters depicting our paddle logo, and personal acknowledgement!!  


Other Ways You Can Help

To learn more about the proposed pipeline and what our paddle aims to accomplish, you can visit our website at www.gbryouthpaddle.org Please LIKE our facebook page to stay tooned in to future awareness and fundraising events http://www.facebook.com/#!/pages/Great-Bear-Rainforest-Youth-Paddle/201111416621815. 

On our website, you can learn more about the proposed pipeline project and its impact on the region. Here you can watch videos, such as the documentary "spOIL", in order to view firsthand the pristine environment of the region and see why we need to work together to prevent the disruption and possibility of an oil spill posed by the Enbridge Pipeline project. If you have any questions please e-mail us at gbryouthpaddle@gmail.com. Please share this campaign with anyone and everyone you know!

story:
Respond & Rebuild is a disaster response team formed in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy to work with families in devastated areas of NYC for safe returns to their flood damaged homes.  Since the day after Sandy struck the East Coast, we’ve been in the field, working with volunteer teams and donated tools to pump water out of homes, remove debris, and gut the damaged first floors of hundreds of homes in Rockaway, New York. 

Now, potentially toxic mold is posing a huge public health risk in the area, and our next and most urgent phase of work is to perform free mold treatments on as many of these affected families’ homes as possible.  

From our experience working in the Gulf Coast after Hurricane Katrina, we know firsthand what a health crisis mold can become if not treated swiftly and effectively.

We have a proven process and the infrastructure to implement it. Time is critical. We need tools and supplies. With your help, we can get 250 families back into healthy homes this winter!

We’re a group of six friends with over 30 cumulative years in disaster response–from hurricanes to earthquakes, from wildfires to Haiti’s cholera outbreak. 

When Superstorm Sandy tore across the east coast on October 29, 2012, we reached for our backpacks, pulled out some tools and made our ways to New York. Within 24 hours we had found our way onto the storm ravaged streets of Rockaway. The scene was reminiscent of another time in our lives when we first met, almost three years ago in the aftermath of the most devastating earthquake Haiti had ever seen.  That was October 30th.  We've all been here since.   

Gathering as many tool donations as we could and teaming up with Occupy Sandy to expand our reach, we've spent the last month and a half working in over 100 homes, while regularly logging over 1800 volunteer hours a week. 

In addition, we also do as much community education on mold, renter's rights, insurance protocols, and FEMA assistance as possible. We offer more than just physical help; we offer an organized and long-term support system for people in the community. The recovery effort in the Rockaways will be a long one, and with your support, we’ll be here to see it through. 

Many people in the Rockaways lost so much when Sandy hit. 

A 12 ft storm surge flooded the basement and first floor of almost every home on the peninsula.  Now, six weeks after the storm, 12,000 families are still displaced from their flood-damaged homes and unable to return for the holidays.  

  • Mold is taking over those wet homes at an alarming rate. 
  • Short term exposure to some types of mold can cause illness.
  • Long term exposure can cause chronic disease and even death. 
  • Until the mold can be cleaned and removed, homes are simply not safe for residents to return to. 
  • Homes left untreated will not be livable for much longer.

 

For around $1,000 per home we can obtain all the supplies we'll need to fully treat and de-mold a house so families can start planning their moves back in. 

We do all this free of cost to residents–many of whom have been quoted upwards of $15,000 for the same treatments from bigger companies.  

We’ve cut those costs using donated supplies and a volunteer labor force and can only continue to expand our efforts with your support.  Our work helps the Rockaway community build back faster, and with a method trusted by experts we’ve consulted to develop our service.  In addition, we offer trainings to Sandy-affected residents so they can take charge of the recovery process on their own, share information among neighbors, and stay informed.

In order to perform a typical mold remediation, our volunteer crews wear protective coveralls, goggles, respirators, gloves and boots to keep safe.  Our method includes commercial mold killer, wire brushes, angle grinders, HEPA vacuums, and most costly, industrial strength dehumidifiers and heaters.  

The list of supplies we need is long, but the list of homeowners who need these services is even longer.    

 

The aftermath of catastrophes like this are heartbreaking, but the response we’ve seen from neighbors, New Yorkers, and the many people from as far away as Michigan, Alaska, and even Belgium who have dropped everything to be part of this relief effort amazes us every day. It’s been organic, exciting, grassroots, and beautiful. Being a part of this effort so close to home has, for many of us, changed what it means to be a part of our communities.

We’ve done more than clean out homes.  Together with residents, community members, seasoned relief workers, and devoted volunteers, we have all built a people-powered coalition that continues to grow both a wider reach and deeper roots each day. And our sights are set on the long haul.

We want to see people in Rockaway return to their homes in the coming months, and we’re committed to being part of that process.  We are neighbors training neighbors to help neighbors.  And no matter how far away you live, we want you all to be a part of this.  Along the way with this campaign, we can’t wait to share our progress, as well as personal experiences and the stories of the community that we’ve become so involved in over the past 44 days. 

The progress we’ve made with volunteers and donated tools since the storm is amazing. In the weeks and months ahead, we know that with your support we can grow that progress exponentially. Our work speaks for itself. Help us to continue it.

Donate. Volunteer. Spread the word. Respond. Rebuild.

**PLEASE NOTE:  Our fiscal sponsor, TRIPLE R PETS, is accepting donations on our behalf so that your contributions can be tax deductible.  Rest assured that all money donated through this IndieGoGo campaign goes directly to Respond & Rebuild and the Rockaway residents we are working with.**

When Superstorm Sandy tore across the east coast on October 29, 2012, we reached for our backpacks, pulled out some tools and made our ways to New York. Within 24 hours we had found our way onto the storm ravaged streets of Rockaway. The scene was reminiscent of another time in our lives when we first met, almost three years ago in the aftermath of the most devastating earthquake Haiti had ever seen.  That was October 30th.  We've all been here since.   
Gathering as many tool donations as we could and teaming up with Occupy Sandy to expand our reach, we've spent the last month and a half working in over 100 homes, while regularly logging over 1800 volunteer hours a week. 
In addition, we also do as much community education on mold, renter's rights, insurance protocols, and FEMA assistance as possible. We offer more than just physical help; we offer an organized and long-term support system for people in the community. The recovery effort in the Rockaways will be a long one, and with your support, we’ll be here to see it through. 
Many people in the Rockaways lost so much when Sandy hit. 
A 12 ft storm surge flooded the basement and first floor of almost every home on the peninsula.  Now, six weeks after the storm, 12,000 families are still displaced from their flood-damaged homes and unable to return for the holidays.  

Mold is taking over those wet homes at an alarming rate. 
Short term exposure to some types of mold can cause illness.
Long term exposure can cause chronic disease and even death. 
Until the mold can be cleaned and removed, homes are simply not safe for residents to return to. 
Homes left untreated will not be livable for much longer.
 
For around $1,000 per home we can obtain all the supplies we'll need to fully treat and de-mold a house so families can start planning their moves back in. 
We do all this free of cost to residents–many of whom have been quoted upwards of $15,000 for the same treatments from bigger companies.  
We’ve cut those costs using donated supplies and a volunteer labor force and can only continue to expand our efforts with your support.  Our work helps the Rockaway community build back faster, and with a method trusted by experts we’ve consulted to develop our service.  In addition, we offer trainings to Sandy-affected residents so they can take charge of the recovery process on their own, share information among neighbors, and stay informed.
In order to perform a typical mold remediation, our volunteer crews wear protective coveralls, goggles, respirators, gloves and boots to keep safe.  Our method includes commercial mold killer, wire brushes, angle grinders, HEPA vacuums, and most costly, industrial strength dehumidifiers and heaters.  
The list of supplies we need is long, but the list of homeowners who need these services is even longer.    
 
The aftermath of catastrophes like this are heartbreaking, but the response we’ve seen from neighbors, New Yorkers, and the many people from as far away as Michigan, Alaska, and even Belgium who have dropped everything to be part of this relief effort amazes us every day. It’s been organic, exciting, grassroots, and beautiful. Being a part of this effort so close to home has, for many of us, changed what it means to be a part of our communities.
We’ve done more than clean out homes.  Together with residents, community members, seasoned relief workers, and devoted volunteers, we have all built a people-powered coalition that continues to grow both a wider reach and deeper roots each day. And our sights are set on the long haul.
We want to see people in Rockaway return to their homes in the coming months, and we’re committed to being part of that process.  We are neighbors training neighbors to help neighbors.  And no matter how far away you live, we want you all to be a part of this.  Along the way with this campaign, we can’t wait to share our progress, as well as personal experiences and the stories of the community that we’ve become so involved in over the past 44 days. 
The progress we’ve made with volunteers and donated tools since the storm is amazing. In the weeks and months ahead, we know that with your support we can grow that progress exponentially. Our work speaks for itself. Help us to continue it.
Donate. Volunteer. Spread the word. Respond. Rebuild.
**PLEASE NOTE:  Our fiscal sponsor, TRIPLE R PETS, is accepting donations on our behalf so that your contributions can be tax deductible.  Rest assured that all money donated through this IndieGoGo campaign goes directly to Respond & Rebuild and the Rockaway residents we are working with.**

story:
Our Mission:

Cape Fear Environmental Film Forum is a non-profit event that aims to offer grass-roots solutions to environmental challenges by presenting environmentally themed documentaries and galvanizing conversation between filmmakers, panels of local advocates and audience members in order to bring about action at the local level. The Forum is open to the public and entry is free.

Background:

CFEFF has hosted films and panelists in a 175 seat theater on the University of North Carolina Wilmington campus since 2012. In addition to showing recently released environmental documentaries in a theatrical setting, CFEFF has also hosted works-in-progress screenings and offered documentary filmmaking workshops to area middle school students who screen their own short documentaries at the event.

What can you do?

The funds raised will help offset the cost of securing a community screening license for each of the films. Our hope is that Indiegogo will not only help with screening fees, but will also aid in our efforts to promote the Forum throughout the region.

story:
Short Summary

My name is John Groth, known by many as "LJ."  I have been traveling to work on and to enjoy Chile's beautiful rivers since 2005.  For years I worked as a river guide in the tourist hub of Pucon, but in 2012 I began my own guide service in the nearby mountain village of Curarrehue, called by the pristine nature of its river valleys and by the deep roots of the native culture.  Upon moving to Curarrehue, I was made aware of an ongoing struggle the local people are faced with as foreign investors continue to target the region for its natural resources.  This area is under great threat of invasion and environmental destruction (i.e., dams, mines, deforestation) in the name of economic progress, and the world needs to know. Due to the mining industry's growing need for energy, hydroelectric power production is a hot topic, and every last one of Chile's many streams and rivers are at risk.  Why should a small, rural community dependent on these free-flowing rivers in the South of the nation be divided/sacrificed for the growth of an industry that needs to bring the energy over 2000km to the North?

Each red dot shown on this map is a river whose rights have been sold to private parties for hydroelectric projects; the pink dots for fish farms, notorious for their negative environmental impact.  by Fede Medina

One of the best ways to educate and to motivate people to act is to bring them together in the very place that needs their help. This way we can all feel the powerful energy of the river and the trees and the mountains, and we can take that sensation with us in order bring a passionate message to the world, "Let the rivers run free." 

(Site of PuescoFest 2014)

By donating to PuescoFest, you will help us to create a revolutionary event designed not for profit but for conservation and real, jubilant celebration of nature and culture. By supporting this type of intercultural exchange, you will help to raise awareness about the environmental threats to a rural community that does not have the resources to fight against multinational corporations alone.

This festival, PuescoFest, will be happening from the 21st-23rd of November 2014. The goal of PuescoFest is to celebrate free flowing rivers. We want people of all cultures (indigenous, Chilean, foreign, kayakers and non-kayakers) to share the majestic beauty of the Puesco valley. We want people to feel free like the river - free to converse, free to float, free to make music and free to dance to it, free to fight for what they love. 

The event will feature:

  • Documentary Film Presentations
  • Kayak Races for Experts and Novice paddlers on one of Chile's most picturesque rivers
  • Local artisan crafts, food and art
  • Native Mapuche ceremony offering respect to the mountains and rivers
  • FREE LIVE MUSIC from Aflora, Newen Afrobeat & guests
  • Presentations about environmental threats to the area and discussion of paths to action

Tell your friends and make your plans now!!!

Aflora LIVE!!!

What We Need & What You Get

Because of the generous support of Northwest River Supplies, we have a solid base to work with in our mission to make this festival a reality.  Our goal is to provide the music and kayak racing events free of charge because we want this to be accessible to all, and because we want this to be about saving the rivers, not about making profit.

We still need to raise more funds for the promotion of the event, production of the show (sound and lighting) and for transportation/food/lodging for the musicians.  We would also like to be able to invite more musicians to celebrate with us and to help with our mission to raise consciousness.

At this point, each and every additional dollar will go towards the local conservation groups and to the community of musicians and whitewater racers and river enthusiasts who will make this event so special. 

The Impact

Not only will we kayak and dance and raise awareness, we will educate people about how they can use the democratic process to act against these corporate, for-profit ventures which put their forests, mountains and rivers at risk.

The campaign against HydroAysen (the damming of large rivers in the Chilean Patagonia) was successful because of community involvement led by groups like Patagonia Sin Represas (Patagonia Without Dams).  As they were presented with information, people were inspired to speak out and to act on their desires to conserve the free flowing rivers of Chile and the world.  This type of community event can be the spark to ignite a fire of consciousness and activism.

As we are removing dams here in the US, developing nations like Chile are building new ones.  We need to remind the world that nature is sacred, and we must do whatever we can to conserve and protect those places that are yet to be destroyed by human greed. 

Risks & Challenges

This event is going to happen no matter what.  We are willing to take a personal financial risk to fund this project, but your support will help to make an even greater impact. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't afford to travel to Chile or if you can't afford to support it financially, you can definitely help to spread the word about the event and this fundraising campaign by using social media and the Indiegogo share tools. 

    Tell your friends to come to the event!  Send us your love and your good vibrations!

story:
Our Story


WE GOT INTO SUNDANCE! We need to complete this film by January! Give us a helping hand so we can make it to the dance on time!

From Oscar-nominated filmmaker Mark Kitchell comes A Fierce Green Fire, the most comprehensive exploration of the environmental movement ever put on film. Ten years in the making, it tells the story about the people that arose to fight for change. It focuses on grassroots and global activism, spanning fifty years worldwide. It focuses on people fighting to save their children, their land, their living planet; from halting dams at the Grand Canyon to battling 20,000 tons of toxic waste at Love Canal; from Greenpeace saving the whales to Chico Mendes and the rubbertappers saving the Amazon; from global activism to address climate change to the promise of transforming our civilization. Neither gloom and doom nor panacea, the film points towards reckoning and renewal, humanity learning to live in sustainable balance with the natural world that supports us.

Join us in bringing the film home! We've shot all of our interviews and gathered all of our archival material. We finished writing and editing a rough-cut last year. Earlier this year, thanks to a grant from Sundance, we began a fine-cut. It's a great time to get on board and see the film through the final phase of production, so our Sundance screening is a smashing success!


The Impact

This final push is the culmination of a lot of work by a lot of people - not in the least, a director at the helm of a ship that has been at sea for over ten years. We're going to Sundance come hell or high water and will need all the help we can get. This is a pivotal moment for us - come help us make it to Sundance on time! These environmental issues affect us all and we can't wait to get this film out into the world and start the community outreach that will accompany it. The first step in this is a successful Sundance premiere and we can't get there without your help!


What We Need & What You Get

There are two things at the end of a production that help a film come together and feel like "a film" - sound and picture. We're asking for $12k to pay for our sound mix (a discounted rate of 8k) and color timing (again, we've negotiated a fantastic deal of 4k). This helps the film coalesce and helps people focus on the meat and issues of the film and not get distracted by shots that don't match or sound cues that get in the way.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you could share this with your friends and family we would be so grateful. Please get this page out there to everyone you have ever met and can possibly think of!

story:
Short Summary

Going Native Ranch was founded by Armed Forces veterans that desired to get youth involved in the outdoors to reduce crime recidivism.  Becoming a social entrepreneur, the founder after serving in several countries became interested in Operations Other Than War and Humanitarian Aide missions.  The conservation program addresses the need for biomass increase and reducing the carbon footprint to create a quality of life initiative. Contributors will help GNR achieve various goals such as an educational blueprint for poverty stricken areas, forest establishment and certification,  and soil improvement efforts to produce organic farming serving the local population.   

What We Need & What You Get

With great innovation comes great trials.  GNR purchased a  2013 Kubota tractor which was stolen from a neighboring military installation's storage facility at Fort Gordon adjacent to Augusta GA.  This is a major hurdle to overcome and no one has yet been arrested.  Our commitment still moves us toward meeting and overcoming any obstacles we encounter leading us to undertake all planting and ground cultivation either by hand or at the expense of renting equipment.  Your funds will be used to replace equipment and  installing fencing.  There are multiple camping sites on the 97 acre masterpiece that we are looking to develop for use in youth initiatives and as training sites for so called at-risk youth.  We believe with quality guidance, No Child Is Left Behind.  We live up to our motto, "Each One Teach One".  So far we have attracted some wildlife for photography only; as we want to conserve nature and develop the inner self to become a good steward of the land.  We have also stocked two 3 acre ponds with various fish and started an orchard and drip irrigation. At night you can see a peaceful sky and hear all that nature offers.

    The Impact 

    This project is just the beginning but offers life and rewarding benefits.  Your contributions Saves!  It saves the lives of those who are less fortunate that travel down a dark road and traumatic end and  it saves the lives of animals being hunted for pleasure and greed.  In all my years I have seen hunger throughout the different countries that I have been deployed to including but not limited to Somalia, Afghanistan and the Middle East.  We cannot fail again to conserve our resources, educate children and live a eco-friendly lifestyle.  GNR stands behind that 100%.    

     

    Risks & Challenges

    There are always risks but with spirit and motivation they become less.  Because we are a small group our way to achieve these goals is through volunteering opportunities.  Volunteers and other agencies working cheerfully will generate a peaceful and educational opportunity for our youth to explore.  When they grow and prosper, we become a better community and nation as a whole. 

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that some cannot help financially, but please tell your friends, families and organizations about this campaign through Indiegogo.  We value their support and expertises.
