story:
About Me   

I have been a firefighter with the US Forest Service for the past 10 years .  As a smokejumper and Hotshot I have been able to work with incredibly talented people all around the US who enjoy working hard, accomplishing difficult tasks and having a good time no matter what challenges may face them.  It is a tough job with long hours, hazardous conditions and constantly changing environments.  Recognizing the potential for firefighter skills to be an asset in accomplishing difficult goals, I started Bushfire Bros (www.bushfirebros.org) in 2013 with the purpose of connecting firefighters to worldwide projects with unique needs.

About this Campaign

For several years I have been involved with the wildlife conservation organization, Pandrillus (www.pandrillus.org), and have travelled to Nigeria and Cameroon four times to assist in their projects.  Pandrillus has been active in these countries for over 25 years and has been instrumental in wildlife and forest conservation, habitat restoration, community education and sustainable development in all the areas where they operate.  Although they originated as a primate conservation organization to rescue, rehabilitate and release the highly endangered drill monkey, through the passion of the directors and staff, they have grown into a major voice for conservation in the region and have garnered both governmental support and international acclaim.

  Currently Pandrillus is on the verge of completing two monumental goals.  First, is the unprecedented release of 150 rescued and captive bred drill monkeys into Afi Mountain Wildlife Sanctuary (a Pandrillus inspired collaboration with the Nigerian government) and secondly, the completion of the Nigerian Chimpanzee Center (NCC), the largest natural forest enclosure for rescued chimpanzees in the world.  These projects are located in Cross River State, SE Nigeria in one of the last remnants of rainforest in this region.  Conservation here also protects the critically endangered Cross River gorilla, Nigerian chimpanzee and a host of other rare forest plants and animals.  Pandrillus works intensively with the local communities, providing job opportunity, education and commerce to create a rare partnership in conservation and local development.

Purpose of Funds

Pandrillus is in immediate need for volunteers to trek through the rugged rainforest mountains to follow the released drills and conduct wildlife and habitat surveys.  We want to send three firefighters to Nigeria to act as primary wildlife trackers and to educate on fire safety, prevention and responsible forestry.  Additionally firefighters will assist in operations throughout the project including wildlife rescue/rehabilitation, maintenance and construction and organization.

What We Need

This fundraising is purely to cover the cost of travel from the US to Nigeria.

Cost breakdown:

  • Flight (USA-Nigeria): $1100, round-trip
  • Flight (Lagos, Nigeria - Calabar, Nigeria): $200, round-trip
  • Travel Health Insurance: $40
  • Nigerian Visa for US citizen: $160
  • Total: $1500 per person (x3 = $4500)

 

If we do not meet our goal of $4500 for the three volunteers, then we will send the most qualified individual with the money we have raised.

If we exceed our goal, we can send more people and contribute to support costs of field teams!

The Impact

  This project is unprecedented in conservation.  Drill monkeys, a critical species for rainforest plant dispersal, are one of the most endangered primates in Africa and notoriously hard to breed in captivity.  After two decades of rescue, rehabilitation and social integration, the captive groups in Pandrillus have had more reproductive success than any other primate conservation project in history and currently consist of roughly 10% of all drills, wild and captive, in the entire world! 

The release of a large group of drills into a protected sanctuary will be a huge boost to dwindling wild populations, create more genetic diversity in isolated populations and serve as a model for reintroductions in other areas where drills once lived.

The conservation of drills and their habitat is hugely important as it results in the protection of a multitude of other species and environments.  Drills share their habitat with two other extremely rare primates, the Cross River Gorilla and the Nigerian Chimpanzee.  The very presence of trackers and rangers on the mountain will keep these and other species safer from poachers and illegal loggers. 

This last remnant of Nigerian rainforest is both a refuge for wildlife and a beacon of hope for a more sustainable future in the region.  Recent localized environmental disasters have made it clear to the people of the area that the forest cannot survive without the animals and the people cannot survive without the forest so a balance must be maintained.  Pandrillus has worked tirelessly with local communities to promote sustainability in the region and encourage innovative solutions to economic and social challenges.

Risks & Challenges

  International travel itself always carries some risks but the nature of this project carries some additional challenges.  The physical demands of moving through the jungle is no small thing and even the local rangers (who will be working side by side with tracking teams) often come out of the bush a few pounds lighter from patrols!  Map and radio skills are essential for off-trail foot travel and communication with base camp, backcountry medical skills are critical for unforeseen emergencies and a willingness to sleep outside in a tent for an extended period in a place with bugs, hot days and cold nights, and occasional downpours (it is a rainforest) are to be expected.

  Working with rangers, local community members and other volunteers can present other unique challenges and having a team structure with strong leadership is important to maintain group cohesion and allow for success.

  These challenges are exactly why US wildland firefighters are uniquely qualified for this task.  Working in small groups, often with different individuals from fire to fire, all firefighters must develop skills for success, specifically leadership, diplomacy and positive attitudes.  The physical requirements of trekking through the mountainous jungle is similar to the demands of fighting fires.  Long days and nights with conditions ranging from freezing rain to hundred degree temperatures (sometimes on the same fire!), hordes of biting insects and miles of hiking and working all with 50+ pound packs is a standard summer for a Forest Service firefighter.  Technical skills including radio operations, orienteering and tool use are also mandatory for firefighters.

  Aside from tracking wildlife through the mountains, the firefighter team will provide valuable expertise and services at the 640 acre Drill Ranch bush site and assist with forest conservation, fire protection, education, wildlife rescue and construction projects.

Other Ways You Can Help

  Please share our campaign with others; the more people who are aware of the challenges for projects like Pandrillus, the more opportunities we have to make a real difference!

If you would like to learn more about Pandrillus, drill monkeys or conservation in Nigeria or Cameroon, take a look at these links:

www.pandrillus.org

Facebook page

 Limbe Wildlife Center

Bushfire Bros also supports other projects around the world by sending skilled volunteers to projects with unique needs.  If you would like to see our site and contribute to sending volunteers to a different project, please visit us!

Bushfire Bros website

 Thanks for taking the time to view this campaign!
story_txt:
About Me    I have been a firefighter with the US Forest Service for the past 10 years .  As a smokejumper and Hotshot I have been able to work with incredibly talented people all around the US who enjoy working hard, accomplishing difficult tasks and having a good time no matter what challenges may face them.  It is a tough job with long hours, hazardous conditions and constantly changing environments.  Recognizing the potential for firefighter skills to be an asset in accomplishing difficult goals, I started Bushfire Bros (www.bushfirebros.org) in 2013 with the purpose of connecting firefighters to worldwide projects with unique needs.About this CampaignFor several years I have been involved with the wildlife conservation organization, Pandrillus (www.pandrillus.org), and have travelled to Nigeria and Cameroon four times to assist in their projects.  Pandrillus has been active in these countries for over 25 years and has been instrumental in wildlife and forest conservation, habitat restoration, community education and sustainable development in all the areas where they operate.  Although they originated as a primate conservation organization to rescue, rehabilitate and release the highly endangered drill monkey, through the passion of the directors and staff, they have grown into a major voice for conservation in the region and have garnered both governmental support and international acclaim.  Currently Pandrillus is on the verge of completing two monumental goals.  First, is the unprecedented release of 150 rescued and captive bred drill monkeys into Afi Mountain Wildlife Sanctuary (a Pandrillus inspired collaboration with the Nigerian government) and secondly, the completion of the Nigerian Chimpanzee Center (NCC), the largest natural forest enclosure for rescued chimpanzees in the world.  These projects are located in Cross River State, SE Nigeria in one of the last remnants of rainforest in this region.  Conservation here also protects the critically endangered Cross River gorilla, Nigerian chimpanzee and a host of other rare forest plants and animals.  Pandrillus works intensively with the local communities, providing job opportunity, education and commerce to create a rare partnership in conservation and local development.Purpose of FundsPandrillus is in immediate need for volunteers to trek through the rugged rainforest mountains to follow the released drills and conduct wildlife and habitat surveys.  We want to send three firefighters to Nigeria to act as primary wildlife trackers and to educate on fire safety, prevention and responsible forestry.  Additionally firefighters will assist in operations throughout the project including wildlife rescue/rehabilitation, maintenance and construction and organization.  What We Need This fundraising is purely to cover the cost of travel from the US to Nigeria.
Cost breakdown:

Flight (USA-Nigeria): $1100, round-trip

Flight (Lagos, Nigeria - Calabar, Nigeria): $200, round-trip

Travel Health Insurance: $40

Nigerian Visa for US citizen: $160

Total: $1500 per person (x3 = $4500)

 
If we do not meet our goal of $4500 for the three volunteers, then we will send the most qualified individual with the money we have raised.
If we exceed our goal, we can send more people and contribute to support costs of field teams!

The Impact  This project is unprecedented in conservation.  Drill monkeys, a critical species for rainforest plant dispersal, are one of the most endangered primates in Africa and notoriously hard to breed in captivity.  After two decades of rescue, rehabilitation and social integration, the captive groups in Pandrillus have had more reproductive success than any other primate conservation project in history and currently consist of roughly 10% of all drills, wild and captive, in the entire world!  The release of a large group of drills into a protected sanctuary will be a huge boost to dwindling wild populations, create more genetic diversity in isolated populations and serve as a model for reintroductions in other areas where drills once lived.The conservation of drills and their habitat is hugely important as it results in the protection of a multitude of other species and environments.  Drills share their habitat with two other extremely rare primates, the Cross River Gorilla and the Nigerian Chimpanzee.  The very presence of trackers and rangers on the mountain will keep these and other species safer from poachers and illegal loggers.  This last remnant of Nigerian rainforest is both a refuge for wildlife and a beacon of hope for a more sustainable future in the region.  Recent localized environmental disasters have made it clear to the people of the area that the forest cannot survive without the animals and the people cannot survive without the forest so a balance must be maintained.  Pandrillus has worked tirelessly with local communities to promote sustainability in the region and encourage innovative solutions to economic and social challenges.Risks & Challenges  International travel itself always carries some risks but the nature of this project carries some additional challenges.  The physical demands of moving through the jungle is no small thing and even the local rangers (who will be working side by side with tracking teams) often come out of the bush a few pounds lighter from patrols!  Map and radio skills are essential for off-trail foot travel and communication with base camp, backcountry medical skills are critical for unforeseen emergencies and a willingness to sleep outside in a tent for an extended period in a place with bugs, hot days and cold nights, and occasional downpours (it is a rainforest) are to be expected.  Working with rangers, local community members and other volunteers can present other unique challenges and having a team structure with strong leadership is important to maintain group cohesion and allow for success.  These challenges are exactly why US wildland firefighters are uniquely qualified for this task.  Working in small groups, often with different individuals from fire to fire, all firefighters must develop skills for success, specifically leadership, diplomacy and positive attitudes.  The physical requirements of trekking through the mountainous jungle is similar to the demands of fighting fires.  Long days and nights with conditions ranging from freezing rain to hundred degree temperatures (sometimes on the same fire!), hordes of biting insects and miles of hiking and working all with 50+ pound packs is a standard summer for a Forest Service firefighter.  Technical skills including radio operations, orienteering and tool use are also mandatory for firefighters.  Aside from tracking wildlife through the mountains, the firefighter team will provide valuable expertise and services at the 640 acre Drill Ranch bush site and assist with forest conservation, fire protection, education, wildlife rescue and construction projects.  Other Ways You Can Help  Please share our campaign with others; the more people who are aware of the challenges for projects like Pandrillus, the more opportunities we have to make a real difference!If you would like to learn more about Pandrillus, drill monkeys or conservation in Nigeria or Cameroon, take a look at these links:www.pandrillus.orgFacebook page Limbe Wildlife CenterBushfire Bros also supports other projects around the world by sending skilled volunteers to projects with unique needs.  If you would like to see our site and contribute to sending volunteers to a different project, please visit us!Bushfire Bros website Thanks for taking the time to view this campaign!

story:
We are 3dtotal, a creative and trailblazing publisher of high-quality art, craft, and sustainable-living books. One year ago we had an idea, to see if a group of the world’s top artists could create a single collaborative art piece, that could be sold and enjoyed by many, with all of the profits going to protect and save the rainforests. After many months of hard work, we would like to present Earth Draw, an artistic fundraising campaign through which all profits go to the innovative rainforest charity Cool Earth.

 

 

As part of this campaign, five extremely talented artists, Lois van Baarle, Tran Nguyen, Yuumei Wenqing Yan, Kerby Rosanes, and Audra Auclair, will each complete a section of artwork to create a limited edition piece. This is an exclusive print that will only be available to purchase through this campaign in November.

 

 

We are so grateful for the hard work and enthusiasm that these artists have put into supporting this project and fantastic cause. Without their help, this wouldn't have been possible. Thank you!

 

 

There are 4 perks available, with 3 named after the portion of forest your pledge could protect.

 

 

The £20 (1/4 of an acre) reward is a high-quality, limited edition print featuring the collaborative artwork of the amazing artists supporting this project.

The £34 (1/2 an acre) reward features the same artwork, but will also include your name, along with the names of other backers of this reward, printed in a clear gloss around the world.

The £67 (1 acre) reward offers the same poster, but features your name, along with the names of other backers of this reward, in gold foil as well as featuring further gold details added to the print.

 

 

 

Hopefully the campaign will be supported by many backers, which will mean there are a lot of names to appear on the 1/2 acre and 1 acre prints. If this is the case, we will divide the names across multiple prints in that category in order to maintain an appealing aesthetic. You will receive the print featuring your name.

The printing company that we have chosen to work with, Gomer Press, is certified with the Forest Stewardship Council and their paper is universally sourced from sustainable forests.

 

 

We are partnering with Cool Earth, the non-profit organisation that works alongside rainforest communities to halt deforestation and its impact on climate change. Cool Earth are able to protect one acre of rainforest for just £60, so with your help we hope to be able to save hundreds, or even thousands, of acres of rainforest with this project.

“With half of the world’s rainforest lost over the past forty years, we need a new approach to conservation.The only way to halt destruction is to align the future of the rainforest with the people best placed to protect it. This means placing forest in the hands of the people who rely on its survival for their survival.” – Cool Earth

 

 

There will be some unavoidable fulfilment costs involved, but the artists and the 3dtotal team are working on this project as a not-for-profit so the majority of all proceeds can be donated to help save the rainforests. Product packaging is included in the shipping costs

 

 

The above breakdown of funds illustrates how much we can give from each sale if we print 1000 posters. We want to go beyond this though, as the more prints we produce the less each one will cost to manufacture, which will in turn mean we can give more of your pledge to Cool Earth.

 

 

To help promote the campaign and encourage the support of the artistic community 3dtotal have started a month long art challenge. We have set 30 themes which participants can use to inspire an original piece of art. We then encourage people to share their art online using the hash tag #EarthDraw2018. With each image shared we ask artists to mention and share our campaign, so the art community can come together to make a positive change on the environment.

 

We hope you'll consider supporting our mission to create art to create change!

 

Thank you very much!

The 3dtotal team

story:
A Natural Wonder

Majestic and practically untouched, Bristol Bay, Alaska provides spawning grounds for half of the world’s wild sockeye salmon. With sustainable commercial fishing providing thousands of jobs, world-class waters for anglers, and many Alaska Native villages still living subsistence lifestyles, salmon are deeply intertwined in the region's culture and economy.

Given massive discoveries of gold and copper deep below the surface of Bristol Bay’s headwaters, a foreign mining conglomerate called the Pebble Partnership plans to build North America's largest open pit mine. Should toxic mining waste from the Pebble Mine find its way into the watershed, the effects would prove catastrophic to salmon and the entire ecosystem.

As a group of anglers, educators, conservationists, and dreamers, we’re not going to let that happen. With your help, we're going to pass legislation that will prevent the Pebble Mine, or any large-scale open pit mine, from ever harming the salmon of Bristol Bay.



BRISTOL BAY

A unique and pristine ecosystem unlike any other in the world, Bristol Bay rests along the southwest coast of Alaska. This expansive watershed is home to at least 29 fish species, 40 terrestrial mammals, and more than 190 different birds.

Biologists consider the stream and river waters of Bristol Bay exceptionally pure. Low sediment levels mean you can see to the bottom at even the deepest parts. Add high oxygen levels and a steady water flow, and you have the perfect salmon habitat.


A KEYSTONE SPECIES

As they make their journey from the ocean to their spawning grounds, salmon deliver a critical source of nutrients to animal and plant life in the region. At least 138 different species in the watershed rely on salmon as an essential source for protein, Omega 3's, and other nutrients—making salmon a keystone species.



A TASTY MEAL

Bristol Bay accounts for 46% of the world's wild sockeye salmon with an average of 37.5 million fish returning to spawn each year. As 51% of wild sockeye consumed in the US comes from Bristol Bay, it's pretty darn likely that the salmon dinner you enjoyed last month came from here.



Wrong Mine,
Wrong Place

THE MINE

Over the course of 78 years, the Pebble Partnership plans to create an open pit mine nearly a mile deep and three miles wide. The pebble deposit is estimated to hold between $300 and $500 billion in mineral resources and will produce 10.8 billion tons of mining waste. That's the equivalent of 3,000 lbs. of waste for every single human on earth!



ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT

Because of its toxicity, mining waste must be stored and monitored “in perpetuity”—i.e. forever. Current plans will house Pebble’s waste behind multiple 700 ft. tall earthen tailings dams. Should this harmful waste leak or get released into the watershed, it would cause irreversible and permanent damage to the surrounding ecosystem.

The sad truth is that open-pit mining has a history of spills, leaks, and accidents. Given the almost unfathomable scale of the Pebble Mine and plans to build it in a wetland environment, it’s hard to imagine leaks won’t occur. The fact that Alaska sits on the Pacific “Ring of Fire” and experiences significant seismic activity doesn’t help much either.

To find their spawning grounds, salmon rely on a highly keen sense of smell. Exposure to even trace amounts of copper or other toxic chemicals could impair a salmon's sense of smell and therefore disrupt their ability to find the streams and tributaries where they hatched and where they will in turn, spawn themselves. History and science have both proven that salmon are highly vulnerable to even small changes in water quality.

Economic &
Cultural Value

COMMERCIAL FISHING

With access to the largest wild sockeye salmon fishery in the world and the most valuable in Alaska, Bristol Bay's commercial fleet has operated since 1884. Working with wildlife biologists and Alaska’s Department of Fish and Game, fishermen catch a sustainable amount of salmon, ensuring enough make it to the spawning headwaters to continue the cycle.

ALASKA NATIVES

Alaska Natives have called Bristol Bay home for over 4,000 years. Living subsistence lifestyles, Alaska Natives not only consider salmon part of their cultural and traditional heritage, but rely on them as a major food source. To this day, salmon still provide food security in 25 of the 31 villages in the region.

RECREATIONAL & SPORT ANGLING

With more than 40 commercial fishing lodges along Bristol Bay tributaries, anglers from all over the world come to fish some of North America’s richest and most productive waters. Their sport helps drive a strong recreation and tourism industry year after year.


State-Based Solution

THE BRISTOL BAY FOREVER INITIATIVE

In 1972, the Alaska Legislature enacted AS 38.05.140(f), establishing the Bristol Bay Fisheries Reserve and providing protection for salmon populations against potential harm from oil and gas development. Unfortunately the law did not include mining operations... until now.

The Bristol Bay Forever Initiative will amend the existing law and ensure “large-scale metallic sulfide mining operation(s) will not constitute danger to the fishery within the Bristol Bay Fisheries Reserve." This standard of no “danger to the fishery” will apply not only to the Pebble Mine, but to any potential large-scale sulfide mine in the Reserve.

The Bristol Bay Forever initiative will ensure that “large-scale metallic sulfide mining operation(s) will not constitute danger to the fishery within the Bristol Bay Fisheries Reserve." This standard of no “danger to the fishery” will apply not only to the Pebble Mine, but to any potential large-scale metallic sulfide mine in the region.

A state-based strategy written by an experienced team of professionals with extensive backgrounds in Alaska law and Alaska politics, the Bristol Bay Forever Initiative establishes a long term precedent of protecting Bristol Bay's salmon.


CHALLENGES

  • Alaska has historically embraced mining operations. No single mine which has applied for a permit has ever been denied.
  • The Pebble Partnership is well funded and has used its resources to influence local, state, and federal government agencies.
  • We anticipate the Pebble Partnership will do everything in their power to defeat the Initiative.




EPA ACTION

This past February, the United States Environmental Protection Agency announced they were initiating a process under the Clean Water Act “to identify appropriate options to protect the world’s largest sockeye salmon fishery in Bristol Bay.”

While the EPA’s response to the requests of local tribal groups and hundreds of thousands of US citizens is taking steps towards protecting Bristol Bay, it’s not enough. In a state built on self-reliance and a spirit deeply connected to the land, it’s incredibly important for Alaskans to control their own fate. Passing the Initiative ensures the Alaska Legislature gains oversight of major mining operations like Pebble.


Facts to consider:

  • A number of steps must occur before the EPA decides whether or not to block the mine. This process will likely take a year or more to complete.
  • Several political leaders in Alaska and Washington D.C. have publicly called a preemptive veto of the mine “extreme federal overreach.”
  • The EPA has initiated a review process under the Clean Water Act 29 times in history. They’ve issued restrictions in 12 of those cases and have only prohibited one project that had not yet applied for a dredge-and-fill permit. Pebble would be the second… ever.
  • If carried through, there’s no guarantee this decision won’t be overturned by future EPA Administrators (who typically change with each new presidential administration).


Only time will tell what actions the EPA might take. One thing is for sure, we cannot afford to just stand on the sidelines and watch the process unfold.


FOR ALASKA, BY ALASKA

On November 4th, 2014 the Bristol Bay Forever Initiative will appear on the Alaska ballot. If passed, it grants the Alaska Legislature authority to determine the fate of any large-scale mine in the Reserve without the influence of the federal government. It will hold potential mining operations to the highest standard and it will ensure Alaskan oversight over an Alaskan treasure.

Independent scientific studies all conclude the Pebble Mine poses far too large a threat to the salmon, the people of Bristol Bay, and the region’s incredibly rich biodiversity. Failure to protect this pristine resource is not an option.

Please join our ranks and share this story today.



MONEY RAISED

Funds raised go directly to Bristol Bay Forever Inc. and will be spent on TV spots, print ads, door-to-door campaigns, and everything else that goes into passing a citizen-based initiative. Once fully aware, educated, and inspired to vote, we are confident an overwhelming majority of Alaskans will do their part when the time comes.

ABOUT US

We're a small group of individuals acting on behalf of Bristol Bay Forever Inc., a non-profit 501(c)(6) organization whose sole purpose is to pass the Initiative. After researching the Pebble Mine and realizing the harm it could bring to such an incredible resource, we decided to take a stance and educate others who might not otherwise be aware. Plus we enjoy eating wild salmon too.

SPECIAL THANKS

Pat Clayton,  Photography

LEARN MORE

story:
My name is Hayley.

I am a young 20-something with a passion. I am passionate about protecting the environment. And finally, my dream has arrived! Greenpeace accepted me into their school!

In school with Greenpeace, I will learn how to go about getting a community aware and involved about the issues they face. I will learn how to bring people together to bring change. I'm so excited about the things that we can fix in the future!

By you contributing to help me, you're helping make my dreams of protecting the planet that much easier.

What I Need & What You Get

Tuition cost: $4200 + living expenses for 3 months

Any and all help is so appreciated. I'll be working hard in the meanwhile to come up with what I can but any help I can get will go straight into the tuition savings fund!

The Impact

I want to do everything I can to keep the world healthy and our outlook positive for a bright future. Please help me help future generations! This program specifically shows empassioned people how to empower their campaings and causes within their own communities and elsewhere.

Other Ways You Can Help

If some folks out there just can't contribute but still want to help, please:

Use the Indiegogo share tools! Post this on your twitter, facebook, tumblr, whatever!

If you know of anyone who may be interested in helping, please message them this link: www.indiegogo.com/hayleylickstrees

 

;) Have an amazing day and take care.

THANK YOU!

 

So excited,
Hayley
story_txt:
My name is Hayley.
I am a young 20-something with a passion. I am passionate about protecting the environment. And finally, my dream has arrived! Greenpeace accepted me into their school!
In school with Greenpeace, I will learn how to go about getting a community aware and involved about the issues they face. I will learn how to bring people together to bring change. I'm so excited about the things that we can fix in the future!
By you contributing to help me, you're helping make my dreams of protecting the planet that much easier.


What I Need & What You Get
Tuition cost: $4200 + living expenses for 3 months
Any and all help is so appreciated. I'll be working hard in the meanwhile to come up with what I can but any help I can get will go straight into the tuition savings fund!


The Impact
I want to do everything I can to keep the world healthy and our outlook positive for a bright future. Please help me help future generations! This program specifically shows empassioned people how to empower their campaings and causes within their own communities and elsewhere.


Other Ways You Can Help
If some folks out there just can't contribute but still want to help, please:
Use the Indiegogo share tools! Post this on your twitter, facebook, tumblr, whatever!
If you know of anyone who may be interested in helping, please message them this link: www.indiegogo.com/hayleylickstrees
 
;) Have an amazing day and take care.
THANK YOU!
 
So excited,Hayley

story:
THE PROJECT:

Winter Social Forestry Camp is a group of twelve humans coming from a diversity of backgrounds - permaculturalists, environmental activists, botanists and ecologists, organizers, herbalists, educators, artists, healers, and sacred hoop walkers.  We have come together through various networks and communities to co-create WinterCamp in the Little Applegate Valley of southern Oregon.

WinterCamp is an experiment in regenerative wildtending, where we will explore what it means for a community of people to restore a landscape while living in reciprocal relationship to nature. Camped out in a temporary village in the woods for five weeks, we’ll work on improving the ecological quality of the landscape, with a focus on tending wild plants that provide sustenance as food, medicine, timber, and craft material.

We approach the work from the perspective that humans are interconnected and vital link in functioning ecosystems, and that our presence living in the wild is not detrimental, but in fact can be beneficial to the diversity of plants and animals that surround us. 

Winter Campers will utilize a variety of management strategies and techniques including fuel load reduction, habitat creation, release of heritage hardwoods, restoration of disturbed areas, invasive species management, carbon sequestration, and data collection & record keeping.

In addition to stewarding the land, we will be hard at work back at camp exploring the cultural aspect of rewilding, learning to be together in community, and to make beauty with our hands to sustain ourselves from the land – processing wild food and medicine, weaving baskets, transforming roadkill into food and crafts and tools, building round-pole structures from forest products, and much more!

OUR VISION:  

WinterCamp provides a bridge from our broken culture back to the earth, a step on our path of reconnecting human beings to our place as part of a functioning regenerative ecosystem. We are seeking a way of life connected to each other and that innately affirms our part in nature. We seek to reshape the economic relationship of how we see the earth and our relationship to her.

WinterCamp is a seed that we hope will germinate towards building semi-nomadic Regenerative Tending Cooperatives that work on long term stewardship contracts on private and public lands and comprise a large mutual aid support network between land projects.  The Cooperatives will help facilitate ecological diversity and fecundity to wildlands while also nourishing and supporting the communities of human beings who tend those lands. 

We've garnered spirit and momentum through teachings of Traditional Ecological Knowledge and Wisdom, the ecological restoration movement, earth ancestral skills movements, and from fervent whispers by mentors Finisia Medrano and Hazel (a.k.a. Tom Ward, of Siskiyou Permaculture). We have grown from previous grassroots-organized community projects in rewilding, such as the RogueAbout, Camas Camp, Root Camp, Pine Nut Camp, Queer Forestry Camp, Free Cascadia Witchcamp, and more. We are nourished by our dear friends and mentors who have come before us and continue to hold us close, providing us with fertile earth from which to sprout.  

WHAT WE NEED:  

While many incredible restoration and rewilding projects currently exist, as far as we know, our project is unique in these ways: it is the seed for the creation of an economically viable culture and lifeway for rewilders; we are documenting and monitoring our work so that we can share our results; and we are deeply committed to sharing our knowledge through public outreach and education, building a bridge from rewilders to the greater community.

We really need your support to get WinterCamp off of the ground.

While each winter camper is contributing significantly to cover our personal food and living costs, your generous donations will help us cover additional expenses for the purchase of infrastructure we will be able to use ongoingly in future rewilding projects. We need to purchase equipment to set up scientific monitoring plots, hand tools for forestry work, medical supplies, kitchen equipment, and more!

Any contribution helps.

We thank you from our hearts for helping us build the vision, and for believing in the possibility of a future where humans live in reciprocal, regenerative relationship with the land and each other.

(Note: All donors will receive periodic updates from WinterCamp, with photos and highlights from our journey!) 

Wintercamper Racoon tending oak woodlands through fire, Winter 2013

Bounty of one day's wild harvest, Root Camp 2013

story:
Every morning, we wake up and the ocean is there, surrounding our island. But now the ocean, driven by climate change is creeping ever closer. Unless something changes, many of our Pacific Islands face losing everything to sea level rise.

For 20 years we’ve asked world leaders to take action to stop polluting the atmosphere. We cannot wait longer. Now, warriors of the Pacific are rising peacefully to protect the Pacific Islands from climate change. 
Our message: We are not drowning. We are fighting.

Next month, we’re standing up to those blocking action on climate change. Pacific Climate Warriors will journey to Australia, where we will use traditional canoes to peacefully lay down a challenge to the fossil fuel industry. On October 17 the canoes will serve as a symbol of our threatened cultures, and will lead a flotilla in the world’s largest coal port - Newcastle. The flotilla will be a direct, peaceful action where we stand up together to say we will not let the fossil fuel industry continue the destruction of our homes.

We must act now to protect our culture, our land and our oceans, and we need people all around the world to stand with us. Make us powerful in this fight, by chipping into our Pacific Warriors crowdfunder.


Who we are

Five years ago, our network of young Pacific Islanders began to form under the name of 350 Pacific, to join with the global climate change movement, 350.org. Active in 15 of the Pacific Island Nations, we have a unique approach of empowering young people to understand the issue of climate change and to take action to protect and enrich our islands, cultures, and oceans.

We know that this project is beyond what we can deliver on our own. We don’t have big bank accounts, big funders, or big email lists. That’s why we’re asking the international community to stand in support with the Pacific Warriors.

What we do have is the network of courageous young Pacific Islanders – from Niue to Tuvalu – that have been learning the skills of canoe building from their elders, are clued up about how climate change is affecting their Islands, and are ready to stand up peacefully but powerfully as warriors for their Islands. 


The Pacific Warrior Journey

As Pacific Warriors we will journey to Australia to stand up to the fossil fuel industry in person and demand they stop their radical plans that are destroying our island homes. We will travel the country, bringing our story of struggle directly to the Australian people and make a call-to-arms, a request that Australians take up the fight to the fossil fuel industry to save our homelands. We will use traditional hand-made canoes to paddle out into the harbour of the world’s largest coal port - Newcastle - to stop coal exports for a day.

We will use these canoes to lay down a challenge to the fossil fuel industry, and to highlight what we will lose if their reckless contribution to climate change continues. This will be a means of telling the industry, the Australian public, their Government, and the global community that climate change is having a real impact and is threatening the culture, health and environment of our Pacific Islands.

We know that many Australians are ready to stand with us. As we arrive, Australians around the country have already pledged to join our flotilla, to attend our talks and stand in solidarity because our fight is their fight too. From those fighting against the construction of new coal mines at Maules Creek and in the Galilee Basin, to those working on essential policy changes, Australians will collectively stand up to say “we will not let our neighbours drown.”

This is a huge undertaking. Building and transporting canoes and at least 30 Pacific Warriors all costs a lot. We can’t do it without you!


Where the money goes

Every dollar donated goes straight to the costs of shipping the canoes, and the journey for the warriors to Australia. Our teams in the Islands have been fundraising locally to build the canoes. We need to reach the full target to have all our warriors and canoes represented on the journey.

Any amount from $20 to $20,000 will be hugely appreciated. The more we raise, the bigger impact we can have!


How climate change is impacting our islands

The Pacific Islands are already witnessing the effects of climate change. A majority are dependent on subsistence agriculture, but with more intense tropical cyclones, flash floods and droughts, food production systems are increasingly vulnerable. Coastal systems and ecosystems are already adversely affected, with erosion impacting in places like the Marshall Islands, Tuvalu, Tokelau and Kiribati. Coral reefs and water resources are also now at risk, and scientists have warned that if the world doesn’t change track now, we face losing much more.

The Pacific Islands are already world leaders in looking to renewable energy - countries like Tokelau are 100% powered by solar energy. Pacific Islanders are working very hard to reduce greenhouse gas emissions - however small we may be. 

Yet many of the countries most responsible for climate change are doing next to nothing to curb emissions. In fact, Australia has recently approved a huge expansion of its coal and gas exports at a time when we are on the edge of climate disaster. The recently federally approved Carmichael Mine not only requires dredging of the Great Barrier Reef, the destruction of over 10,000 hectares housing multiple endangered species, but alongside the other 8 proposed megamines in the Galilee Basin, will burn through 5% of the world’s carbon budget – from one basin in Queensland alone! These exports already operate on a scale that is almost unimaginable.

All this coal and gas will have a devastating impact on the Pacific Islands.
Find out more about the Pacific Climate Warrior campaign by visiting the website here.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Peggy Hiers. Im a student at Florida International University in Miami, Fl. working toward a bachelor's degree who is thrilled about an opportunity to volunteer and help an environment in need. The International Student Volunteers organization has accepted my application to go to Australia this summer for 4 weeks where I will volunteer on a conservation project. Most of the projects involve habitat restoration and are geared toward the protection and rehabilitation of the environments in which Australia's unique animals live.

Unfortunately, students accepted to volunteer abroad with ISV must pay their own way.  Indiegogo is one of the recommended ways to raise funds for the trip.  If I can raise the needed funds, I will not only be able to make a difference in the world, I will be able to show the volunteer experience on resumes and applications for scholarships and internships. The most rewarding part however would be the opportunity to help the environment and the animals who depend on that environment to survive.

 

What We Need & What You Get

My program costs include my accommodations, most meals, project materials and support, ground transportation, and tour guidance in Australia. These costs will directly help me gain more knowledge and help with conservation efforts. You are making a direct contribution for conservation. The program cost is about $5,000. I have saved about $1,500 on my own, but I need your help! All the money raised will go toward the total program cost.

 

How Does This Help?

The ISV program has been organizing these volunteer efforts for almost 30 years. In that time, they've clocked over 220000 hours of volunteer work in six different countries, protected and relocatetd 8570 endangered sea turtle eggs, and spent over 27500 hours teaching music, English, conservation, recreation, & health programs to over 4100 children.
 
For more info on ISV's achievements:
http://www.isvolunteers.org/achievements

 

What You Can Do

Not everyone is in a position to help out financially, but that's okay! Please, if you can, spread the word. Tell friends, family, post this site on facebook, do whatever you feel to help get the word out there. You never know who of your friends may feel inclined to donate!

story:
UPDATE MAY 24th 2013


I wish to extent a very merry thank you to all those in our community to contributed to the Entanglement campaign and to those who came down to the event. It was an amazing day, a wonderful collection of people.  

We have just started working on the fulfillment of your perks and based on the contribution levels, you will receive an email shortly. The desktop backgrounds phone backgrounds will likewise be sent out in the coming weeks.

Thanks again for your support!

Michael 

 

 

 

UPDATE APRIL 3rd 2013


We did it! Yesterday afternoon we broke through the $3000 barrier! What an awesome feeling of support knowing  my friends, family and the art community have  made choices to stand behind this projet and help make it happen. I feel really supported by everyone so thank you. 

The goal now, is to get a lot of people out to the Art Auction and to the After-Party. It's going to be a great evening full of really conscious and powerful people. Make sure to invite all your friends!

Here is a video we shot over the weekend with the goal of engaging the public about single-use plastic waste. 

 

https://vimeo.com/63225640 

 

 

UPDATE APRIL 2nd 2013

YIKES! We are getting soooooooooo close to our goal, and with 4 days left! I want to  extend a huge thank you and a heart-side hug to our latest contributers! I hope you are all ready to shake your tail-feathers on Saturday night!

A sincere thank you, and big hugs when I see you!

LOVE

MJPH

Wow! Its hasn't even been 48 hours since we launched the campaign and the response to the project has been huge! We are narrowing in on a 1/3 of our goal already!

 

A Big Big Big Thank You to our Contributers! And please keep the momentum going!

 

Love and high-fives,

MOUNTAIN HEMLOCK

Kelly Ann Woods IOU one big, heart-side hug!

 

CAMPAIGN OVERVIEW

 

Entanglement is a series of images that explore the relationship between human beings and waste plastic. Sourcing waste plastic recovered from construction sites, movie sets and back alleys, Michael has commissioned the design and construction of costumes and set pieces for this moving portrait of a human culture.

 

He is seeking to raise $5000 to help with the production and exhibition of this work at Vancouver Science World. Thousands of people will be impacted by this work and its message about our entangled relationship waste material. Please help us achieve our goal by contributing to our three-phase fundraising campaign.

 

PHASE I / MARCH 19 - APRIL 6 / Online INDIGOGO campaign

 

$3000 goal

 

Awards are listed to the right. Included: signed archival prints of Michael J.P. Hall's previous work, future signed archival prints from the Entanglement series, tickets to the after-party and more.

 

http://www.michaeljphall.com

 

10% of all online campaign donations will directly support The Surf-rider Foundation and The Great Canadian Shoreline Clean-up.

 

PHASE II / APRIL 6 / 2pm - 9pm / ART EXHIBITION - Hosted by EAST VAN STUDIOS

 

Art exhibition for the Vancouver community featuring local artists focused on sustainability. Art proceeds will go directly to campaign and artists.

 

Engaging children through art and environmental stewardship. Connecting front line organizations with the greater Vancouver community through the use of art activism. Check out art installations from organizations like Surfrider, The Great Canadian Shoreline cleanup, Maker Fair and more.

 

DE Radio DJ’s, Environmental Film Screenings throughout the afternoon, Silent Auction for Michael JP Hall limited edition prints, Raffle for campaign packages including tickets to closing night after party.

 

Connect with the movement towards a sustainable future.

 

ENVIRONMENTAL ART SUBMISSIONS REQUESTED. hello@michaeljphall.com

 

PHASE III / APRIL 6 / 9pm – LATE / AFTER-PARTY - Hosted by EAST VAN STUDIOS

 

Check out the Facebook event page for details: https://www.facebook.com/events/263190963816173/

 

Campaign closing after-party. A DE RADIO production featuring the talents of Vancouver DJ’s, musicians and visual artists.

 

Ticketed event celebrating the end of the successful campaign.

 

Affilated Partners:

 

SURFRIDER FOUNDATION - VANCOUVER CHAPTER

 

We are the Vancouver chapter of the Surfrider Foundation, a global environmental non-profit organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves and beaches through a powerful activist network.

 

Our Vancouver chapter is 100% volunteer run by everyday people like you.

 

Founded in southern California in the early eighties, Surfrider Foundation started with a couple of surfers concerned about the possible destruction of their favourite wave. Since then it has grown to a network of chapters around the world that believe global challenges can be addressed through local grassroots actions.

 

We’re more than just surfers. We’re a community of beach and ocean enthusiasts who share a common vision of healthy and accessible oceans and coastlines, for now and for generations to come. We play an active role in the Vancouver community through outreach and education programs. We create opportunities for activism on issues of ocean and coastal pollution.

WWW.SURFRIDERVANCOUVER.COM

 

GREAT CANADIAN SHORELINE CLEANUP - WWF and Vancouver Aquarium

 

In 1994, a small team of employees and volunteers at the Vancouver Aquarium decided to clean up a local beach in Stanley Park to help protect the city’s shorelines. They submitted the data collected during this event to the International Coastal Cleanup, a global program managed by the Ocean Conservancy. By 1997, 400 volunteers were participating in 20 sites across British Columbia as part of the Great BC Beach Cleanup.

 

In 2002, the Great Canadian Shoreline Cleanup emerged as a national program, providing all Canadians the opportunity to make a difference in their local communities. Cleanups started appearing in every province and territory, and by 2003, more than 20,000 volunteers were taking part.

 

Over the following years, the program continued to expand its reach and influence, aided by the support of sponsors, donors, and partners (such as WWF Canada, who became a full partner of the Shoreline Cleanup in 2010). Public support and interest in the program also grew as Canadians gradually became more aware of the harmful effects of shoreline litter on both fragile aquatic ecosystems and people.

 

In 2011, the Shoreline Cleanup celebrated its 18th anniversary with more than 56,000 volunteers, and piloted the first spring cleanup for school groups in British Columbia. Today, it is recognized as one of the largest direct action conservation programs, as well as the most significant contributor to the International Coastal Cleanup in Canada.

WWW.SHORELINECLEANUP.CA

 

SCIENCE WORLD

 

Science World British Columbia is a charitable non-profit organization that engages British Columbians in science and inspires future science and tech- nology leadership throughout our province.

WWW.SCIENCEWORLD.CA

 

DE RADIO

 

The DE Kollektiv is a Vancouver creative collective with the fundamental purpose to bring a global audience a fresh, organic, electronic sound in a way that uplifts, provides solace and facilitates community in the most minimal and accessible way possible.

WWW.DERADIO.CA

 

PONDERA FM

 

PONDERA FM supports people, communities and ideas that break with convention, inspire innovation and test preconceptions.

We develop visually based campaigns to promote environmental and cultural conservation.
story_txt:
UPDATE MAY 24th 2013
I wish to extent a very merry thank you to all those in our community to contributed to the Entanglement campaign and to those who came down to the event. It was an amazing day, a wonderful collection of people.  
We have just started working on the fulfillment of your perks and based on the contribution levels, you will receive an email shortly. The desktop backgrounds phone backgrounds will likewise be sent out in the coming weeks.
Thanks again for your support!
Michael 
 
 
 
UPDATE APRIL 3rd 2013
We did it! Yesterday afternoon we broke through the $3000 barrier! What an awesome feeling of support knowing  my friends, family and the art community have  made choices to stand behind this projet and help make it happen. I feel really supported by everyone so thank you. 
The goal now, is to get a lot of people out to the Art Auction and to the After-Party. It's going to be a great evening full of really conscious and powerful people. Make sure to invite all your friends!
Here is a video we shot over the weekend with the goal of engaging the public about single-use plastic waste. 
 
https://vimeo.com/63225640 
 
 
UPDATE APRIL 2nd 2013
YIKES! We are getting soooooooooo close to our goal, and with 4 days left! I want to  extend a huge thank you and a heart-side hug to our latest contributers! I hope you are all ready to shake your tail-feathers on Saturday night!

MJPH

LOVE
MJPH

Wow! Its hasn't even been 48 hours since we launched the campaign and the response to the project has been huge! We are narrowing in on a 1/3 of our goal already!
 
A Big Big Big Thank You to our Contributers! And please keep the momentum going!
 
Love and high-fives,
 
MJPH

CAMPAIGN OVERVIEW
 
Entanglement is a series of images that explore the relationship between human beings and waste plastic. Sourcing waste plastic recovered from construction sites, movie sets and back alleys, Michael has commissioned the design and construction of costumes and set pieces for this moving portrait of a human culture.
 
He is seeking to raise $5000 to help with the production and exhibition of this work at Vancouver Science World. Thousands of people will be impacted by this work and its message about our entangled relationship waste material. Please help us achieve our goal by contributing to our three-phase fundraising campaign.
 
PHASE I / MARCH 19 - APRIL 6 / Online INDIGOGO campaign
 
$3000 goal
 
Awards are listed to the right. Included: signed archival prints of Michael J.P. Hall's previous work, future signed archival prints from the Entanglement series, tickets to the after-party and more.
 
http://www.michaeljphall.com
 
10% of all online campaign donations will directly support The Surf-rider Foundation and The Great Canadian Shoreline Clean-up.
 
PHASE II / APRIL 6 / 2pm - 9pm / ART EXHIBITION - Hosted by EAST VAN STUDIOS
 
Art exhibition for the Vancouver community featuring local artists focused on sustainability. Art proceeds will go directly to campaign and artists.
 
Engaging children through art and environmental stewardship. Connecting front line organizations with the greater Vancouver community through the use of art activism. Check out art installations from organizations like Surfrider, The Great Canadian Shoreline cleanup, Maker Fair and more.
 
DE Radio DJ’s, Environmental Film Screenings throughout the afternoon, Silent Auction for Michael JP Hall limited edition prints, Raffle for campaign packages including tickets to closing night after party.
 
Connect with the movement towards a sustainable future.
 
ENVIRONMENTAL ART SUBMISSIONS REQUESTED. hello@michaeljphall.com
 
PHASE III / APRIL 6 / 9pm – LATE / AFTER-PARTY - Hosted by EAST VAN STUDIOS
 
Check out the Facebook event page for details: https://www.facebook.com/events/263190963816173/
 
Campaign closing after-party. A DE RADIO production featuring the talents of Vancouver DJ’s, musicians and visual artists.
 
Ticketed event celebrating the end of the successful campaign.
 
Affilated Partners:
 
SURFRIDER FOUNDATION - VANCOUVER CHAPTER
 
We are the Vancouver chapter of the Surfrider Foundation, a global environmental non-profit organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves and beaches through a powerful activist network.
 
Our Vancouver chapter is 100% volunteer run by everyday people like you.
 
Founded in southern California in the early eighties, Surfrider Foundation started with a couple of surfers concerned about the possible destruction of their favourite wave. Since then it has grown to a network of chapters around the world that believe global challenges can be addressed through local grassroots actions.
 
We’re more than just surfers. We’re a community of beach and ocean enthusiasts who share a common vision of healthy and accessible oceans and coastlines, for now and for generations to come. We play an active role in the Vancouver community through outreach and education programs. We create opportunities for activism on issues of ocean and coastal pollution.
WWW.SURFRIDERVANCOUVER.COM
 
GREAT CANADIAN SHORELINE CLEANUP - WWF and Vancouver Aquarium 
 
In 1994, a small team of employees and volunteers at the Vancouver Aquarium decided to clean up a local beach in Stanley Park to help protect the city’s shorelines. They submitted the data collected during this event to the International Coastal Cleanup, a global program managed by the Ocean Conservancy. By 1997, 400 volunteers were participating in 20 sites across British Columbia as part of the Great BC Beach Cleanup.
 
In 2002, the Great Canadian Shoreline Cleanup emerged as a national program, providing all Canadians the opportunity to make a difference in their local communities. Cleanups started appearing in every province and territory, and by 2003, more than 20,000 volunteers were taking part.
 
Over the following years, the program continued to expand its reach and influence, aided by the support of sponsors, donors, and partners (such as WWF Canada, who became a full partner of the Shoreline Cleanup in 2010). Public support and interest in the program also grew as Canadians gradually became more aware of the harmful effects of shoreline litter on both fragile aquatic ecosystems and people.
 
In 2011, the Shoreline Cleanup celebrated its 18th anniversary with more than 56,000 volunteers, and piloted the first spring cleanup for school groups in British Columbia. Today, it is recognized as one of the largest direct action conservation programs, as well as the most significant contributor to the International Coastal Cleanup in Canada.
WWW.SHORELINECLEANUP.CA
 
SCIENCE WORLD
 
Science World British Columbia is a charitable non-profit organization that engages British Columbians in science and inspires future science and tech- nology leadership throughout our province.
WWW.SCIENCEWORLD.CA
 
DE RADIO
 
The DE Kollektiv is a Vancouver creative collective with the fundamental purpose to bring a global audience a fresh, organic, electronic sound in a way that uplifts, provides solace and facilitates community in the most minimal and accessible way possible.
WWW.DERADIO.CA
 
PONDERA FM 
 
PONDERA FM supports people, communities and ideas that break with convention, inspire innovation and test preconceptions.
We develop visually based campaigns to promote environmental and cultural conservation.

story:
Update 7!


It's not just about sunglasses!

We're rolling into the final week of the campaign. It's a great time to remind everyone that this is not just about sunglasses. The sunglasses are funny, but this project is really about the stretch goals. Goals like:

1. Conservation genetics of three shark species, including Great Hammerheads. We're using DNA to unlock the history of shark populations before and after fishing depleted their stocks. Funds will go to lab costs* and consumables. 

2. Taking a class from a Title 1 school in the Miami area out on a day long shark tagging expedition. Students will get a hands on experience collecting data and participating in all (safe) components of the research. Funds raised above $4000 will first cover bus costs for the school, then go towards the shark conservation genetics project. 

3. Building the ultimate ecodrone. We're building a quadcopter for serious, diverse ecologic research, capable of water take-off and landing. More than 75% of the cost of the drone is already covered, but extra funds means better cameras, water sampling capabilities, and other valuable tools to make this the most capable general use marine ecodrone out there. 

---------

I think so. And I hope you do too. Let's buy him some sunglasses that reflect how cool his shark conservation work really is.

Wait, really? Yes. I really do want to buy David Shiffman some nicer sunglasses.

That's it? Pretty much. There's some nice, small rewards to your right that might interest you, but nothing too fancy.

Really? Really?! You bet. Though, if by some fluke of incredible luck we go over, we do have some stretch goals in mind that would help support existing, partially-funded projects, including: covering the cost to take an underserved Title 1 school on a shark tagging field trip, lab consumables and technician time for a conservation genetics project investigating the consequences of overfishing on three shark species, and building a custom drone for marine science and conservation studies.

But really, I just want to get my colleague, co-author, and good friend some cool shades.


What's your budget? $500 for the cost of a decent pair of sunglasses with prescription lenses plus the fee that IndieGoGo take soff the top.

So who is this David Shiffman guy anyway? Oh man, if you like sharks, he's the best. He's on Twitter (@WhySharksMatter) and Facebook (David 'WhySharksMatter' Shiffman). He writes awesome articles at Southern Fried Science, Scientific American, and many other venues. He also publishes quite a bit of peer-reviewed scientific research, too. He deserves to look cool while keeping the sun out of his eyes.

Update 1: Challenges and Stretch Goals

Are you ready for a challenge?

Thanks to all your support we surpassed 50% funding in the first 24 hours! We're one step closer to ridding the world of those horrible, horrible, sunglasses. And that means it's time for Challenge Goals!

Here's how it works: We've selected 16 challenges the can be accomplished online. Some are silly, some are serious, some help promote the project. For every 4 goals you achieve, we'll reveal a new and exciting surprise. Maybe it'll be a new reward. Maybe it'll be some new content. Maybe it will be completely unexpected. Your challenges, should you choose to accept them:

Some rules: Tag everything with either #sharkglass, sharkfacts, or #ecodrone on twitter (even the blogs, since we have to be able to find them). The blog posts should make passing reference to this project (so no recycling old content). You can post pictures to Twitter or the Southern Fried Science Facebook page, but we prefer Twitter. And please, for the love of cod and all that is mola, don't mess with real, live sharks. For that matter, please don't send us pictures of dead sharks, they make us sad. 

Announcing the Stretch Goals!

So what happens if we go over? Where does the extra money go? Because our projects have variable budgets, we have a sliding scale for stretch goals.

Up to $4000: Conservation genetics of three shark species, including Great Hammerheads. We're using DNA to unlock the history of shark populations before and after fishing depleted their stocks. Funds will go to lab costs* and consumables. 

$4000: If we hit $4000, we'll be able to take a class from a Title 1 school in the Miami area out on a day long shark tagging expedition. Students will get a hands on experience collecting data and participating in all (safe) components of the research. Funds raised above $4000 will first cover bus costs for the school, then go towards the shark conservation genetics project. 

Over $6000: Help build the ultimate ecodrone. We're building a quadcopter for serious, diverse ecologic research, capable of water take-off and landing. More than 75% of the cost of the drone is already covered, but extra funds means better cameras, water sampling capabilities, and other valuable tools to make this the most capable general use marine ecodrone out there. 

*Full disclosure: Andrew is the geneticist doing the lab work, so a portion of funds for the genetics project may go towards covering his salary while working on the project.

Risks and challenges

There is always the risk that, for whatever reason, David Shiffman won't like wearing one nice pair of good looking sunglasses and will default back to stacking those big clunky things on top of his regular glasses. But, as David is actually involved in the process and gets final say over the sunglasses we buy for him, that is exceedingly unlikely.

I guess a massive and unexpected surge in the price of decent sunglasses could also cause us to blow our budget, but the history of the non-ugly sunglasses commodities market makes this exceptionally unlikely.

story:
Frogs in Airports!

Please help SAVE THE FROGS! raise the $500 we need to get TWO of these 4x5' educational posters up in John Wayne International Airport outside Los Angeles. SAVE THE FROGS! has educated tens of thousands of people about frogs through our partnerships with airports around the USA. The airports donate us free ad space that they usually sell to for-profits for thousands of dollars per month. All we need to do is cover the cost of the poster printing. That's where you can help! For only $500, we can get two huge educational frog posters up in John Wayne International Airport outside Los Angeles. Some of our airport posters stay up for several years, so this is a fantastic opportunity! Please donate and help us SAVE THE FROGS!

The poster lists seven major threats to frogs across the top, and why frogs are important across the bottom. It also introduces people to SAVE THE FROGS! and our mission, so it will help us get a lot of new supporters. The huge URL will also drive lots of students and teachers to savethefrogs.com, which has over 300 pages of free information on amphibians and how to protect them for future generations. 

Your donation will help us get these posters in front of the public and educate thousands of people about frogs. Thanks so much for your support!

Everyone who donates $25 or higher will get their name listed in the Thank You section of www.savethefrogs.com/airports

Thanks to SAVE THE FROGS! Graphic Design Wizard Alyson Lee for the volunteer graphic design assistance.

You can find more ways to donate to SAVE THE FROGS! at www.savethefrogs.com/donate

story:
I recently obtained a piece of paradise - a small land parcel on a mostly vacant island (under 20 people live here), with an unfinished micro cabin. I am SO excited to turn it into a sustainable living project - off grid, living off the land, permaculture, and community. I plan for it to be fully self-sustaining, but like any project - it requires a bit of initial investing. Actually alot of investment for me - I am trying to build almost everything myself, and to use natural materials found on my land. I'm looking to fund a few important basics to get the project going - wood stove parts (for basic cooking & heat), a simple wire fence (required before I can grow anything - otherwise the deer will eat it all!), and arborist fees for a few trees that are leaning a bit too close to the cabin (much cheaper to take care of now, then after they fall). Once the basics are in place (besides the projects I hope to fund here, I have been busy building water catches, installing a bathroom, sheetrocking, clearing land, hauling rocks, building garden beds...) I plan to live there full time, and hope that I can share this project and piece of paradise with many people to provide a relaxing escape from the rush and stress of mainstream culture, experience of an alternative lifestyle, connection with nature, connection and awareness of our food system, and new do it yourself skills (I sure am learning ALOT). Future plans include - a mini fruit & nut orchard, berry patches, rabbits, quails, a pond, a root cellar, fruit vines, solar energy, vegetable beds, lots of edible preennials, food preservation, wild edible foraging, an edible weed garden, grey water cache, composting, a bug farm, crafts made from materials on the land, kayaking & fishing projects, community building & awareness.... and my ideas are endless really! 

Short Summary

 Being on the land fills me with serenity, peace, and hope... it feeds me and inspires me, and my hope is that through this project I can also feed (both literally with produce and energetically) and inspire others for global change. The projects I am looking to fund are relatively small, but any contribution towards them would make a HUGE difference to me, and to the sustainability of the project. Sustainable living and connection with nature is quintessential to global well being.  And, I would love to share my piece of paradise with you - once it gets going - come relax and play (and\or work and learn!) for an afternoon, or weekend, or a week!

What We Need & What You get:

Seeking: $500 towards heating & cooking (wood stove installion, parts...), $500 for fence building materials, and $800 for skilled tree cutting labor (required priority for safety of the cabin, and to provide enough space and light for growing food, some lumber will be traded for discounted work and the rest used for firewood). (The rest of the money is paid to this site in fees). If I don't make my goal whatever money I do get will still be extremely helpful and go towards the projects listed. If I were to exceed my goal I would use any extra money towards building supplies, tools, and starter plants.

I want to share this project with the community from the beginning, so I am offering some related perks when you contribute: vegetable starts, an afternoon get away on the island, a weekend on the island. I hope you will join me!

 

The Impact

I have been a teacher and service provider for almost 20 years (yes, since I was a child), with a strong desire to change the world into a more loving, connected , just, and sustainable place. I desire to contribute individual, community, and world health and the growth of social justice. And then I burned out. I still love teaching, but I realized that I was completely burned out of fast paced city life, running a business, being disconnected from nature and from real food. I realized I had been caught up in and exhausted by the very things I wanted to change. So I decided to "be the change you want to see in the world" (Ghandi) instead. That means radical changes for me, but my spirit has already been up lifted. I hope that my personal transformation through this project will have a positive ripple affect, but also that I will be able to share directly with many others - through sharing food grown & raised, sharing skills and knowledge learned, leading by example and demonstrating a more sustainable and peaceful way of life, and by inviting the community in to participate and experience paradise for themselves :) 

Other Ways You Can contribute :

If you can't help financially no problem! I can also use help with projects - pretty much any tool you would like to use - I have a job for you! :)  And of course it would be a great help if you could share this funding campaign with your friends, on Facebook, twitter, whatever else you use to spread the word!

I realized I had been caught up in and exhausted by the very things I wanted to change. So I decided to "be the change you want to see in the world" (Ghandi) instead. That means radical changes for me, but my spirit has already been up lifted. I hope that my personal transformation through this project will have a positive ripple affect, but also that I will be able to share directly with many others - through sharing food grown & raised, sharing skills and knowledge learned, leading by example and demonstrating a more sustainable and peaceful way of life, and by inviting the community in to participate and experience paradise for themselves :) Other Ways You Can contribute :If you can't help financially no problem! I can also use help with projects - pretty much any tool you would like to use - I have a job for you! :)  And of course it would be a great help if you could share this funding campaign with your friends, on Facebook, twitter, whatever else you use to spread the word!

story:
We're at a critical moment in our campaign and need your support:

The Municipality of West Vancouver recently voted to pursue our by-law but the final decision won't be made until this fall. We want to use this period to build on their example and inspire leadership across the country. Your contributions will be used to hire a student who will do a lot outreach to ensure that councillors in other communities support our climate change warning labels.

The student:

Meet Shivani! She's a bright, motivated student that's really concerned about climate change and is keen to help Our Horizon. She's ready to begin on June 16th. We're all ready to go - we just need your support to make it happen.



The game plan - how we'll get broad support:

  1. Academic endorsements: Experts like James Hansen (Columbia University), Andrew Weaver (University of Victoria), Thomas Homer-Dixon (University of Waterloo) and several others have recently endorsed the concept of warning labels on gas pumps. Shivani will do outreach to secure 100 academic endorsements over the summer and prepare a media release.
  2. Citizen endorsements: Shivani will help run a petition through a popular online platform to get citizens to endorse the idea of warning labels on gas pumps. We're aiming to get more than 10,000 signatures to support our concept.
  3. Corporate endorsements: After we've done the above, Shivani will reach out to corporations that have endorsed the Climate Declaration. The objective is to get mainstream businesses to support our idea so that it becomes mainstream by association.
  4. Councillor outreach: We have a database with the email addresses of 25,000 municipal councillors across Canada. We plan on contacting all of them after completing the steps above. We're putting it all on the line this summer. We're going to ask Canadian communities to lead.

This plan will provide our concept with intellectual credibility, popular support, and corporate mainstreaming. The objective is to create conditions that would make a politician feel out of step if they were to say 'no' to our idea.

By having Shivani work on this plan, I'll have more time to reach out to youth to encourage them to bring the idea forward in their own communities. I'll also be able to communicate with councillors and staff to facilitate the adoption of our by-law.

How your donations will be used:

  • Wages: $12/hr * 40 hrs/wk * 11 weeks = $5,280
  • Work space: $200/mo * 2.5 months = $500
  • Perks fulfillment & Indiegogo/credit card fees (estimate): $670
  • TOTAL: $6,450

The hot plate - a message from Rob:

Read the headlines: extreme weather, ocean acidification, rise in sea level, drought and famine, mass migration, conflict, extinction of species. The list goes on. This really is the fight of our lives.

The solution is simple: transition away from fossil fuels and towards renewables. The question is: what are some of the tools that can help hasten that transition? At just pennies a sticker, our idea is perhaps the cheapest climate intervention on the planet. As simple as it is, I believe it will contribute to the creation of social conditions that favour reform.

The last year and a half has turned an idea into something that's now on the verge of becoming law. While I'm almost always smiling, the truth is it's been a challenging ride. A few weeks ago, I whipped out a calculator to see how long I worked and realized it had been 100 hours that week. The hot plate is from my basement apartment. Living there is what lets me afford this advocacy work.

We all have to do our part. If you worry about climate change, please make a small contribution to our campaign and share this crowdfund with your friends. I see these labels taking root in Canadian communities and spreading all over the world. It's no exaggeration to say that you're helping to shape history by contributing to this campaign.

On a personal note, your contribution would also let me cut back a few hours a week and have a bit of time off to enjoy the summer. Thanks for your support!

- Rob

Please watch our TEDx below to learn more about our campaign:


If you want to go beyond the brief TEDx talk and really learn about our concept, please watch our lecture recorded at CIGI (Centre for International Governance Innovation) on May 8th, 2014:


Warning label samples:
