                                 The crew so far..

       Brett Scott                                                                   Eric Henry                                                      
"Through sustainably growing gourmet and medicinal mushrooms with/for our community, we seek to initiate and maintain various (mycorestoration) projects amongst native waterways.  By doing so, we hope to discover how to live in a deeply abundant and symbiotic relationship with our only home, planet Earth."
                         -SWF Mission statement                  
                    Why mushrooms?


   
For thousands of years, ancient cultures have revered mushrooms for their health benefits, culinary value, and the sacred experience that some can invoke.  Fungi contain some of the most potent, natural medicine on the planet, and are known to possess supernatural healing qualities in many eastern traditions.  
   Of the estimated 140,000 species of mushroom-forming fungi, science is familiar with only 10 percent, according to world-renown mycologist Paul Stamets, who has written several books on this fascinating topic.  Paul is also responsible for much of the research regarding the remedial properties of fungi, and how we can apply them to our current situation of environmental degradation.  
In his book, "Mycelium Running," Stamets highlights the many functions and behaviors of mushrooms.  Some species hyperaccumulate heavy metals such as radioactive isotopes Cesium-134 and 137, mercury, lead and arsenic among others. They digest and/or trap several pathogens, including malaria! They also digest pesticides, estrogen-based pharmaceuticals, dioxins, dyes and petroleum hydrocarbons. Some of which are found in run-off from CAFOs (concentrated animal feeding operations) and other industrial farming operations. The list can be further expanded and is only growing. This, to us, indicates HUGE, exciting potential. “In God, every end is converted into a new means. Thus the use of commodity, regarded by itself, is mean and squalid.” ― Ralph Waldo Emerson, Nature 


It could be debated that water is the main transportation device of biological systems on a global and cellular level.  All life on this planet needs water. We believe, through cleaning water, we are helping to clean every facet of life.   We are all impacted by pollution, whether you know it or not.  Water from streams used to be drinkable, swimmable, and generally safe to enjoy.  We are now confronted with the fact that our levels of consumption have compromised the natural world, and our waterways are no longer the life-giving bodies that they once were. Soil no longer provides for the diversity of life when it is over-farmed and soaked with toxic chemicals.  These issues seem daunting, and many would choose to ignore them for the comfort of complacency, but we believe that nature has equipped us with the tools necessary to restore our planet to the abundant paradise that it once was.  We also believe that the potential for a healthy, symbiotic and balanced life are within the grasp of each individual, and every community.

     By investing in this project, you are helping us to create a model that could very well change the planet, transforming our relationship with the environment as a whole.We hope to spark a regenerative trend that will eventually be present in all business models, with Earth and biology as a priority.


     Laetiporus Sulphureus:  The Chicken of the Woods   

                                  How it works:


There's a fairly simple process that we use to propagate mushrooms indoors. Here's a little breakdown of what's involved: 

             
   We start with a liquid culture of a particular strain, in this case we are growing the Elm Oyster.  The liquid is carefully inoculated via syringe into a jar containing pasteurized rye grain; this begins the first step of the 'spawn run' stage of growth.         
   A week later, we transfer the colonized grain into a  bag of enriched, pasteurized sawdust for the second stage of the spawn run.  Using different mediums in the spawn run stage gives the fungi a metabolic advantage, as well as a wide range of nutrients to consume throughout it's growth.

                    Another week goes by, and we are ready to transfer the colonized sawdust into our fruiting bags, which contain a mixed medium of thrashed wheat straw, locally sourced coffee grounds and hardwood chips that have been pasteurized beforehand.  After carefully transferring the mycelium into the fruiting bags, they are moved into a dark room to finish spawning; and a few weeks later, can be moved into an environment that is conducive for fruiting. This is the stage that produces the wholesome mushrooms we all love.           

From here we can use the "spent" mycelial cakes to create mushroom compost and more importantly, employ this "acclimated spawn" in our bioremediation projects. 




    
Where the funding goes:   
As simple as this process is, there is a significant margin for error, and a risk of contamination while working in the small space that we have.  We are reaching out to the community to support us in making this process more organized and efficient, so that we can have room to grow this vision, as well as provide space to initiate and maintain restoration projects.  

The donations contributed will help us expand and acquire certain tools and materials such as:  a small structure for spawning/fruiting, ventilation and climate control equipment, spawning containers, fruiting containers, substrates, supplements and various lab equipment.  Any extra proceeds will go directly towards our mycorestoration projects.

   

By helping us attain these small goals, we can assure that the community is provided with an abundant and consistent harvest of healthy and organically grown mushrooms, educational resources to expand our knowledge of the fungi kingdom, and a sustainable business model for a brighter future!  In addition to providing food for this region, we will also be channeling our efforts into creating a variety of restoration projects aimed at removing toxins from industrial farm run-off by  installing "myco-filters"  to digest or trap any pollutants that may be contaminating the soil and water.


  
Can't Donate? No worries!


We understand that funds are tight for many of us these days, but there are some other ways you can help us manifest this vision!  
Word of mouth is still a crucial means of communicating!  As much time 
as we spend on computers and devices, it's still highly effective to 
reach out and talk to your peers.  Help spread the word about SweetWater
 Fungi by bringing us up in conversation and directing folks to our 
Facebook page: HERE
Do you use Facebook?  Give us a 'like', and share the status of our 
campaign with your friends and family.  We will be updating often, and 
providing information on wild, edible and medicinal fungi for anyone and everyone wishing to be closer to these wonderful allies.
  This has been a hobby for us for some time, and is rewarding in many ways; but recently we have become aware of a greater potential to this work.  Now, we seek to expand and sustain this vision into a more serious endeavor that will benefit the environment, and the community.  With industrial practices impending on our own waterways, we feel personally convicted to offer solutions in this time of need. 
Blessings and gratitude!   Sincerely, The Sweetwater Fungi team

Further reading on mycorestoration:

Water remediation in Nigeria


Fungi Perfecti's delivery system for mycotechnologies


Want more?  Watch this.



And this...






Contact us by email: sweetwaterfungi@gmail.com

story:
Tanker Enemy realizzerà la prima produzione professionale dedicata alla geoingegneria clandestina, aka "scie chimiche". Tutti noi saremo i produttori di un documentario che non porrà solo domande, ma che snocciolerà, una ad una, prove inconfutabili e che porrà di fronte alle loro responsabilità tutti coloro che, in questi anni, hanno negato, ridicolizzato, sminuito il problema che non è un problema, ma IL PROBLEMA.

 Sìate parte integrante del progetto! Siate gli artefici del cambiamento! Contribuite anche voi. Qui la pagina per contribuire alla realizzazione del primo documentario professionale italiano sulla geoingegneria clandestina.

CHE COS'E' "SULLE SCIE... DEL RISVEGLIO"

 E' il primo documentario professionale dedicato alla geoingegneria clandestina, aka "scie chimiche", realizzato da Tanker Enemy. Volete anche voi un prodotto che condensi le centinaia di prove, che raccolga testimonianze e che parli senza mezzi termini? Allora aiutateci a realizzarlo. Tutti noi saremo i produttori di un documentario che non porrà solo domande, ma che snocciolerà, una ad una, prove inconfutabili e che porrà di fronte alle loro responsabilità tutti coloro che, in questi anni, hanno negato, ridicolizzato, sminuito il problema che non è un problema, ma IL PROBLEMA.

PERCHE' IL VOSTRO AIUTO E' FONDAMENTALE

 Questo è un progetto no-profit. Tutto ciò che donerete servirà a coprire le spese di produzione e realizzazione. Non ci sarà nessun introito per i creatori.

CONDIVIDI LA CAMPAGNA

Indiegogo dà la possibilità di condividere la campagna, quindi il vostro aiuto in questo sarà fondamentale allo stesso modo delle donazioni. Più persone conosceranno il progetto, più avremo la possibilità di realizzarlo. Cliccate sui link di condivisione e coinvolgete tutti quelli che conoscete!

GRAZIE DI TUTTO!

Antonio e Rosario Marcianò
Comitato Nazionale Tanker Enemy

story:
Our Story

NEST is an all-volunteer group of self-organizing, tree-climbing humans. We take on a role as canopy surveyors, who utilize the Northwest Forest Plan’s “Survey and Manage” laws to protect ancient forests threatened by clearcut logging.


"Survey and Manage" laws protect the endangered species in Oregon's forests.  Endangered species need habitat to survive, so if you find an endangered critter, the trees that it lives in cannot be cut.  The Red Tree Vole and The Marbled Murrelet live in trees that are 150-400 years old, so we are trying to keep the oldest forests in the country standing.  Only 4% of Oregon's old growth forest remains after decades of heavy logging.  NEST, as well as many Oregonians, know that there is nothing like an ancient forest, the mammoth trunks and hanging green moss are a sight to behold.  These forests are home to many species of owl, bear, salmon, bird, snake, frog, and deer.  Unfortunately, the managers of these precious ecosystems still try to clearcut them.


NEST formed in response to this phenomenon in 1998, when several observant forest defenders noticed paid USFS surveyors climbing trees. These paid surveyors were seeking the treetop nests of red tree voles. Unfortunately, their abstract survey protocol does not fully account for tree vole habitat, and it is not ideal for finding nests.


Under Survey and Manage, each red tree vole nest documented was required to receive a 10-acre surrounding buffer where no logging could occur. Following a little research, the forest defenders realized just what needed to be done to do a much more thorough job, on their own.  They went out to the woods to do the surveys themselves.

The Impact

Since this time, NEST has found hundreds of Red Tree Vole nests in areas that were slated for logging. Thousands of acres of forest have been saved, as a result of NEST surveys.



Timber sales that have been canceled, largely due to NEST surveys, include the Clark Timber Sale (site of the Fall Creek Tree-sit), Straw Devil (site of a years-long occupation), and others.



Forest preservationists have very few tools to work with, and NEST is the most direct way we have found to confront forest management agencies and logging companies.  They may not listen when people hold signs outside their offices, but they cannot ignore good documentation of endangered species.



NEST has surveyed everywhere from the Illinois Valley of Southern Oregon, as far north as the Mt. Hood National Forest, and many sites in between. Some timber sales surveyed include Althouse Sucker, Anderson West, Deer Creek, Boney Skull, Cow Catcher, Trapper, and many others.



We hope to climb in many more!


For more information on NEST, visit the website at:


http://nestcascadia.wordpress.com


What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $2,000 for this summer and beyond.  A large portion of that money will go to gas.  We have to drive anywhere from 1-4 hours, depending where NEST is currently located, and gas is very expensive these days!


We also need to buy new climbing ropes ($300+ each) and a new compound bow (which can cost up to $700).  We use bows to shoot climbing lines into the tops of the trees, and then climbing harnesses to ascend the rope into the canopy.


The community of Eugene, OR is very supportive of us.  Local businesses donate most of the food we eat throughout the summer because they know how important our work is.  In Oregon, the forest belongs to everyone, but not everybody has time to fight for it.  But we are still in need of money for gas and gear.

 

DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE AS NEST IS A 501c3 NON-PROFIT.


For donations of $20 you will receive:

A monthly e-newsletter, informing you of NEST's successes, locations, and adventures.


$50 or more:

e-newsletter plus a handmade patch with the NEST logo


$100 or more:

e-newsletter + patches + a NEST t-shirt


$250 or more:

e-newsletter + patches + t-shirt + a NEST sweatshirt in your size


$500 or more:

e-newsletter + patches + t-shirt or sweatshirt + high quality photographic prints of the sales we survey, the huge trees inside them, and the tiny people that climb them!


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, you can help by passing the our campaign to interested parties/friends.  Get the word out!  Or even better, come visit the Oregon forests and climb with us!  If you are interested in getting involved, contact us via our website, 

http://nestcascadia.wordpress.com

Thanks!  May the Forest Be With You!

Thanks!  May the Forest Be With You!

story:
RAJOLI CHENETHA SRAMIKA SEVA SAMITHI 

Short Summary

We are passionate group of 10 people who have formed this NGO to help the weavers community in Rajoli village. During the 2009 floods around 800 families lives in terms of houses and livelihoods have been completely effected. These weavers have to depend on master weaver who exploit's these weavers by giving loans and charging them at a very high interest. These weavers also get very less amount after weaving a fabric. But the master weavers without investing much money or energy earns a lot of money. Next is the person who gives them the design he also controls these weavers. So ultimately the weaver is the one who struggles hard and the others earn money just by selling the fabric/saree at a huge prize. 

Our NGO would like to set up a center in rehabilitating these weavers in terms of giving them the raw materials establish a design center. This will make the weavers directly to go to the market and sell their produce and get very good profits.

This will help the weavers to lead a decent debt ridden life. 

The impact of this campaign will be the 800 weavers community. The center will get access to all the emerging trends in weavers technology.

story:
NEW PERK- Mother's Day Special, can only be purchased on Indiegogo. Get yours before we run out! 

                                      

Without bees to pollinate fruit trees, there would be no cherry pie. 
Without bees to pollinate vegetable gardens, there’d be no tomatoes.
Without bees to pollinate almond trees, there’d be no almond butter. 

The list is so long that without bees to pollinate your food, more than 1/3 of what you eat and drink would be gone. 

Problem: Most farmers depend on a single type of bee to pollinate our food and that bee, the honey bee, is struggling. Honey bees and local farmers need your help.

Solutions: There are 4,000 types of native bees in North America whose only job is to pollinate fruits, vegetables and nuts. Join the pollinator movement today! You can release a few native bees in your garden, raise gentle bees in your backyard or support someone else who is raising bees. 

Contribute: Keep your favorite foods on the table by contributing today to make sure there are enough bees to get the job done. 

            

5 Easy Ways You Can Help 

  1. Contribute $25
  2. Release Native Bees in Your Own Garden
  3. Raise Native Bees Local Farmers Can Use
  4. Support Someone Who Raises Native Bees
  5. Ask a Friend to Join the Pollination Revolution

What’s cool about native bees is that they’re super pollinators:

  • They don’t make honey, they just pollinate things.
  • It takes just 400 mason bees to pollinate 100 fruit trees. It takes about 30,000 honey bees to do the same job.
  • They gentle-natured and only sting in self-defense, so they’re safe around children and pets,
  • They’re easy to keep in your garden. You don’t need a hive or fancy equipment, just a “bee house” that you hang like a bird feeder.

    

The BeeWithMe Network

Whether you are releasing or raising native bees, we want to provide an easy-to-use tool that unites bee lovers and food lovers. Our goal is to teach people how to raise native bees and connect them with other backyard beekeepers who are already doing it. In the beta-version of BeeWithMe.net, you’ll find a simple concept that points to the potential.

Here is what you can do on BeeWithMe:

  • Participate: Raise bees and connect with others.
  • Learn: Receive garden tips, learn bee-safe best practices and find resources and mentors to ensure your success.
  • Share: Pin your bee house location on the interactive map and see the farms where your excess bee cocoons are being rehomed.
  • Communicate: Share and receive bee raising tips, stories and advice.
  • Bee Rewarded: Download rewards, coupons and obtain badges
  • Shop: Find local or online stores for bee-safe plants and products

Crown Bees has the vision and ability to start this movement, but you, the Bee Booster, and your community will make it succeed.

                                                         

Crown Bees Founder

The demand for food is increasing, which means we need more bees.

For 20 years, Dave Hunter has been on a mission to solve this problem. He founded Crown Bees, a Seattle -based company that specializes in gentle solitary bees, to diversify the types of bees used to pollinate our crops.

In growing his business, he began developing a small network of people who cared about bees, our food supply and the environment.

At Crown Bees, our first hurdle is to increase public awareness about solitary, native bees – even many experienced gardeners and farmers have never heard of them.

We Need $100,000 To:

  • Launch a public outreach and education campaign to increase awareness of native bees
  • Hire a webmaster, a web developer and a graphic designer to create BeeWithMe.net.
  • Our $100,000 will build a network of Native Bee Boosters from coast to coast and develop a new website to support this multi-faceted community.
  • Encourage people to raise native bees
  • Engage Garden Media Group, the leading public relations firm in the lawn and garden industry, to spread the word.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk is not moving fast enough to meet the demands of our future food supply. The good news is there are many ways to help save bees, even if you don’t want to be a beekeeper or raise native bees.

Our biggest challenges are:

  1. Educating people about native bees.
  2. Getting more people to release and raise native bees.
  3. Educating consumers about what the food they eat would look like without bees pollinating crops.
  4. Having enough bees to share with local farmers to help them continue to grow healthy, local food.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not all of us are willing or able to raise bees, but everyone who eats has a responsibility to help protect our food supply. Here’s what you can do to help:

  1. Support: Give a Crown Bee house to a community garden, public park, zoo, botanical garden, local farmer or give one as a gift. 
  2. Ask: Email your friends and ask them to join the movement and contribute.
  3. Share: Use Indiegogo Share Tools to spread the word. Post on social media about how native bees ensure food security. Use #BeeWithMe #BeeBooster #NativeBees @CrownBees
  4. Change: Let your friends know you are a Bee Booster by changing your social media profile picture to this photo.

What You Get

Want to raise mason bees through one of our perks? Our Kits are the best for that. 

All Kits come with a Shout Out on the BeeWithMe and Crown Bees websites, a native bee educational e-Booklet and a deluxe Bee Booster pin on the Bee With Me map.

Veggie Garden Kit 

Roll out the welcome mat for gentle leafcutter bees in your veggie garden this summer. They’ll move right in when you put up a BeeHut with the perfectly sized holes for their nests. You’ll also receive an assortment of 4 ‘Bee Satisfied’ top-quality vegetable seed packets from Botanical Interests to plant a buffet of their favorite flowers. And when these hardworking bees are happy, you’ll be happy with how much more your garden produces.

Please note best date for you June 1-August 1

2016 Limited Edition Mason Bee Booster Kit

Help take the stress off honey bees and raise mason bees next spring. Bee Boosters are the key to increasing our bee population. Next February, you’ll receive a new Limited Edition Bee Cabin and a pack of 20 mason bees that have been acclimated to pollinate spring flowers in your region, plus a HumidiBee™. This small humidity-controlled case makes it easy to overwintering cocoons in your refrigerator. 

Estimated Delivery: Feb 1, 2016

Teacher’s Kit

Are you a teacher or want to give a gift to your favorite teacher? This kit is a pollination lesson plan in a box by Michelle Mohr. Includes a Limited Edition Bee Cabin, 20 pack of mason bees, our small humidity-controlled case which makes it easy to overwintering cocoons in your refrigerator, a Mason Bee Viewer to watch the gentle bees do their work, a picture book about a boy who becomes empowered to help save the bees called Mason Meets a Mason Bee, a ‘I’m Helping Save the Bees’ certificate and a pack of 30 stickers for your students. 

Estimated Delivery: Feb 1, 2016

Mother’s Day Kit 

Perfect for a mom or grandmother interested in gardening, nature or animals, this kit includes her very own Bee Cabin, 20 pack of mason bees, a BrazelBerries® blueberry shrub and a Mother’s Day card. Expedited shipping paid separately in order to arrive by Mother’s Day, May 10. 

Delivery By May 8

Master Gardener Kit

Make your garden skills to a new level with this Master Gardener Kit! You’ll receive a beautiful Bee Chalet, 104-hole leafcutter wood tray, 100 leafcutter bee cocoons plus a Humidibee. Use this humidity controlled case to overwinter your bees and keeping them safe from predators. In addition, you’ll also receive a professionally designed bee-friendly landscape plan by award winning, nationally certified landscape designer, Susan Cohan, ‘Bee Happy’ assortment of 6 flower seed packets from Botanical Interests and a BrazelBerries® blueberry shrub. This new container-sized blueberry has delicate spring flowers, delicious summer fruit and bright fall color. 

Estimated Delivery: June 1 to Aug 1

Can't raise bees but want to donate to your garden club, favorite community garden or botanical garden? Choose one of these rewards: 

National Garden Clubs, Inc. Educational Package

Join Crown Bees CEO Dave Hunter, and National Garden Club officers, Linda Nelson, current President, and Sandy Robinson, incoming President for a two hour virtual hangout with your garden club. Dave will guide the conversation as you explore the possibilities for solutions to the problems pollinators face. Your club will also receive the Veggie Garden Kit which contains 100 leafcutter bees, Crown Bees Summer BeeHut, 4 seed packets, a Shout Out online, a bee sticker, an e-book about how to raise native bees and a deluxe Bee Booster pin on the Bee With Me map. Date and time to be determined. The session will be conducted by Google Hangout for all participants. If someone from your club is unable to attend the live session, a recording will be available. 

Estimated Delivery: Summer 

Community Gardening Association Package

Support your favorite community garden by donating 5 Bee Chalet Kits to an American Community Gardening Association member garden to increase local pollination. Each kit includes a chalet, wood nesting trays, 20 mason bee cocoons, 100 leafcutter bee cocoons, and supplies. Additionally, each garden will receive instructions to ensure success for years to come. ACGA has gardens in every state and in Canada, so please designate the region or state you’d like to see receive pollinators. Visit Communitygarden.org to learn more.

Estimated Delivery: June 15

Philadelphia Community Garden Package

Give back to the city of Brotherly Love by supporting a community garden in Philadelphia. This perk is for 5 Bee Chalet Kits for one community garden to increase local pollination. Each kit includes a chalet, wood nesting trays, 20 mason bee cocoons, 100 leafcutter bee cocoons, and supplies. Additionally, the community garden will receive support, training and materials from Pennsylvania Horticultural Society and Crown Bees to ensure success for years to come. Visit PHSonline.org to learn more.

Estimated Delivery: June 15

Pittsburgh Lovers Special – Bees for Phipps

Are your favorite colors black & gold – like honey bees? Do you tell everyone you know that Phipps Conservatory & Botanical Gardens is one of Pittsburgh’s greatest treasures? Then this perk is for you! Donate 5 Bee Chalet Kits to Phipps! Their staff will raise solitary bees in their gardens as a new hands-on science activity for kids. Each kit includes a chalet, wood nesting trays, 20 mason bee cocoons, 100 leafcutter bee cocoons, and supplies. Additionally, Phipps will receive training and materials from Crown Bees to ensure success for years to come. Visit Phipps.Conservatory.org to learn more.

Estimated Delivery: June 15

I Love NYC Community Gardens

This is your chance to make a difference in the city that never sleeps. Donate 5 Bee Chalet Kits to New York City GreenThumb gardens! Each kit includes a chalet, wood nesting trays, 20 mason bee cocoons, 100 leafcutter bee cocoons, and supplies. Additionally, GreenThumb Gardens will receive training and materials from Crown Bees to ensure success for years to come. Visit Greenthumbnyc.org to learn more.

Estimated Delivery: June 15

Consumer Brunch and Community Brainstorm at Your Garden Center or Health Food Store 

Events are the best way to drive traffic into your garden center or heath food store. With this perk, Crown Bees CEO Dave Hunter will host an educational lecture at your local store on the challenges currently faced by pollinators. This one-of-a-kind experience will educate current and potential customers on how to increase bee populations in your area. Foods pollinated by bees will be served. Dates are flexible. Perk also includes a Shout Out online, a bee sticker, an e-book about how to raise native bees and a deluxe Bee Booster pin on the Bee With Me map. 

Estimated Delivery: Summer 2015-Feb 2016

Just want something for yourself?

Weekend Trip for Two to Oregon’s Hood River Valley 

A once in a lifetime opportunity to visit Oregon’s rich Hood River Valley with people who call it home. Trip itinerary includes a guided hike in a local gorge, waterfalls, a tasting, dinner and tour at the famed Analemma Winery. Analemma Winery is an orchard completely pollinated by mason bees. Contributors receive transportation to and from Portland airport and a two-day, two-night stay at a local inn. Perk also includes the Crown Bees BeeWorks Kit, a Shout Out online, a bee sticker, a native bee educational e-booklet and a deluxe Bee Booster pin on the Bee With Me map. Perk does not include airfare or additional dining and expenses. 

Estimated Delivery: Date of June 2015 is flexible

Cocktails and Gentle Bees at your House

For a truly unique experience, Crown Bees CEO Dave Hunter will come to your house and entertain 20 of your friends. Specially crafted "Bees Knees" cocktails and foods pollinated by bees will be served. Learn how to join the mason bee revolution to grow more food and flowers. Discover how you can help keep food on the table, and save the overworked honey bee. Have fun finding out how easy it is to raise, harvest and share these gentle bees in your local community. The perk includes a Bee Chalet, a 104-hole leafcutter wood nesting tray, 100 leafcutter bee cocoons and a Humidibee, a storage case to overwinter bees in the fridge. 

Estimated Delivery: Date of March 2016 is flexible

EVEN MORE Signed cartoons from environmental artist Joe Mohr

Calling all fans of “Hank D and the Bee” cartoons! If you’ve loved Joe Mohr’s environmental art for a long time or only just discovered him, this perk will make you smile. Joe is debuting new cartoons exclusively through this campaign AND is offering signed cartoons to lucky contributors. Learn more about Joe and his new book for kids, “ROBOT+BIKE=KITTEN,” at poemsofjoems.com

Estimated Delivery: June 15

Ignite a Bee Revolution: 

Pollinate It Forward
story_txt:
NEW PERK- Mother's Day Special, can only be purchased on Indiegogo. Get yours before we run out!                                       Without bees to pollinate fruit trees, there would be no cherry pie. Without bees to pollinate vegetable gardens, there’d be no tomatoes.Without bees to pollinate almond trees, there’d be no almond butter. The list is so long that without bees to pollinate your food, more than 1/3 of what you eat and drink would be gone. Problem: Most farmers depend on a single type of bee to pollinate our food and that bee, the honey bee, is struggling. Honey bees and local farmers need your help.Solutions: There are 4,000 types of native bees in North America whose only job is to pollinate fruits, vegetables and nuts. Join the pollinator movement today! You can release a few native bees in your garden, raise gentle bees in your backyard or support someone else who is raising bees. Contribute: Keep your favorite foods on the table by contributing today to make sure there are enough bees to get the job done.             5 Easy Ways You Can Help 
Contribute $25

Release Native Bees in Your Own Garden


Raise Native Bees Local Farmers Can Use


Support Someone Who Raises Native Bees


Ask a Friend to Join the Pollination Revolution


What’s cool about native bees is that they’re super pollinators:


They don’t make honey, they just pollinate things.
It takes just 400 mason bees to pollinate 100 fruit trees. It takes about 30,000 honey bees to do the same job.
They gentle-natured and only sting in self-defense, so they’re safe around children and pets,
They’re easy to keep in your garden. You don’t need a hive or fancy equipment, just a “bee house” that you hang like a bird feeder.



    




The BeeWithMe Network

Whether you are
releasing or raising native bees, we want to provide an easy-to-use tool that
unites bee lovers and food lovers. Our goal is to teach people how to
raise native bees and connect them with other backyard beekeepers who are
already doing it. In the beta-version of
BeeWithMe.net, you’ll find a simple concept that points to the potential.
Here is what you can do on BeeWithMe:


Participate: Raise bees and connect with others.


Learn: Receive garden tips, learn bee-safe best practices and find resources and mentors to ensure your success.


Share: Pin your bee house location on the interactive map and see the farms where your excess bee cocoons are being rehomed.


Communicate: Share and receive bee raising tips, stories and advice.


Bee Rewarded: Download rewards, coupons and obtain badges


Shop: Find local or online stores for bee-safe plants and products



Crown Bees has the vision and ability to start this movement, but you, the Bee Booster, and your community will make it succeed.
                                                         

Crown Bees Founder

The demand for food is increasing, which means we need more bees.
For 20 years, Dave Hunter has been on a mission to solve this problem. He founded Crown Bees, a Seattle -based company that specializes in gentle solitary bees, to diversify the types of bees used to pollinate our crops.
In growing his business, he began developing a small network of people who cared about bees, our food supply and the environment.
At Crown Bees, our first hurdle is to increase public awareness about solitary, native bees – even many experienced gardeners and farmers have never heard of them.


We Need $100,000 To:




Launch a public outreach and education campaign to increase awareness of native bees
Hire a webmaster, a web developer and a graphic designer to create BeeWithMe.net.
Our
$100,000 will build a network of Native Bee Boosters from coast to coast and
develop a new website to support this multi-faceted community.
Encourage people to
raise native bees

Engage Garden Media
Group, the leading public relations firm in the lawn and garden industry, to spread
the word.




Risks
& Challenges
The biggest
risk is not moving fast enough to meet the demands of our future food supply. The good
news is there are many ways to help save bees, even if you don’t want to be a
beekeeper or raise native bees.
Our
biggest challenges are:



Educating people about native bees.


Getting more people to release and raise native bees.

Educating consumers about what
     the food they eat would look like without bees pollinating crops.
Having enough bees to share
     with local farmers to help them continue to grow healthy, local food.

Other
Ways You Can Help
Not
all of us are willing or able to raise bees, but everyone who eats has a
responsibility to help protect our food supply. Here’s what you can do to help: 



Support: Give a Crown Bee house to a
community garden, public park, zoo, botanical garden, local farmer or give one
as a gift. 


Ask: Email your friends and ask
them to join the movement and contribute.


Share: Use Indiegogo Share Tools
to spread the word. Post on social media about how native bees ensure food
security. Use #BeeWithMe #BeeBooster #NativeBees @CrownBees


Change: Let your friends know you
are a Bee Booster by changing your social media profile picture to this photo.



What You Get


Want to raise mason bees through one of our perks? Our Kits are the best for that. 
All Kits come with a Shout Out on the BeeWithMe and Crown Bees websites, a native bee educational e-Booklet and a deluxe Bee Booster pin on the Bee With Me map.
Veggie Garden Kit 



Roll out the welcome mat for gentle leafcutter bees in your veggie garden this summer. They’ll move right in when you put up a BeeHut with the perfectly sized holes for their nests. You’ll also receive an assortment of 4 ‘Bee Satisfied’ top-quality vegetable seed packets from Botanical Interests to plant a buffet of their favorite flowers. And when these hardworking bees are happy, you’ll be happy with how much more your garden produces.
Please note best date for you June 1-August 1
2016 Limited Edition Mason Bee Booster Kit


Help take the stress off honey bees and raise mason bees next spring. Bee Boosters are the key to increasing our bee population. Next February, you’ll receive a new Limited Edition Bee Cabin and a pack of 20 mason bees that have been acclimated to pollinate spring flowers in your region, plus a HumidiBee™. This small humidity-controlled case makes it easy to overwintering cocoons in your refrigerator. 
Estimated Delivery: Feb 1, 2016
Teacher’s Kit

Are you a teacher or want to give a gift to your favorite teacher? This kit is a pollination lesson plan in a box by Michelle Mohr. Includes a Limited Edition Bee Cabin, 20 pack of mason bees, our small humidity-controlled case which makes it easy to overwintering cocoons in your refrigerator, a Mason Bee Viewer to watch the gentle bees do their work, a picture book about a boy who becomes empowered to help save the bees called Mason Meets a Mason Bee, a ‘I’m Helping Save the Bees’ certificate and a pack of 30 stickers for your students. 
Estimated Delivery: Feb 1, 2016
Mother’s Day Kit 


Perfect for a mom or grandmother interested in gardening, nature or animals, this kit includes her very own Bee Cabin, 20 pack of mason bees, a BrazelBerries® blueberry shrub and a Mother’s Day card. Expedited shipping paid separately in order to arrive by Mother’s Day, May 10. 
Delivery By May 8
Master Gardener Kit


Make your garden skills to a new level with this Master Gardener Kit! You’ll receive a beautiful Bee Chalet, 104-hole leafcutter wood tray, 100 leafcutter bee cocoons plus a Humidibee. Use this humidity controlled case to overwinter your bees and keeping them safe from predators. In addition, you’ll also receive a professionally designed bee-friendly landscape plan by award winning, nationally certified landscape designer, Susan Cohan, ‘Bee Happy’ assortment of 6 flower seed packets from Botanical Interests and a BrazelBerries® blueberry shrub. This new container-sized blueberry has delicate spring flowers, delicious summer fruit and bright fall color. 

Estimated Delivery: June 1 to Aug 1

story:
Festival Story

BACKGROUND

The Borneo Rhythms of Rimba (ROR) Wildlife Festival is the first wildlife-focused festival on the island of Borneo and in Malaysia. 

An idea created by 9 guys and girls from very different backgrounds but all of whom share the same love for the town of Sandakan and its amazing Bornean biodiversity. Everyone is doing this on a voluntary basis. The fanciful idea turned into a tangible platform, when we got ourselves registered officially as a society called Future Alam Borneo (FAB) and started bringing together conservationists, scientists, musicians, artists and many more on board this ambitious ride in 2013.

The festival will be a 2 days, outdoor festival held on the fringe of a virgin rainforest reserve, the Rainforest Discovery Centre. We created this platform so that the numerous wildlife, forest and even marine conservation and research materials can be presented to the public as an overview of the natural diversity. From orang utans, to proboscis monkeys, sunbears, pygmy elephants, sumatran rhinos, pangolins and dolphins  and so many more endemic species will hopefully come alive to an audience we hope to attract locally as well as from abroad.  

And to add colour and fireworks to the event, we are bringing in friends who are musicians, artists, dancers, illustrators, and people wholly passionate about the wildlife message, and we intend to turn this into some amazing energy and fun.  

The dates of the ROR festival  are the 3rd and 4th OCT 2014. 

We have spent close to one year raising money from governmental, institutional, corporate bodies and individuals. The core team may just be 9, but it has been a wide-reaching collective effort. 

We hope ROR will open people's eyes and inspire them to play a part in conserving biodiversity in some of the oldest rainforests on this planet.

We have in hand 90% of our needed budget to run the festival. But to ensure this doesn't just become a spark which dies out, (we want it to continue annually and grow even bigger), we have decided to reach out internationally for your assistance and your awareness.


CROWDFUNDING.

We are seeking to raise USD9,000 from this campaign. 50% of this target will go towards bridging the outstanding 10% we need to fully cover the 2014 festival costs. The other 50% (USD4,500) and whatever ticket sales we manage to generate will go towards the festival the following year 2015. This first experience has proven raising and generating funds are vital for our own sustainability, and that we should plan and do it way in advance.

The festival tickets are sold at USD10 adults and USD3 children, with a large quantity going for free to charities, schools and other non-profit organisations. Ticket sales would only cover about 1/4 of the costs of running, If we sold out.

As a registered society, not only will our financial accounts have to be professionally vetted and submitted for review annually, we are also bound by funds donated to us from our state government and foreign embassies who are supporting us, to give them our financial reports as well.

In supporting us, not only will you be playing a part in educating locals about our natural heritage but the message has international reach, as we are supported in spirit by many people overseas too.

Contributions towards ROR will enable you to put your name on our foundation stone (ok, the website), get images and video from our fest, t-shirts, an exciting illustrated children's book The Wild Treehouse of Borneo, future tickets to ROR and even a place on our 'partners' lists.

All funds contributed will be acknowledged as promised, and if we do not hit our target, any money raised will go towards ensuring the 2015 ROR festival happens, come rain or shine, be it big or small.


IMPACT

We are hoping for an initial audience of around 1500 people, made up of local families, youths, students and international tourists. This audience would potentially multiply our content many-fold if they share it with their peers. Borneo and the town of Sandakan is already a popular eco/nature tourism destination. The conservation message would be further emphasized to a growing international audience.

Though this is our first attempt at organising a wildlife and music festival for the general public, 3/4 of our present team successfully raised the equivalent of USD135,000 for the Bornean Sun Bear Conservation Centre here last year through an ambitious, local donation drive.

We are by no means aspiring conservationists nor activists. But what we can do is create the platform for the public to meet and learn from the experts, in an approachable and entertaining way, and ultimately educate our future generations about living in harmony with our natural environment.


FINAL WORDS

We do need financial support urgently or else any deficits will have to come out of our own pockets (somehow), as the festival will definitely run. However if you are unable to support us in this way, any opportunities to share what we are doing through ROR will be greatly appreciated as the fundamental soul of it is the collective effort, for the conservation of our wildlife and their habitats.

story:
Utilizing the transformative power of music to encourage creativity and the protection of natural resources.


Clarinets for Conservation is gearing up for its 5th annual Tanzania program and we need your help to make this the most successful year yet! 

We offer a unique educational opportunity to K-12 students by teaching music, conservation, and sustainability while planting African Blackwood trees in one of the least developed countries in the world, Tanzania.  

Your donation is critical to making this experience possible. In order to take our students on tree plantings and educational trips we need $2,570.                            Your contribution is 100% tax-deductible!

_____________________________________________________________________________

Funds from this campaign will cover the following costs: 

  • Mpingo seedlings (600 will be planted at 16 different planting sites)
  • Conservationist teaching stipends
  • Transportation to tree planting sites
  • Transportation to conservation field trip sites 
_____________________________________________________________________________


WHAT DOES THE CLARINET HAVE TO DO WITH CONSERVATION? 

The African Blackwood is Tanzania’s national tree.  It is extremely valuable to musicians, the economy, and the environment. Prized for its tone and resiliency, the black heartwood is used in the manufacture of many instruments including: clarinets, oboes, piccolos, violins and guitars, and piano keys. 

African Blackwood is a commercially endangered resource.  

What does it mean to be a commercially endangered resource? It means that the mature trees have been harvested at a rate faster than the time it takes for seedling trees to reach maturation. The international demand for Blackwood is greater than the resources available. 

WHAT DOES C4C DO IN TANZANIA?

In 2010, one teacher traveled to Tanzania with 12 clarinets and the idea to teach both music and conservation. For the first time in history, the product (clarinets) were brought back to the product source (East Africa) and used as a creative interdisciplinary tool. Musical skills where taught and African Blackwood trees were planted.

Teaching secondary students in Tanzania to play the clarinet empowers them by improving problem-solving skills, facilitating self sufficiency, and by providing a healthy creative outlet.

Students of Korongoni Secondary and C4C teachers take part in innovative interdisciplinary performances and tree plantings throughout Tanzania to help connect the African Blackwood tree and the clarinet to the community – therefore fostering a sincere desire for a sustainable future.

A majority of Tanzanians have never heard or seen the clarinet. 

The environmental benefits of the African Blackwood are substantial!

The tree is a nitrogen-fixing species and improves soil fertility - making it an important component to the ecosystem of Tanzania. The carbon-rich black heart of the tree is uniquely dark because of the extraordinary amount of carbon absorbed by the tree relative to other types of trees. Forests are often called the ‘lungs of the earth’ because of the role they play in removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and providing oxygen. The African Blackwood tree is like a carbon vacuum for the environment. 

When harvested, the estimated value of the tree nurseries is over one million U.S. dollars.  The trees are owned and cared for by the students and staff at each school; schools will use the value of the harvest to improve infrastructure and the overall educational environment for their students.

These students (above) are all seeing and hearing the clarinet for the first time!  The students are actively engaged with the music by participating in conducting activities.  

After performances, the students swarm around the teachers, their curiosity of the clarinet and the music it makes is incredible!  Every school has asked us, "will you please bring clarinets to our school so that we can learn?"

The Korongoni Secondary School students (below) are learning how to play the clarinet.  Currently, there are more than 30 students and a few staff members taking part in the C4C program at Korongoni Secondary School.  

If you'd like to know more about what we do in Tanzania and the United States, check out this PBS feature: "Harvesting Music in Tanzania" 

Clarinets for Conservation: Harvesting Music in Tanzania

Please help us bring educational opportunities to the students of Korongoni Secondary school by making a donation today!  And remember to share this with your friends and family, musicians and conservationists.  


Thank you for checking out our campaign.  Asante sana!  ____________________________________________________________________

Keep up with us on Facebook and our website www.clarinetsforconservation.org
story_txt:
Utilizing the transformative power of music to encourage creativity and the protection of natural resources.

Clarinets for Conservation is gearing up for its 5th annual Tanzania program and we need your help to make this the most successful year yet! 

We offer a unique educational
opportunity to K-12 students by teaching music, conservation, and sustainability while planting African Blackwood trees in one of the least developed countries in the world, Tanzania.  
Your donation is critical to making
this experience possible. In order to take our students on tree plantings and educational trips we need $2,570.                            Your contribution is 100% tax-deductible!
_____________________________________________________________________________Funds from this campaign will cover the
following costs: 

Mpingo seedlings (600 will be planted at 16 different planting sites)
Conservationist teaching stipends
Transportation to tree planting sites
Transportation to conservation field trip sites 

_____________________________________________________________________________


WHAT DOES THE
CLARINET HAVE TO DO WITH CONSERVATION? 
The African Blackwood is Tanzania’s
national tree.  It is extremely valuable to musicians, the economy, and
the environment. Prized for its tone and resiliency, the black heartwood is
used in the manufacture of many instruments including: clarinets, oboes,
piccolos, violins and guitars, and piano keys. 
African
Blackwood is a commercially endangered resource.  
What does it mean to be a commercially
endangered resource? It means that the mature trees have been harvested at a
rate faster than the time it takes for seedling trees to reach maturation. The
international demand for Blackwood is greater than the resources
available. 



WHAT DOES C4C DO IN TANZANIA?
In 2010, one teacher traveled to
Tanzania with 12 clarinets and the idea to teach both music and conservation.
For the first time in history, the product (clarinets) were brought back to the
product source (East Africa) and used as a creative interdisciplinary
tool. Musical skills where taught and African Blackwood trees were planted.
Teaching secondary students in
Tanzania to play the clarinet empowers them by improving problem-solving
skills, facilitating self sufficiency, and by providing a healthy creative
outlet.
Students of Korongoni Secondary and
C4C teachers take part in innovative interdisciplinary performances and tree
plantings throughout Tanzania to help connect the African Blackwood tree and
the clarinet to the community – therefore fostering a sincere desire for a
sustainable future.
A majority of
Tanzanians have never heard or seen the clarinet. 


The environmental benefits of the African Blackwood are substantial!



The tree is a nitrogen-fixing species and improves
soil fertility - making it an important component to the ecosystem of Tanzania.
The carbon-rich black heart of the tree is uniquely dark because of the
extraordinary amount of carbon absorbed by the tree relative to other types of
trees. Forests are often called the ‘lungs of the earth’ because of the role
they play in removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and providing oxygen. The
African Blackwood tree is like a carbon vacuum for the environment. 

When harvested, the estimated value
of the tree nurseries is over one million U.S. dollars.  The trees are
owned and cared for by the students and staff at each school; schools will use
the value of the harvest to improve infrastructure and the overall educational
environment for their students.





These students (above) are all seeing
and hearing the clarinet for the first time!  The students are actively
engaged with the music by participating in conducting activities.  
After performances, the students
swarm around the teachers, their curiosity of the clarinet and the music it
makes is incredible!  Every school has asked us, "will you please
bring clarinets to our school so that we can learn?"
The Korongoni Secondary School
students (below) are learning how to play the clarinet.  Currently, there
are more than 30 students and a few staff members taking part in the C4C
program at Korongoni Secondary School.  


If you'd like to know more about what we do in Tanzania and the United States, check out this PBS feature: "Harvesting Music in Tanzania" Clarinets for Conservation: Harvesting Music in TanzaniaPlease help us bring educational opportunities to the students of Korongoni Secondary school by making a donation today!  And remember to share this with your friends and family, musicians and conservationists.  



Thank you for checking out our
campaign.  Asante sana!  ____________________________________________________________________
Keep up with us on Facebook and our website www.clarinetsforconservation.org

story:
Goal of this trip and the future of Hawaii:

The goals of this trip is to support the Hawaii Bicycling League's efforts to create the cycle track, safe bike lanes by networking on bicycle around the island with our Pedal-Powered Musical offerings.

The desire is to create a movement towards more people on the island sharing the bike lanes and getting involved in the 'bike-movement' that is happening on the island of Oahu, Hawaii. We are doing outreach in the following ways:

  • This will create a launching party for the new safe Bike Lane on King Street in Honolulu with the Mayor Kirk Caldwell supporting by speaking through the pedal-powered system we are bringing from California.
  • Creating a buzz about bikes on the island and the fun of the trip sharing music and culture while getting from point 'a' to 'b' by bicycle, carrying our instruments, speakers, and gear as we go
  • FINALLY - create the buzz to officially make the Bicycle Music Festival happen in Hawaii in December 2015, which is a $40,000 budget!
Your contributions will help create a movement that can turn into actualizing less traffic on the H1, safer bike lanes for young and old to enjoy, and a cleaner, more sustainable environment for the future of Hawaii and conscious lifestyles and tourism. Our goal is to bring the complete system of Rock The Bike and the Bicycle Music Festival to Hawaii at it's fullest magnitude to create the most impact we can on the people we encounter, as well as create a final show December 2015 with 3,000 + attendees. Your support will make this happen!

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a take on what we need and what you get, as quick and efficient as we can say it:

  • We need funds for bringing the appropriate custom speaker system, musicians, and contributions to get the people to the event(s) with a PR campaign, 
  • We are offering free compilation downloads of all the musicians involved, as well as Pedal-Powered compilation Rock The Bike CDs. We also can supply 'house concerts' for 2015, next trip we are in town. 
  • The funds will start from the top of this list and the more we get, the more we can fund: Food costs, Flyer/Poster Promotion, Bike Support and shipping costs, Expenses of travel for videographers, Expenses of travel for musicians.
  • As of now, we are coming out of pocket for the Pedal power, shipping, printing, food, and all travel and performance costs. Your contribution will directly support us balancing our budget so that we can come full-force for 2015. 

The Impact

This campaign is one way we are combating global warming. We believe that there is no better solution in transportation then the bicycle for local transportation for work, school, and daily activities. The reasoning behind this is through scrutinous studies on biodiesel, fuel cell, electric, and hybrid vehicle options. Some basic value listings of this work are:

  • finding a way to decrease the carbon footprint of society
  • Increase road safety for bikers
  • decrease vehicle congestion on Oahu

Risks & Challenges

There is a risk in investing 4+ years of work into creating a movement on Oahu and being located in Northern California. As well, the investment of time and money into something that has not ever been done before is frightening. These challenges are met by the following qualifications:

  • Passion for the environment and ties of local family on the island, making this a personal story. 
  • We are in close connection with the Hawaii Bicycle League, the longest running Bike Coalition of the Islands, and we working towards more partnerships with local municipalities, businesses, and movers-and-shakers such as Kirk Caldwell, Mayor of Honolulu and bike advocate himself.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that funds aren't always an option for contributing to the efforts of bringing safe bike lanes and riders to the island, so here are some other ways you can help out:

  • Tell friends about the campaign, sharing on facebook and other social media, and/or personally emailing friends and family to engage in the pleasant revolution.
  • IndieGogo has created share tools to make it easy to 'share' this page, so please take advantage of this. We also have more information at: www.soulgraffiti.info on how you might be able to participate in the future or come to one of the events being held by one of the many musicians involved in this artist for artist label 'for the environment'. 

Thank you for your time and for helping with this project.

story:
DAS RECHT AUF WASSER IST EIN GRUNDRECHT

Die Broschüre in deutsch: https://www.dropbox.com/s/k9gqtepiq6moqgg/wasser_ist_grundrecht.pdf
The flyer in english: https://www.dropbox.com/s/53ykf09ky3579zc/wasser_is_a_fundamental_right.pdf

Privatisierung würde das Leben versiegen lassen

Wasser ist Leben. Wasser schafft Leben und ist somit eine Grundvoraussetzung für Existenz. Deshalb setze ich mich mit all meinen Möglichkeiten ein, das Wasser für jeden frei zugänglich ist bzw. wieder frei zugänglich gemacht wird. Eine Privatisierung und somit auch ein Kontrolle von
Wasserquellen könnte fatale Folgen haben:

  1. Wasser wird teurer, sogar unbezahlbar

    Leben wie Produktion benötigen sauberes Wasser. Wird Wasser zur Ware, sind beide in Gefahr, denn viele werden sich Wasser bzw. sauberes Wasser nicht mehr leisten können.

  2. Wasser wird künstlich verknappt

    Wie jede Handelsware unterliegt Wasser, wenn es gewinnbringend vermarktet wird, den Gesetzen der Marktwirtschaft. Insbesondere künstliche Verknappung ist ein Instrument, mit dem sehr vielen der Zugang zu Wasser versperrt werden kann.

  3. Wasser wird manipuliert

    Bereits in den 60er Jahren belegten Versuchsreihen in Amerika, dass durch den Zusatz von Chemikalien (Silberjodid) in der Atmosphäre das Wetter beeinflusst werden kann. Über das Regenwasser wurden sowohl Boden und zeitlich versetzt das Grundwasser stark kontaminiert. Heute nennt man es Chemtrailing, was täglich am Himmel beobachtet werden kann.

  4. Die Qualität wird schlechter

    Wenn Wartungs- und Erneuerungszyklen zugunsten Gewinnmaximierung keiner geregelten Kontrolle unterliegen, wird die Wasserqualität immer schlechter. Die Folge: Marode Leitungswege, zu erwartende Umweltschäden. Unreines Wasser kann zudem nachhaltige Schäden an den Maschinen erzeugen, die auf Wasser im Herstellungsverfahren angewiesen sind.

  5. Privatisiertes Wasser wird teurer

    Nur zwei Beispiele: Die Wasserwirtschaft in Portugal und in Frankreich „erzeugten“ Preissteigerungen innerhalb von x Jahren von 400% bzw. 250%.

  6. Wasser wird zum Monopol

    Die Erfahrung zeigt: Erzeugen mehrere Unternehmen das gleiche Produkt, werden Preisabsprachen begünstigt. Und diese umschreiben eine zunehmende Monopolisierung.

  7. Das empfindliche Ökosystem wird geschwächt Nur ein Beispiel: die Rodung von Regenwäldern bringt den Weg des Wassers durch die Oberflächenzerstörung aus dem natürlichen Weg. Um sauberes Wasser zu gewinnen, muss immer tiefer gebohrt werden. Wasser wird immer teurer somit für viele unbezahlbar.

 

Ich möchte auf die Folgen einer verfehlten Wasser-wirtschaft ein Zeichen setzen.


Deshalb starte ich in der Woche vom 4.6.2013 zu Fuß zum Nordkap (Norwegen). Ein Pilgerweg wird mich dann bis nach Finisterre in Galizien führen. Auf diesem Weg dürfen Sie mich begleiten. Durch Zusprache, durch intensiven Gedankenaustausch und durch Ihre Unterstützung.

Ziel ist es auf die Problematik der Privatisierung der Wasserquellen aufmerksam zu machen.

Sie können mit mir diesen Weg gemeinsam gehen, wenn Sie meinen Weg für wichtig betrachten. Mit Ihrem Sponsoring tragen Sie einen entscheidenden Beitrag zum Gelingen bei. 

FÜR FREIES WASSER GEH ICH MEILENWEIT!

Mit Ihrer Unterstützung, dank Ihres Sponsoring

FREIES WASSER. JEDERZEIT.

Für alle Menschen. An jedem Ort. Auf dieser Welt.

story:
WHO ARE WE:

A molecular biologist studying herbal medicine and a mexican guy studying permaculture and eco-construction. We decided to start an itinerant project from PANAMA, Chiriqui Province, spreading knowledge (and seeds!) about medical plants use, permaculture and renewable energies in the communities we meet along the way. The idea of a traveling Ecovillage looks as smart as it is in order to keep the project affordable and not invasive for the indigenous culture. Indeed, the core of the project is to promote independence and sustainability in these areas, spreading awareness, ecocreativity, biodiversity and harmony with nature.

 

WHAT´S THIS ABOUT:

  By using the facilities of local farms and no-profit organizations, the Learning Centre is able to offer several courses and workshops on Herbal and Folkloric medicine, Ecodesign and Eco-construction, Bike Maintainance, Biodiversity, DIY solar panels. Training, practical work sessions on farms and gardens using the resources of the forest according to sustainability principles. This will help the communities to create an alternative job system and life style, promoting independence and decentralization. After an adequate training and a warm-up period, the project will be supported by locals: they will be able to activate and mantain the network independently. It allows the itinerant project to rapidly recycle itself for a new venture.

 

WHAT WE ARE HOPING FOR:

  Harmony with the Earth we inhabit, resilience from the modern oil age and decentralization for a better local network..and of course Love and Light for everyone :)

 

WHAT WE NEED:

  Simply and clearly we aim to mantain this itinerancy and to avoid any form of property and land occupancy, this would help to be focused on the real purpose and save money! We need basic materials and gardening tools for the permaculture workshops, seeds and materials for building medical plants garden beds, a clayoven and a dehydrator for herbs. Other expenses will be the living costs and books, solar panels and bikes.

 

JOIN US:

  You will be able to follow all our courses and workshops online, visiting the existing Ecovillages and Learning Centres and actively partecipate. Our first project would start in Panama, Chiriqui Province, an area enclosed in a rainforest with a pro-active rural community. We will co-operate with "DESAROLLO RURAL DE PANAMA'" and will use the facilities around GUALACA VILLAGE. Courses will start as soon as we will reach the goal. 

Please, feel free to ask for more info.

Thank you in advance for your help.

"From right where you are, your love will change the world"

 

UPDATE:


Hey guys!!

We are very happy to inform you that we have successfully delivered the first two workshops about Permaculture and Medicinal Plants in the small town of Gualaca, Chiriquí, Panamá.

We had a great response from the people of the community. Soon, we will start some practical workshops on the elaboration of compost, organic fertilizers, herbal tinctures with local medicinal plants, etc., etc.

We would like to thank you for all your support!! Please continue helping us and spread the word!!

Love and Light

 

Here are some pictures of the workshops:

story:
I made it to my goal with over 2 weeks left!

Thank you to all my funders and supporters who made this possible!

I will be in touch with everyone next month to make sure perks can be delivered successfully. Thanks again and so excited about what this means for permaculture at Texas State!

Please feel free to contact me about anything, and if you care to contribute more it will go straight to the Permaculture Committee at Texas State.
[:

_____________________________________________________________________

Campaign purpose:

My name is Katie Tritsch. I'm a recent graduate of Texas State University - San Marcos. During my last few semesters I founded and served as president for a permaculture student organization called PERMIES. We held many educational meetings, workshops, documentary nights, etc. to spread the word of permaculture!

I wrote an undergraduate thesis entitled, "Moving Beyond Sustainability at Institutes of Higher Education: The Potential of a Permaculture Initiative at Texas State" which received a lot of positive feedback, including from the folks at UMass Permaculture. 
My thesis can be found here: https://digital.library.txstate.edu/handle/10877/4474

I'm currently helping a dedicated group of young leaders form a Permaculture Committee at Texas State and have been invited to give a lightning talk about our initiative's progress at the UMass Permaculture Your Campus Conference this June 23-26. 
More about the conference here:
http://www.umasspermacultureconference.com/

 

Please help fund my travels and make Fall 2013 the semester that brings Texas State University a student-run permaculture garden on campus!

 

Where does the money go?

Funding this campaign will allow me to travel from San Marcos, TX to Amherst, MA and back. (About $450 for plane tickets and cab rides, $150 for lodging)

My attendance gives the Permaculture Committee at Texas State a chance to network with other colleges, universities, and permaculturists who can help us ensure our initiative's success. We have found so much support among students, faculty, and staff; nothing could be more meaningful than to share our struggles, strategies, and success stories with others.

If you donate and I DON'T get near my goal funds will go straight to the Permaculture Committee at Texas State and the permaculture garden we will be campaigning for this fall!

Anything helps!

If you can't donate, please spread the word! This would mean so much for Texas State, central Texas permaculture folks, and me.

 

*A note on perks: I apologize for not having the graphics in digital form for the buttons and t-shirts, but will get them on here ASAP!

We held many educational meetings, workshops, documentary nights, etc. to spread the word of permaculture!
I wrote an undergraduate thesis entitled, "Moving Beyond Sustainability at Institutes of Higher Education: The Potential of a Permaculture Initiative at Texas State" which received a lot of positive feedback, including from the folks at UMass Permaculture. My thesis can be found here: https://digital.library.txstate.edu/handle/10877/4474
I'm currently helping a dedicated group of young leaders form a Permaculture Committee at Texas State and have been invited to give a lightning talk about our initiative's progress at the UMass Permaculture Your Campus Conference this June 23-26. More about the conference here:http://www.umasspermacultureconference.com/
 
Please help fund my travels and make Fall 2013 the semester that brings Texas State University a student-run permaculture garden on campus!
 


Where does the money go?
Funding this campaign will allow me to travel from San Marcos, TX to Amherst, MA and back. (About $450 for plane tickets and cab rides, $150 for lodging)
My attendance gives the Permaculture Committee at Texas State a chance to network with other colleges, universities, and permaculturists who can help us ensure our initiative's success. We have found so much support among students, faculty, and staff; nothing could be more meaningful than to share our struggles, strategies, and success stories with others.
If you donate and I DON'T get near my goal funds will go straight to the Permaculture Committee at Texas State and the permaculture garden we will be campaigning for this fall!


Anything helps!
If you can't donate, please spread the word! This would mean so much for Texas State, central Texas permaculture folks, and me.
 
*A note on perks: I apologize for not having the graphics in digital form for the buttons and t-shirts, but will get them on here ASAP!

story:
===================

*****UPDATE*****

The roadtrip has now been cancelled due to lack of funds. Thank you heaps to the contributors and sorry to not be able to put your donations to work on this, but rest assured it’ll still be spent on solarflower related activities.
I think at this stage I’m off to Paris to start an urban farming collective based on the greenhouse design ( http://urbangreenhouse.blogspot.com ) and other technologies.
Which isn’t such a bad fallback position, tho it would’ve been nice to tour us some festivals. O well.

Then, after the summer, start in on the world tour, probably heading through Turkey to the middle east and Asia. So stay tuned. You can follow all this on http://solarflower.blogspot.com

And thanks once again for your support. I’ll see you amongst it.


====================


After a year and a half of prototyping, the SolarFlower is now ready for beta release.

It's an open source solar energy device which can be made from recycled materials by anyone anywhere, practically for free using very basic tools and skills. It is powerful, efficient, has no emissions, requires no fuel and little maintenance.


The device uses a simple non electrical mechanism to accurately track the sun and collect energy, which can then be used for generating electricity, heating or purifying water, cooking, producing bio-char, or anything else heat can be used for.

Full animated tutorials will be available for free from the website; http://www.solarflower.org


Now that the device is working the next step for the project is to increase awareness of it, and so we'll be spending the summer touring European ecovillages, communities and festivals, offering hot showers and free workshops on the device's construction.This has the potential to put us in contact with up to tens of thousands of people, who would otherwise be unaware that these solutions and technologies exist, and that they can easily make them themselves.


For this we need funds.


Appropriate technologies like this; which work, are free and open and accessible to the world, have the potential to fundamentally change the way in which we produce energy, food, water, communications, community and almost everything else.

Then the tour heads through Turkey and the Middle East, through Asia to the Pacific.


Budget:


The costs of this leg of the trip will likely break down as follows:

€ 1,000 fuel for the vehicle

€ 300 salary for participants

€ 300 food and other expenses

€ 400 vehicle maintenance, contingencies, etc.


Accommodation will be mostly ecovillages, festivals etc who will host us as support of the project. Other than that a mix of couchsurfing and tents.


If the funding goal is not fully met the money will still be used for the expenses that arise during the trip, which will be happening either way, the shortfall coming from the project. However, as we have no funding sources besides personal savings, this will likely cut short the trip, which we were hoping to be doing for the next 2-3 years.


Other Ways You Can Help:


More info here:

http://www.solarflower.blogspot.com

Facebook group: http://www.facebook.com/home.php?sk=group_184038684971498&ap=1

Facebook event: http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=166441523415416


Please proliferate this via social media, invite your friends, et cetera.


And if you really want to be amongst it, join the open source hardware community and start building your own energy devices.


Other projects:


An ultra simple to construct, high volume greenhouse:

http://urbangreenhouse.blogspot.com


A non-electrical cooling system for homes and growing spaces:

http://urbangreenhouse.blogspot.com/2011_03_01_archive.html


And a non-turbine resonant wind generator, but this remains to be prototyped just yet.


These and other projects we also hope to promote and develop this summer.


Thank you for your time, and for all the support received. It makes this fun.

story:
CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand -- A powerful earthquake struck New Zealand's already-bruised city of Christchurch on Tuesday, collapsing buildings, burying vehicles under debris and sending rescuers scrambling to help trapped people amid reports of multiple deaths.

The 6.3-magnitude quake hit the country's second-biggest city on a busy weekday afternoon and closer to downtown than a major quake that damaged Christchurch last September but caused no deaths when it struck before dawn on a weekend.


Police said there were reports of multiple fatalities from the latest temblor in the city of 350,000, while Prime Minister John Key told Parliament it was still too soon to confirm the deaths.


The quake destroyed the spire of the iconic stone Christchurch Cathedral, which toppled into a central city square, and police said there was a report of two buses crushed under falling buildings.


Video footage showed some multistory buildings collapsed in on themselves, and others with walls that had collapsed into the streets, strewn with bricks and shattered concrete. Sidewalks and roads were cracked and split, and thousands of dazed, screaming and crying residents wandered through the streets as sirens blared. Groups of people helped victims clutching bleedings wounds, and others were carried to private vehicles in makeshift stretchers fashioned from rugs or bits of debris.


Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker declared a state of emergency and ordered people to evacuate the city center. Troops were deployed to help people get out and to throw up a security cordon around the stricken area, said Deputy Prime Minister Bill English.


"Make no mistake -- this is going to be a very black day for this shaken city," Parker said when asked about possible deaths

What We Need 

This project will pass on all contributions to a combination of the Salvation Army support services and one of the major trading banks relief funds.


Other Ways You Can Help

Pass this on to friends, work colleagues and total strangers!


This is a major disaster that is effecting many New Zealanders.

story:
Help Us Finish Boise's First Enviromentally Friendly Taxi Cab Fleet

Wouldn't it be nice to have the comfort of knowing that you are eliminating greenhouse gas emmisions while riding in the comfort of one of our luxury Mercedes taxi cabs.

Here at ReCab we recycle early 80’s Mercedes Benz Diesels, and run bio-diesel made from waste vegetable oil sourced from local restaurants.

Each cab give a nostalgic ride back to a time when elegance, comfort, and reliability were paramount all while eliminating nearly 30,000 lbs of CO2 from the atmosphere annually.

Carbon Footprint of a Traditional Taxi Cab

Most Taxi Cabs out there are Crown Victorias and they average around 16 mpg in town.  Over the span of a 5 year lifecycle of one of these cabs will emmit 181,875 lbs of CO2.

  37,500 lbs       +  5 years  x  28,875 lbs/year    =   181,875 lbs of CO2

Car Production            Tailpipe Emmissions               Total CO2 emmissions

Carbon Footprint of a ReCab

At ReCab we recycle cars and veggie oil.  By using these 30-year-old Mercedes, we are eliminating the carbon dioxide associated with manufacturing a new vehicle.  

We also operate in a closed loop Carbon Dioxide Cycle meaning any CO2 we emmit into the atmosphere is offset by the CO2 pulled out by the plants that are turned into Veggie Oil.               

The Impact

You have the opportunity to make a significant difference.  Every dollar you donate to this project, will offset 28lbs of CO2 emmissions.

What Can You Do? 

We are trying to raise $19,500 to put another 3 ReCabs in service by summer 2013.  For every $6,500 we raise, we will put another ReCab on the road.  All funds will be applied towards the production of more of these eco-friendly cabs.

Here's what your contributions will be used for:

  • $2,400 - Car Purchase
  • $1,200 - Paint 
  • $1,000 - Bio Diesel Conversion
  • $400 - Restoration
  • $1000 - Taxi Insurance
  • $300 - Sinage/Meters/Topight
  • $200 - Licensing

How Else Can You Get Involved

We are looking for restaurants willing to trade their waste veggie oil for advertisement on top of our cab so hit us up with any restraunt connections.

Make ReCab your transoprt of choice.

Share Share Share!  Let as many people know about thisReCab and this crowdfunding project as you can.

At ReCab we love new ideas.  Let us know if you have any other inovative ideas to partner with or support ReCab.

Press

Boise Weekly

CNN

KTVB

story:
Travel with Bob and his nephew Joey on the biggest journey of our lives. We are signed up for the MR 340, the longest continuing canoe race in the world. http://rivermiles.com/mr340/information/

Our boat name is "Bob's Friends". Be one of our friends and ride down the river with us for 340 miles.

Our trip from training, planing, racing, post race will be documented in pictures.

We are just looking to be sponsored by 340 friends of $10. Thats only $10 per mile. Approximately $1800.00 of the funds will be used for a newer canoe, Photography equipment, other equipment, fees, and support of our ground crew. I have already started a major fitness/weight loss program while Joey is in pretty good shape already. While training for and while on our race we will be doing a video blog on our progress. For any donation amount of $10 and up, your name will be on the side of our canoe in 1/2 inch lettering so you can be one of Bob's Friends and travel with us. You will also receive the link to follow us during the race. Our team name is Bob's Friends, be a friend and come on our journey with us. All funds over our estimatedexpenses of 1800.00 will go to Missouri River Relief. www.riverrelief.org
