story:
Be a part of developing 

THE ELECTRIC SAFARI VEHICLE OF THE FUTURE

Imagine being in a silent safari vehicle that makes you feel as if you are outside on foot, face to face with a lion, elephant or cheetah.

Welcome to Ol Pejeta Conservancy

A 90,000 acre home to one hundred endangered black rhino, four of the last seven northern white rhino in existence, and a sanctuary for predators: lion, leopard and cheetah.


We believe in conservation you can touch. 

Ol Pejeta is always on the lookout for new and better ways to protect the wildlife and environment, whilst at the same time engaging our 80,000 visitors a year. We want to bridge the gap between scientist and tourist. 

But it is a constant struggle to balance the wilderness, wildlife and tourists.

In the beginning safaris were done on foot.  Then on horseback.  Then by vehicle.  And there the innovation stopped. Vehicles are vital for getting around but they can be noisy and intrusive.

We believe it is time for change!  

Why not vehicles that make the wildlife viewing experience better and more educational?  

Why not vehicles that intrude less on the wildlife, sometimes disrupting predator hunts, depriving them of food?  

Why not vehicles with a smaller footprint on the ground they cross? 

Why not vehicles with zero emissions into the fresh air?

Ol Pejeta has teamed up with the world famous Royal College of Art Vehicle Design Programme, and with Green Automotive, makers of the first electric Liberty Range Rover, to create the Safari Vehicle of the Future.

The twelve strong team will focus on three areas for improvement:

  1. VIEWING: creating an improved cabin to sit in, with an all round, uninterrupted line of sight that makes you feel as if you are on foot or horseback.  Closer to nature.
  2. IMPACT: exploring a hybrid electric-diesel solution that will allow silent safaris with zero emissions, and which can travel off-road with minimum foot-print.
  3. EDUCATION: enhancing the wealth of fascinating information about the flora and fauna on view, and the information being provided by guides.

The Royal College of Art will be developing design ideas for the overall vehicle.  Green Automotive have kindly agreed to act as electric/hybrid advisors and should funding be sufficient to also provide production at cost.

We have set the IndieGoGo amount to raise enough to be able to complete the design and blueprint process: a total of $50,000.

We would like though to raise a total of $150,000 so that we can create and operate the first prototype on Ol Pejeta.

PLEASE NOTE - IMPORTANT:  Constantly looking for innovative ways to improve conservation and tourism is not easy.  These things can take longer and cost more than initially planned.  Our previous project, a new Aerial Ranger Drone, for example is still underway.  If you would like to support us we will be incredibly grateful and will regularly communicate updates on progress.  Please bear in mind though that you are supporting something new and fresh and it will take time to bear fruits.

In the event that we raise more than the design process but less than prototype production then rewards will continue to be honoured and the funds will go towards ongoing conservation innovation on Ol Pejeta.

story:
Why do we need to help seabirds?

You may have seen photos of Hawaiian albatrosses full of plastic, but did you know the same thing is happening HERE in Australia right now?? 

Dr. Jennifer Lavers found  270 pieces of plastic inside this 80 day old Flesh-footed shearwater chick. She's also found that 100% of this species on Lord Howe Island contain plastic.

Populations have already declined by more than 50% in the past 35 years. We need to find out more, before it's too late.


Who are we?

Two Hands Project

In less than 3 years the ‘Two Hands’ concept has gone worldwide, with over 35,000 fans on Facebook alone, this gives a reach of around 400 000 per week.

It continues to grow, inspiring and encouraging people to clean their own patch of park, lake, beach or coastline and post a photo showing the rubbish collected with just their two hands in 30 minutes …

This simple idea both records what was found and recognizes others cleaning up polluted waterways and coastlines all over the world. Even better, it connects community groups, schools, individuals, businesses and local authorities with their local area through regular involvement. The best bit of all: this results in changes in behaviour and attitudes to the way we ‘consume’ plastic. 


The Two Hands Team

The Two Hands Project  is a not-for-profit organisation run entirely by volunteers.

The seabird team is made up of:

Paul has worked hands on in marine education and shark conservation for over 20 years. Some of the awesome things he's done on this journey include co-founding the award-winning Two Hands Project in 2010, sailing and researching tsunami debris in the North Pacific Garbage Patch and creating a touring 'Shark in a Bus' to provide marine education.

Silke is the other Two Hands founder and an award winning photographer, Australian Seabird Rescue volunteer and winner of the Manly Environment Eco-Award for her pioneering campaigns to stop plastic pollution. She spends her 'spare' time running clean ups, doing education programs and making plastic pollution displays.

Alice is a conservation biologist and serial volunteer. Her adventures in conservation have taken her from hanging out with monkeys in Bolivian jungles, to feeding sharks in Sydney, to photographing whales and trawling for plastic in the Indian Ocean, to talking to huge rooms of rowdy school children.


Dr Jenn Lavers

Dr Jenn Lavers is a conservation biologist and bird lover who studies the impacts of plastic pollution on seabirds. You might have seen her on the ABC or read about her in Australian Geographic or the Sydney Morning Herald. She is completely in love with the fleshfooted shearwaters and is passionate about saving them, before it's too late.

What are we doing?

Funding is urgently needed for research on remote islands off Western Australia. We want to study how seabirds on these islands are being affected and provide much needed data to raise awareness about the extent of this issue. 

Your money will go towards: 

  • Vital research into the effects of plastic pollution on Australian seabirds such as the flesh footed shearwater
  • Education and raising awareness about this huge problem
  • Ongoing research on Australia’s seabirds

We need enough to cover transport, accommodation and equipment. Nothing fancy, just return economy flights, car rental (to get from Perth to Albany as well as doing workshops in coastal towns on the way), and camp-site fees. Anything extra that we raise will go towards future projects and education programs at public events and schools.


What can you do?

Every dollar gets us closer to our goal, so if you can afford to donate we'd appreciate anything you can give. For $30 we'll clean a beach just for you and for $60 you can get one of these awesome, limited edition Save Our Seabird reusable CHEEKI drink bottles. The bottles will be sent out in time for Christmas so they'll make great presents for any of your friends or family who are still buying plastic water bottles!

You can also share our campaign on Facebook or Twitter and help us get the word out. And of course, say NO to "disposable" plastics - there is no excuse for single use!

The Two Hands Team




The Two Hands Project  is a not-for-profit organisation run entirely by volunteers. The seabird team is made up of: Paul has worked hands on in marine education and shark conservation for over 20 years. Some of the awesome things he's done on this journey include co-founding the award-winning Two Hands Project in 2010, sailing and researching tsunami debris in the North Pacific Garbage Patch and creating a touring 'Shark in a Bus' to provide marine education. 
Silke is the other Two Hands founder and an award winning photographer, Australian Seabird Rescue volunteer and winner of the Manly Environment Eco-Award for her pioneering campaigns to stop plastic pollution. She spends her 'spare' time running clean ups, doing education programs and making plastic pollution displays. 
Alice is a conservation biologist and serial volunteer. Her adventures in conservation have taken her from hanging out with monkeys in Bolivian jungles, to feeding sharks in Sydney, to photographing whales and trawling for plastic in the Indian Ocean, to talking to huge rooms of rowdy school children. 
Dr Jenn Lavers

Dr Jenn Lavers is a conservation biologist and bird lover who studies the impacts of plastic pollution on seabirds. You might have seen her on the ABC or read about her in Australian Geographic or the Sydney Morning Herald. She is completely in love with the fleshfooted shearwaters and is passionate about saving them, before it's too late. 







What are we doing? 



Funding is urgently needed for research on remote islands
off Western Australia. We want to study how seabirds on these islands are being
affected and provide much needed data to raise awareness about the extent of
this issue.  
Your money will go towards:  


Vital research into the effects of plastic
pollution on Australian seabirds such as the flesh footed shearwater
Education and raising awareness about this huge
problem
Ongoing research on Australia’s seabirds




We need enough to cover transport, accommodation and equipment. Nothing fancy, just return economy flights, car rental (to get from Perth to Albany as well as doing workshops in coastal towns on the way), and camp-site fees. Anything extra that we raise will go towards future projects and education programs at public events and schools. 
What can you do?

Every dollar gets us closer to our goal, so if you can afford to donate we'd appreciate anything you can give. For $30 we'll clean a beach just for you and for $60 you can get one of these awesome, limited edition Save Our Seabird reusable CHEEKI drink bottles. The bottles will be sent out in time for Christmas so they'll make great presents for any of your friends or family who are still buying plastic water bottles! 

You can also share our campaign on Facebook or Twitter and help us get the word out. And of course, say NO to "disposable" plastics - there is no excuse for single use!

story:
My name is Sami and I am the videographer for Paddle Forward. 

Fear.

This is what you need to know first: I am frequently afraid. But there’s more. Because I’m also frequently brave.

We all are. We have to be brave because we are all taught and encouraged to be afraid. We live in a society that promotes and profits from fear. Some of us are more entrenched, and more targeted, than others, but we all live in this culture of fear. To survive and thrive, cultures of fear must teach children fears. Fears of strangers, fears of crowds, fears of cities and suburbs, fears of peers and teachers, fears of faces, genders, and darkness. But how many of these fears are rational? How many keep us safe? And from what?

I couldn’t possibly trace all the origins of my courage. Much comes from my family, much from my friends, some even from my cat. But there is one fear, however, that I can distinctly remember choosing to battle: a fear of nature. Such a strange fear, such a strange statement, as if I am not natural, but this is not an uncommon message. Many people are indoctrinated with this dichotomy: indoors or outdoors, rural or urban, wild or tame. 

I chose to fight this fear out of necessity. I was at camp and I was miserable. I was scared of the bugs, the owls, the dirt, the rain, the grass, the space, the smells, everything. And I realized, with quite a bit of help, that I was in control of that discomfort. I didn’t need to be afraid. It was a choice, but a choice I’d have never gotten to make if I hadn’t found myself on a camping trip in a downpour in the southern Appalachians.

Almost 15 years later and I’m still afraid of many things. But I refuse to be frightened into submission. I refuse to be bullied. I have made a habit of fighting back. And of encouraging others, particularly children, to fight back too. Eventually, I led the camping trips and when, in the middle of a storm, a child came to me with so much fear, I tried to take that fear gently from his or her hands and replace it with a choice.

So...What does this have to do with Paddling the Mississippi River?

Well, the trip itself is a rejection of fear. But it is my goal is to take a personal rejection and create a public renouncement.

As we travel downstream, we will be filming. Everything! But in particular, we will be stopping to interview basically anyone we meet along the river about the river. We will talk to the interviewees about the history of the Mighty Mississippi, the legends and the lore. We will talk about the river as a resource then and a resource now, for commerce, irrigation, transportation, sanitation. We will talk about the impact of industry and agriculture and how our current needs will affect future river communities. We will talk about weather and fishing and politics and food. The point is: we will talk.

The best way to dispel fear is to talk about it. 

And these are conversations worth having. There are hundreds of thousands of people worth listening to. Everyone, in fact. And though this documentary will cover only a small subset of the populations reliant upon the Mississippi River, it is a start. A beginning. A moment that we can look back on and say, yes, that was the moment that I listened and in that moment, no one was afraid.


What We Need 

So the breakdown is pretty simple.  First and foremost, I need to eat.  I’m asking $720 for all of my food expenses.

Food for one day:

$9

Food for one week:

$63

Food for one month:

$279

Food for the whole trip:

$720

While it would be nice if there were no other expenses, there are.  Both myself and my canoe need to come back to Minneapolis in one piece.  The breakdown is as such:

Ship a canoe to Minneapolis

$130

Pay for one person to travel back to the Twin Cities

$150

                                                                         Total Trip Cost:        $1,000

What You Get


$25 – A HUGE hug and a postcard from somewhere along the river. My standard hug is pretty big, so just be prepared. Also lots of karma points.

$50 – A shout-out to you or your organization on our Twitter and Facebook with a picture of me featuring your name or company. Plus a HUGE hug and a postcard from somewhere along the river. And a canoe-full of karma points.

$100 – Your name will be featured in the credits of our documentary. This could be your big break! Plus A HUGE hug, a postcard, and a photo shout-out, and a multitude of karma points.

$250 – A Paddle For Change t-shirt. Who doesn't love a good t-shirt?? Plus A GIGANTIC hug, a postcard, your name featured in the credits of our documentary, and a photo shout-out. And feel free to give yourself pats on the back at any time.

$500 - A copy of our finished documentary! Show it to your friends! Plus a Paddle For Change t-shirt, your name in the credits of our documentary, a photo shout-out, a postcard, a hug, and as many karma points as I can summon from the universe.

$1,000 – A copy of the finished documentary, a photo shout-out, a Paddle For Change t-shirt, your name in the credits of our documentary, a postcard, THE BIGGEST hug, and my eternal gratitude. And I will wish happy things for you for all of my birthday wishes from here on out.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not be able to contribute monetarily, but that doesn’t mean you can't help.  Please spread the word about our campaign by sharing this page on Facebook, Twitter, or any other social platform you prefer. Also, if you are a teacher or know of a classroom that would be interested in following us on our journey and tuning in to video chats with us, let us know!!

Send me a message if you think you have connections or information that may be helpful for us. Though our group has a great deal of paddling experience, we cannot do this without community support. We welcome your insight. 

http://paddle4ward.com/

https://www.facebook.com/paddle4ward

story:
What if you could make a difference and help save our place on the planet today?

What if the future of your children, their children, and your great-grandchildren was dependent on your making the right choice…right here, right now? Would you do it? 

Because that’s the big idea. Sometimes the biggest ideas are the simplest. Your gift of $50 today will plant one Champion Coast Redwood clone in 2015. Our goal is to plant 2000 of these trees in the coming year.

People around the world are starting to understand that climate change is not only real, but its impacts are imminent and will become more severe unless we make big changes now.  They are struggling to come up with solutions as natural disasters, extreme temperatures, and water shortages threaten people and species everywhere. At Archangel Ancient Tree Archive, we feel that one solution is far simpler than most think. 

But first, a little about us...

Quote © The Estate of R. Buckminster Fuller - Used with permission

About Archangel Ancient Tree Archive

Archangel Ancient Tree Archive, a 501(c)(3) non-profit, is the first organization in the world that locates and vegetatively propagates the world’s largest and most iconic trees. AATA is creating living libraries of old-growth tree genetics by cloning superior old-growth "Champion" trees through traditional and advanced horticultural propagation for the purpose of future research and functional reforestation.


The mission of Archangel Ancient Tree Archive is to:

  • Propagate the world’s most important old-growth trees before they are gone.
  • Archive the genetics of ancient trees in living libraries around the world for the future.
  • Reforest the Earth with the offspring of these trees to provide the myriad of beneficial ecosystem services including sequestering carbon dioxide; essentially a global warming solution.

We now have 2,000 Champion Coast Redwood cloned saplings ready to plant, but need your help.

The Archangel team has expended tremendous time and effort over the past six years to locate a wide variety of the largest and oldest ancient redwoods from across their 600 mile range. We have carefully and with great risk collected the specific tissue needed for the cloning process from the tops of these old giants, developed and then replicated the cloning process, and have raised these clones to an age where they are able to be transplanted back to a suitable forest setting. These ancient giants provide the exact replica DNA of the original old-growth parent trees to the world for planting. 

The saplings are growing robustly in Archangel’s Copemish, Michigan facility, and since they are now at their peak planting age, we need your help to get them from Michigan to appropriate planting locations around the world. These special clones are direct genetic copies of the original old-growth giants and once planted, will help genetically strengthen and expand the current range of Coast Redwoods. It's a crucial step in our plan for restoring the global forest.

  • Every gift of $50 helps to plant one Coast Redwood in the 2015 planting season. 
  • Your gift of any size will help us reach our goal and begin to reforest the planet with these giant trees that can make a significant impact on climate change, and to allow us to continue to ramp up to produce more of these special trees.

Perhaps the most efficient tree planting possible is to reforest the Earth with the oldest and most effective carbon filters alive—the ancient Coast Redwoods. With the work of Archangel Ancient Tree Archive, this is now possible. 

We just need your help.

About These Special Second-Generation Tree Clones

  • Redwoods grow faster than almost any other tree in the world, obtaining three to ten feet of growth per year. A normal Redwood can easily reach 65 ft. in height in 20 years.
  • Our special clones are direct copies of these unique giants that tower up to 35 stories and have lived thousands of years, as well as some of the largest and oldest redwoods that ever lived - stumps of trees that have been cut down a hundred years ago but still retain the genetic heritage of the original ancient trees.
  • Why focus on ancient trees? All memory is trapped in DNA, the older the better. It is spelled out in the molecular machinery of a tree and that tree’s relationship to a forest and the forest’s relationship to all life around it. Each event of the past finds its molecular home in the strands of DNA to be represented there, possibly forever. This is called epigenetics.
  • Redwoods safely sequester carbon more efficiently than other organisms on Earth. A typical 25-inch-diameter redwood can store about a ton of carbon.
  • Each Redwood matures to create unique ecosystems that include species of insects, birds, reptiles, and other organisms that exist nowhere else in the world. So while you’re saving the trees, you’re saving the natural life that coexists with them as well. 
  • Archangel takes special care in planting and monitoring each clone in their tenuous first years. Our Redwoods are replanted in areas expected to be cooler than their current range through a process called “assisted migration” for a better chance to survive in our rapidly changing climate.

Meet Some of the Champion Trees

Our living library has been collected from Champion trees and stumps of some of the only remaining old-growth Coast Redwood forests! 

1,600-year-old tree that David Milarch calls "Old Man.” The tree is about 18 feet in diameter. Photo by Jamie Francis, The Oregonian


An original old-growth Coast Redwood named the Ball Stump


The Barrett Tree Fort Stump - one of the largest Coast redwoods that ever lived


We've also cloned the Alonzo Stagg Tree, a Giant Sequoia that's over 3,000 years old. 

Give a gift for the planet!

Every $50 plants one Coast Redwood in the 2015 planting season. Your gift of any size will help us reach our goal and begin to reforest the planet with the giant trees and make an impact on climate change.

Please join us by making a gift today. You can make a big difference by being part of this big effort to be the change you wish to see in the world.

story:
Who We Are:

The Energy East Resistance Ride is a two-month effort by the four of us, Dyanna, Shannon, Zakaria, and Alex, to connect and strengthen grassroots opposition to the proposed Energy East pipeline. This pipeline would bring 1.1 million barrels of tar sands crude oil every day from Alberta to refineries and export terminals on the Atlantic coast. We reject the fiction of the fossil fuel industry that tells us increased tar sands expansion is inevitable. We are working with local partners all along our route, from Sydney, NS, to Ottawa, ON, to create spaces for people to come together over a common desire to protect their land and their climate - beginning with halting the Energy East pipeline. This ride will strengthen the growing resistance to Energy East by connecting the powerful stories of people across eastern Canada who are standing up the fossil fuel industry. We will strive to capture and share the energy of the people we encounter along our tour in a way that is authentic, to serve as a collective narrative of resistance to fossil fuel extraction and its degradation of communities and the environment.


Why We're Fundraising:

Our team is working with local organizers to hold community feasts, direct actions, public art sessions, and other projects to build a stronger network of resistance. We have set a goal of $2 000 to help cover many costs of a two month cycling tour and to enable our team to fund materials that will help us spread resistance and build community. The funds we raise through this page will go towards:

  • Materials to fuel resistance: media kits and poster making materials
  • Food to share with communities
  • Food to fuel ourselves
  • Surprise bike maintenance

Tar sands development has been slowed by people power for years—from the Keystone XL pipeline in the U.S. to the Northern Gateway and TransMountain pipelines in B.C. Now, the folks behind Energy East are hoping to slip this project through before people in eastern Canada have the chance to fight back. We believe deeply in this ride and in the communities we are connecting with. We have already met dozens of people who are doing incredible work and your donation will allow us to invest even more time and energy into sharing their stories.


Other Ways You Can Help:

Can’t contribute right now? No worries! You can support the Energy East Resistance Ride by donating your social reach; share this page on your social media platforms to help us reach our goal.

You can follow our blog to see stories of the incredible people we are meeting along the way: http://energyeastresistanceride.wordpress.com

You can also follow our ride on Facebook, as well as Instagram and Twitter (@energyeastride).


THANK YOU!

story:
The Problem

Site 3 Colaboratory is housed in a unique building. Many decades ago it was a horse stable. Before Site 3 came along, it was a blacksmith shop. As a result, it never got connected to the city sewage and water lines. 

And now the city is making it prohibitively expensive to do so. But Site 3 is a busy place, and it needs a bathroom. So currently, the makerspace uses "fire toilets" to incinerate people's waste, and sends the ashes and smells up a smoke stack. It's just as unpleasant as it sounds.

Being an environmentally-minded person, I was not enthused by this idea. And Site 3's members are tired of the fire toilets constantly breaking down, or scaring away would-be members.

The Solution

With every problem, there comes an opportunity. I had joined Site 3 in order to build a technology that could convert organic waste into renewable energy & fertilizer, without ever leaving the building where it was produced. 

Soon I realized this was the perfect solution to Site 3's toilet problem. Instead of trying to connect to the city infrastructure, we could combine my technology with grey-water recycling and rainwater collection, to make the bathroom completely self-sustaining and "zero waste." Site 3 would become a small island of sustainability in the middle of downtown Toronto.

I hope you will join us in embarking on this pioneering project. You can learn more about the project inception, and keep track of our progress on my blog at www.everflux.tech/blog.

How It Works


Phase 1: Toilet & running water (Flush)

The basic system will include installing a low-flow toilet, waterless urinal and sink. Two IBC tote tanks will be installed below the bathroom, one to hold fresh water to supply the system, and one for "black water," aka toilet waste. The fresh water tank will initially be filled with a hose from a friendly neighbor's house, and the black water tank will be pumped out by a honey truck through a port in the wall of Site 3. We aim to complete Phase 1 by mid-May, allowing members to start using the bathroom ASAP. The materials for this initial phase will cost about $1,800.

Phase 2: Anaerobic digester, grey water recycling and rainwater collection (Recycle)

The anaerobic digester will be made from a water heater tank, and will require a heat exchanger to keep it's temperature at 55 degrees Celsius for 10-15 days in order to fully digest and eliminate all pathogens. It will reduce the volume of solids from the black water by another 50-75%, and convert it into useful byproducts: biogas and fertilizer. Anaerobic bacteria are finicky, so the entire system will require a series of sensors and controls to ensure that all the parameters required to keep the system working are being optimized. In total, this part of the system will cost about $2,200.

The grey water recycling system, which will treat water from the sink only, will consisting of eight buckets in two parallel rows. The bucket system will include a) settling tank, b) anaerobic sludge blanket, c) bio-membrane filter and d) a second bio-membrane filter. Finally, the water will run through a UV filter before it returns to the fresh water tank. This part of the system is relatively inexpensive, except for the UV filter. The total cost comes to about $700, with nearly half that going to the UV filter (they're expensive). The inspiration for our system came from Bob Crosby at Biorealis: 


Finally, Site 3 has been blessed with a metal roof that is perfect for rainwater collection. Installing gutters along the edges, and a pipe that runs into the freshwater tank, should allow Site 3 to completely replenish the water that leaves the system through the black water tank and eliminate the need to use the hose. This will cost another $300.

The entire system should be up and running by early July. Again, we will be posting regular updates here, and at www.everflux.tech/blog.


What We Need

Site 3 is a non-for-profit that is 100% funded by its members. The makerspace makes just enough money to cover paying for the space and other basic expenses. Any extra cash available typically goes into maintaining or upgrading the equipment and machines that are vital to the workshop's livelihood.

We are asking for $5,000 to cover the cost of materials to construct this system. Labour will be provided by volunteers. 

Cost Breakdown

Phase 1: Toilet & Running Water (toilet, sink, piping, fresh water and black water tanks, pumps): $1,800

Phase 2: Anaerobic Digester (tank, pump, piping, heat exchanger, preprocessing equipment, sensors & controls): $2,200

                 Grey-water Recycling (buckets, pumps, piping, bio-filter, UV filter): $700

                 Rainwater Collection (Gutters, drainage piping): $300

TOTAL: $5,000


The Impact

Today, the world faces a number of potentially disastrous crises, involving scarcity of healthy food, fresh water and clean energy. Waste and pollution from our current food, water and energy systems are accumulating at alarming rates. Places like China, Japan and Europe are already facing severe resource shortages, and North America is next. Check out this humorous, yet depressing clip of John Oliver talking about food waste in America.


What most people don't realize is that the food and sewage waste that we try to get rid of everyday can actually be transformed into valuable resources with the right technologies.

Anaerobic digestion is the key to this transformation. But so far in the modern world, its potential has remained hugely unrealized. This project will demonstrate the potential for onsite anaerobic digestion of organic waste in an urban setting. Renewable biogas can be used for cooking in restaurants, or for water or space heating in buildings. Readily available organic fertilizer in cities could lead to more urban farming. And diverting food waste from landfills, and sewage from our lakes and rivers will leave our land and water much cleaner for future generations.


Risks & Challenges

Building a small plumbing system such as the one proposed for Phase 1 (Flush) is nothing new. The basic concepts for grey water recycling system are also well documented.

The greatest challenge will be constructing the anaerobic digester. While designs for home-sized digesters are abundant, choosing the right one for our situation proved to be a challenge, since most designs are for warm climates like those in India and Africa. Luckily, the basic technology is quite simple: you need an air-tight compartment that is corrosion resistant, can be pressurized, is well insulated and can be easily and efficiently heated. We decided that a modified water heater tank seemed like the perfect fit. But there will be some experimentation involved in getting it right, since no one has ever built a biodigester from a hot water tank, as far as we can tell. So there is a risk that our first attempt at building the biodigester won't work quite right, or will be more expensive to build than we thought.

In order to ensure technical success, we've put together a team that has quite a bit of relevant experience:

Oluchi Chiazor spent three years as a project manager designing and constructing biogas plants in Malaysia.

Patrick Vipond operates an onboard wastewater treatment system for a cargo vessel.

Jacob Botden is an automation and control engineer for a company that operates a building with an onsite sewage system. 

Kris Coward has been a liveaboard sailor for the past 12 years, and
converted his sewage system to a composting toilet 6 years ago.


If we do not meet our funding goal, we will still proceed with the first phase of the project, and anything else we can afford. If there is a small deficit, we will likely ask Site 3 members to make up the difference. So the project will still move forward, just not quite to the full extent we had envisioned.

If we surpass our goal, there are additional features we'd like to add, such as a place to grow plants in the building, a stove top to use biogas for cooking, and a backup generator that can use the biogas to generate electricity when the power goes out.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can afford to contribute, so if you'd really like to get involved, here are some ways you can help:

1) Spread the word. Please post about us on your Facebook, Twitter, and talk it up with your friends at your next BBQ.

2) Contribute expertise. If you've ever built or operated an anaerobic digester or grey water recycling system, and you've got some ideas for us, we'd love to hear from you! These technologies are still relatively young and we need innovative ideas to make them better. Please email me with your ideas: info@everflux.tech.
story_txt:
The Problem
Site 3 Colaboratory is housed in a unique building. Many decades ago it was a horse stable. Before Site 3 came along, it was a blacksmith shop. As a result, it never got connected to the city sewage and water lines. 

And now the city is making it prohibitively expensive to do so. But Site 3 is a busy place, and it needs a bathroom. So currently, the makerspace uses "fire toilets" to incinerate people's waste, and sends the ashes and smells up a smoke stack. It's just as unpleasant as it sounds.

Being an environmentally-minded person, I was not enthused by this idea. And Site 3's members are tired of the fire toilets constantly breaking down, or scaring away would-be members.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Shayna Gladstone. For my entire life I've been envisioning this harmonic life for everyone on the planet. This harmonic life where everyone comes together in their communities to empower each other, develop sustainable and regenerative food creation and become a positively charged united force to create peace, love and responsibility to our planet. 

This harmonic life is being built and it's SO radical and transformative! I've just moved from Chicago to an awesome intentional community just ouside Austin, TX called CREATION FLAME. I am here to jump-start the building project,manage their social media and fund raise!  

Here, we've created a space for anyone to learn to live sustainably, love fearlessly and heal naturally. As a Non-Profit organization we do need your help to maintain the greatness we're creating!

What We Need 

For this project we need $5500 in order to purchase the supplies to build our Compressed Earth Block home. We're so grateful to have an amazing team of volunteers provided by Design-Build-Live that will be taking care of the labor of the house. 

This house is going to be completely sustainable and will include: Passive thermal design, minimal resource footprint. local/on-site & recycled supplies, cob, berms, and enhanced beauty versus sterile drywall stick frame houses. The bricks will be made using Open Source Ecology's Liberator CEB press, which Creation Flame was the first in the world to replicate! This earth brick house will be a demonstration of radical energy efficiency that many people can afford.

All funds go to building the Earth Brick Home! 

The Impact

This project is extremely valuable to create a model for existing and future sustainable communities. We're creating this project to show that building an eco-home with modern comforts is very affordable and attainable. It's vital that from here on out much focus and energy be in transforming our society to live in harmony with nature. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any funds to donate please spread the word about this radical project through your e-mail and social media outlets! I'm unbelievably grateful for any assistance in materializing this design!

story:
Who are we?

El Fuego del Sol Haiti (FdS) is a small Haitian developmental enterprise that began production of alternative cooking fuel in 2012. At our Port-au-Prince facility, FdS employs twenty workers that were displaced by the 2010 earthquake to produce a clean cooking fuel briquette out of equal parts recycled paper, recycled cardboard, and saw-dust. Agricultural waste from sugarcane, corn, palm, etc. can also be used.

Currently, less than 2% of Haiti's natural forest cover has been cut down to produce charcoal fuel, and charcoal cooking causes chronic pulmonary diseases in the women who cook for hours on end over charcoal stoves daily. Moreover, the typical Haitian family spends roughly 30% of family income on fuel expenses alone. El Fuego del Sol was created to give the Haitian people an alternative cooking fuel that would protect their homes and environment, and to encourage a higher standard of living throughout the country. 

FdS has been in operation for nearly one year now, and it has grown dramatically. In the last year FdS has grown from 2 volunteers to 20 workers that are paid a living wage and fed lunch at work every day.  FdS has formed crucial partnerships with important local institutions like MINUSTAH, the World Food Program, the International Organization for Migration, the US Embassy, The Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves, American NGO Rebuild Globally, and Haitian NGO Haiti Communitere.

 

FdS partners with our American sponsor, Rebuild Globally,

       all donations made to FdS are tax-deductible!

 

What We Need & What You Get

With our current team of 20 employees, FdS can produce 80,000 fuel briquettes every month. This school year we anticipate a demand of 300,000 briquettes per month for the school feeding program. FdS has the capacity to meet this production level if we can hire an additional 15 workers before October. 

With new funds, FdS will be able to set up a cookstove assembly workshop in our Port-au-Prince facility and buy the materials necessary to build the stoves so that we do not have to import foreign stoves.

Funding from you will allow FdS to hire 15 more workers to produce briquettes and stoves to meet the demand of the school feeding program!

FdS needs funds since FdS just purchased a new waste collection truck and will hopefully buy a second truck soon so that FdS will be able to service additional waste suppliers. FdS pays the facility cost of $2000 every month for rent. Your donation will help FdS generate additional income by providing paper waste pickup service to more and more suppliers! Your support will help us expand. Long-term, FdS is financially self-sustainable through providing ecological waste collection and recycling services to clients in P-a-P.

 

The Impact

Your contribution to the success of El Fuego del Sol is invaluable to the people of Haiti. FdS is providing multiple services that are severely lacking in the Haitian economy.

FdS is providing a crucial alternative to harmful charcoal cooking. Most Haitian families spend roughly 30% of their income on the charcoal fuel that is destroying the natural forests of Haiti and damaging the health of its cooks. Ten pounds of wood from beautiful trees is destroyed in order to make one pound of charcoal in Haiti, and most charcoal in Haiti now comes illegally from the Dominican Republic. If the DR closes its borders, Haiti will fall into nationwide crisis. Fuel briquettes can save Haiti from crisis.

El Fuego del Sol is committed to long-term financial sustainability. FdS is dedicated to providing quality products that benefit the Haitian people while employing displaced skilled Haitians who now have the ability to feed their families and improve their community.

FdS needs to expand now to meet demand for this year, and you can give it the headstart it needs to be competitive!

 

Don't forget that donations to El Fuego del Sol

      are tax-deductible in the United States!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a donation now, we can still use your help! 

Share our campaign with your friends! Please use the media sharing links below to find us on facebook, twitter, youtube, and our website!

Contact Kevin@elfuegodelsol.com to find out more about ways you can help us!

Volunteer or intern with FdS-Haiti!

story:
Who we are:

We are “Radnor to River" (www.radnor2river.org), a local grass roots organization working closely together with the Tennessee Parks and Greenway Foundation (TennGreen) to preserve clean waterways, woods, wildlife in and around Nashville. TennGreen is a non-profit organization, working statewide to preserve and protect the natural treasures of Tennessee, now and for future generations.

Our mission in Nashville:

Nashville is one of the fastest growing cities in the US. The building boom threatens many up to now untouched areas of pristine forests around the city. As part of our effort to create an ecological corridor in the SW area of the city, we have purchased a 4-acre tract in Bellevue, a suburb of Nashville, using a short term the loan.  We are currently raising funds to pay back this loan.

Why is this property worth protecting? 

The 4-acre forested parcel contains a limestone cave that supports bats, five species of sensitive salamanders, other cave-associated wildlife and a clean head water spring.  The front of the cave is a well house once used as a natural refrigerator by the last farmer in the adjacent valley.


Above the cave rises a steep 300-foot hill on top of which grows a flora unique and typical for highland acid soil, including azaleas, farkleberry and blueberry bushes, service berry trees, as well as old chestnut oaks. 


Below the ridge three creeks  converge to create the headwaters of Flat Creek, one of the many tributaries to the Harpeth River watershed. One creek flows permanently out of the cave.  The other two creeks run along long valleys that end on a ridge where an old wall marks the boundary of the famous Belle Meade plantation. Our 4-acre parcel is an entryway to valleys and ridges not logged for at least the last 80 – 100 years, hosting mature trees including majestic sweet gums, one of which was designated the champion sweet gum tree of Nashville of 2014.

A 50-minute hike from this property leads to a waterfall (the West Meade waterfall) also recently protected by TennGreen and now a Metro wilderness park. The entire area encompasses 230 undeveloped acres much of which is currently open deeded land but is under threat of being developed.  


The Cave Property provides not only an entryway to this remarkable open land in West Nashville. It is also a key part of a potential ecological corridor that could connect the largest urban park complex in the nation: Percy and Edwin Warner Parks, with the untouched woods and the Waterfall park. Our hope is to extend this corridor to form an arc that connects Radnor Lake State Park with the Cumberland River (Radnor to River) and beyond. For more information see the recent article in The Tennessean (or go to:  www.tennessean.com and search for “Small cave saved”).

Considerable work still needs to be done.

We want to remove a chain-link fence and several old metal structures as well as a considerable amount of trash (bottles, aluminum cans, paint buckets and plastic material) that has been dumped on the property.  In addition, we must remove the exotic invasive plants that have completely over grown the forest rim and replace them with native plants. Although with the help of a number of volunteers, we are already in the process of cleaning up, we need funds to remove the debris and to reintroduce the native plants, thereby re-establishing the original natural setting of the forest. We are determined to beautify this precious piece of land for the benefit and enjoyment of the nearby neighbors and other visitors.  

Please help finance our effort. Although a 4 acre parcel may seem like a small piece of land, it is an important first step toward protecting more of the forestland that both we and the wildlife that inhabit our woodlands rely on for health and wellbeing.

out of the cave.  The other two
creeks run along long valleys that end on a ridge where an old wall marks the
boundary of the famous Belle Meade plantation. Our 4-acre parcel is an entryway
to valleys and ridges not logged for at least the last 80 – 100 years, hosting
mature trees including majestic sweet gums, one of which was designated the champion sweet gum tree of Nashville of 2014.A 50-minute hike from this
property leads to a waterfall (the West Meade waterfall) also recently
protected by TennGreen and now a Metro wilderness park. The entire area encompasses 230
undeveloped acres much of which is currently open deeded land but is under
threat of being developed.  
The Cave Property provides not
only an entryway to this remarkable open land in West Nashville. It is also a
key part of a potential ecological corridor that could connect the largest urban
park complex in the nation: Percy and Edwin Warner Parks, with the untouched
woods and the Waterfall park. Our hope is to extend this corridor to form an
arc that connects Radnor Lake State Park with the Cumberland River (Radnor to
River) and beyond. For more information see the recent article in The Tennessean (or go to:  www.tennessean.com
and search for “Small cave saved”).Considerable work still needs to be done.We want to remove a chain-link fence and several old metal structures as
well as a considerable amount of trash (bottles, aluminum cans, paint buckets and
plastic material) that has been dumped on the property.  In addition, we must remove the exotic
invasive plants that have completely over grown the forest rim and replace them
with native plants. Although with the help of a number of volunteers, we are
already in the process of cleaning up, we need funds to remove the debris and to
reintroduce the native plants, thereby re-establishing the original natural
setting of the forest. We are determined to beautify this precious piece of
land for the benefit and enjoyment of the nearby neighbors and other visitors.  Please help finance our effort.
Although a 4 acre parcel may seem like a small piece of land, it is an
important first step toward protecting more of the forestland that both we and
the wildlife that inhabit our woodlands rely on for health and wellbeing.

story:
Almost There! We have just one remaining campaign stretch goal:


We are raising money to support the water monitoring and oil clean-up efforts taking place in the Sundarbans, the largest mangrove forest in the world. If you haven't heard, earlier this month an oil tanker capsized deep inside this UNESCO World Heritage Site, home to people, the rare Irrawaddy Dolphin, the endangered Bengal Tiger, and countless other species--many that are endangered. Now, waterways throughout the Sundarbans are contaminated with furnace oil, a threat to human life, bio, and eco diversity of the mangrove forest. 

What We Are Trying to Do:

Our plan is to complement the work of the Bangladeshi government and the UN by bringing together a group of local and international experts who can assist with advanced cumulative water testing, monitoring, and cleanup of the site.

As part of its "We Are There" campaign, Water Defense will send a small team to test the water column at various points throughout the affected Sundarbans.  We are using advanced methods and extremely sensitive environmental indicators that detect and monitor the full gamut of contaminants over a period of time.  As qualified third party testers, Water Defense will be able to provide independent analysis of the situation. See more about the "We Are There" Initiative here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m-Omx92hDqc

Water Defense will bring a large quantity of open-celled foam, (OPFLEX), which acts as synthetic eelgrass, to assist with the ongoing oil spill clean-up effort. Once onsite in the affected area, this team will deploy OPFLEX materials in the water along main anchoring lines and/or other structures (e.g. boats). The deployment will include mesh belt booms configured into long rolls for deployment with boats, and the synthetic eelgrass.

Who are we? 

We are Water Defense, a non-profit based in the United States, working to protect water.  We have engaged a group of Bangladeshis and global citizens who want to help protect the fragile Sundarbans ecosystem and the human communities living nearby.  We are working with TED Fellows, Fulbright Fellows, Global Shapers, oil spill specialists, conservationists, and more. 

Water Defense was founded in 2012 by the award-winning American actor Mark Ruffalo. Ruffalo was recently honored for his work on behalf of clean water and the environment with the Britannia Humanitarian Award from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA).

Scott Smith, Water Defense's Chief Scientist, is the Founder and Inventor of OPFLEX technology.  He studied chemistry at Baylor University and received his MBA at Harvard University. When oil contaminated floodwaters destroyed his factory in 2006, Scott discovered his open-celled foam material’s oleophilic nature, and subsequently dedicated his entire career to removing oil and other contaminants from water across the globe. Scott has tested various designs of OPFLEX at over 50 worldwide water-related disasters, and works regularly with scientists from the University of Massachusetts (UMASS), New York University (NYU), and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.

What is OPFLEX Technology?

OPFLEX technology was approved and used by BP America to help remove oil from water during the Deepwater Horizon spill off the U.S. Gulf Coast in 2010, and is included on the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) National Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan (NCP) list. OPFLEX is also listed and approved by the Italian EPA and has been approved and deployed by the government of Bermuda. 

In November 2014, testing at the United States Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement's OHMSETT facility demonstrated that OPFLEX can remove over 80% of spilled oil from water.  A summary video can be accessed here.

Downloadable white papers describing the efficacy of the technology as proven in real world disasters are available here.

And why do this?

The current standard of water monitoring doesn't test for the full gamut of oils, volatiles, semi-volatiles, metals, and metalloids -- but Water Defense can.  Due to the size of this spill and the sensitive nature of the Sundarbans, Water Defense will bring its cumulative water testing to the Sundarbans and share our findings to educate and inform the world.

To Bangladeshi Readers: The Sundarbans is our birthright. It is a unique, fragile ecosystem found nowhere else in the world! If we do not care for the Sundarbans today, it might no longer exist for our children and grandchildren.

To All Other Global Citizens: There are over 300 species of plants, 150 species of fish, 270 species of birds, 42 species of mammals, 35 reptiles, and 8 amphibian species. Two amphibians, 14 reptiles, 25 aves, and 5 mammals living in the Sundarbans are endangered. The affect of the oil spill on this fragile ecosystem will be wide reaching and long lasting. Help us bring in a team of experts to assist in the clean up of the spill.

How we can help clean the Mangroves:

Check out Chief Scientist of Water Defense, Scott Smith, demonstrate one of the remediation strategies that we can offer for the Sundarbans:

How we plan to test and monitor the waterways for contamination:

This video highlights how we plan to test the water column throughout the affected areas.  It was our announcement from the December 2014 Uplift presentation :


Other remediation tools we plan to donate to the Sundarbans cleanup effort:


How can you participate:

There are many ways you can help, whether you are on the ground in the Sundarbans or at home on your computer.

1) SHARE INFORMATION ABOUT THE SPILL ON SOCIAL MEDIA: The most obvious way is by sharing information about the oil spill on your social media page to keep it top of mind. For the latest information check on Twitter @Sundarbans_SOS for regular updates and remember to use the hashtag #SundarbansOilSpill.

2) DONATE TO THIS CAMPAIGN: Every little bit counts! 

Cost Breakdown (subject to change as situation/necessity changes):

1) Cumulative Water Column Testing and helping to remediate impacted areas: $15,000

2) Travel for 2 experts from the US: $10,000

3) Additional Aid TBD: $15,000

Total Ask: $40,000

Stretch Goals:

4) Grants for local experts, working in conjunction with professors and students (under proper supervision), from Universities in Bangladesh to deploy Water Defense water testing and remediation technology: $12,500

5) Additional Water Defense Cumulative Water Column Testing and remediation aid: Depending on our assessment from feedback of people on the ground: $12,500

Note: The budget above is our best estimate of the funds we will need, but the reality on the ground is constantly changing. If our team of experts finds that this technology is no longer necessary, funds will be used for future spills and evaluation missions to ensure the health of the Sundarbans ecosystem. 

How will the funds be used?

The money we collect will go directly to Water Defense, a registered NGO in the United States. The money we raise in this international account will be used for non-cash based transactions, as we see fit. However, it may be necessary to transfer some of these funds to a local account for cash-based transactions necessary while traveling in the Sundarbans area. 

Any extra donations above and beyond will be used to support the affected communities of the Sundarbans.

All donations are being tracked transparently. If you have questions at any time about what has been donated, please contact us for a full report.


[OTHER BACKGROUND INFORMATION]

More About the Spill:

At 6am on December 9, 2014, an oil tanker carrying an estimated 357,000 liters (77,000 gallons) of furnace oil was anchored overnight in the Sela River because of dense fog and poor visibility. Another empty tanker hit this tanker, causing it to capsize.

Impact of the accident:

Waterways throughout the Sundarbans are being contaminated with furnace oil, which is a threat to the bio and eco diversity of the mangrove forest. The oil spill has already blackened the shoreline, spreading over a 60-kilometre-long (37-mile-long) area of the Sundarbans and threatening trees, plankton, and populations of small fish and dolphins. 

About The Sundarbans:

The Sundarbans is the world's biggest mangrove forest. Spread over 10,000 square kilometres (3,800 square miles), the Sundarbans is a UNESCO-listed World Heritage Site and home to hundreds of the last remaining Bengal tigers. It is also the largest known home of the rare Irrawaddy Dolphins, which can be found only in South East Asia.  The Sundarbans delta comprises a network of rivers and canals.

The Bangladeshi government established a sanctuary in the Sundarbans in 2011 after studies found that there were hundreds of endangered Irrawaddy and Ganges River Dolphins living in the area. Fishing is now banned, but tankers and other boats are allowed to pass through.

About The Sela River:

Mongla port, one of the most economically important ports in Bangladesh apart from Chittagong, is situated on the Sela River, which runs through the Sundarbans.

Why was an oil tanker travelling through the Sundarbans?

The alternative route from Mongla to Ghashiakhali has been closed for three years. All commercial vehicles travelling from Mongla Port (the second busiest port in the country) must take this route through the River Shyala.

Why has the Mongla-Ghashiakhali route been closed for 3 years?

The Mongla-Ghashiakhali channel became unsuitable for shipping three years ago due to excessive silt build-up in the Kumarkhali River. The BIWTA began dredging the 22-km channel in July of this year and were set to complete the project in early 2015. Read more here.

Who else is involved in our efforts?

Bangladeshi NGO Amader Gram has been immensely helpful in getting this off the ground. We are extremely grateful for all of their hard work helping us collect local donations.

Coverage in the media:

  • http://birdgirluk.blogspot.co.uk/2014/12/the-sundarbans-oil-spill-part-1.html

  • http://birdgirluk.blogspot.co.uk/2014/12/the-sundarbans-oil-spill-part-2.html

  • https://soundcloud.com/bbc-world-service/sundarbans-oil-spill-public-health-disaster-an-ecological-mess

  • http://www.thedailystar.net/animals-start-to-die-54929
